TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on its inquiry into the operation of the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This inquiry arose out of the consideration by the Committee of the Education Services (Export Regulations) Bill 1990. In reporting to the Senate on the Bill, in May 1991, the Committee recommended that:
. . . the operation of the Bill, if passed as an Act, be referred back to the Committee for inquiry and report, on, or before the first sitting day in December 1992.

In August this year, the Committee wrote to the Department of Employment, Education and Training and organisations representing both the industry and students seeking submissions on the operation of the ESOS Act. A public hearing involving interested parties was held on 9 October. The exercise of reviewing the implementation and operation of the Act has been a worthwhile one.

PARA.TAB: The review made it clear that, while there have been some problems in implementing the legislation, it has provided a coherent regulatory framework at the national level for safeguarding the financial stability of institutions involved in the provision of educational services to overseas students.

The major recommendation arising from this review is that the date of the sunset clause on which the legislation would cease to have effect should be amended from 1 January 1994 to 1 January 1995. The Committee recommended this change in the date of effect of the sunset clause for two reasons. The first was the need expressed by industry representatives for a stable policy environment. The second reason for extending the operation of the Act was the slow pace at which the States have moved to bring in legislation to provide financial security for fees paid by overseas students.

The Committee has also recommended that a number of other minor amendments be made to the Act and regulations in the light of the experience of both the industry and the Department of Employment, Education and Training during the first year of operation of the legislation. These changes include the addition of a time limit of 28 days for the repayment of fees under subsection 6(5) of the Act and the alteration of the heading for section 7 from `Insurance' to `Guarantee of Fees'.

I would like to thank, on behalf of the Committee, all those who assisted it in its review of the legislation, whether by way of appearing as witnesses or preparing submissions. I commend the report with its recommendations and conclusions to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator McMullan)—by leave—agreed to:
That the following Government Business, orders of the day, be taken together for their remaining stages:

No. 2—Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1992-93
Debate resumed from 30 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main purpose of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) is to give effect to the announcement of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) on 13 November of plans to reallocate $150m from rail expenditures and $24m from electricity expenditures, contained in the Budget, to other infrastructure and labour market projects. The introduction of these additional Appropriation Bills at this time is extraordinary. The Bills reappropriate funds from Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2), which had not even been passed by the Senate before the Treasurer's 13 November statement.

PARA.TAB: The Budget Appropriation Bills are only two months old and already the Government has been forced to admit that $174m of proposed spending in 1992-93 cannot be achieved. The timing of these Bills reflects the economic shambles of the Government's economic and budgetary mismanagement. It is totally politically driven. It shows yet again that we cannot trust Labor with our money or our jobs. It is more evidence of the Government trying to push some people out of the official unemployment statistics through hasty, make-work spending.

These Bills demonstrate the failure of the Government's economic policies. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has no answers to the massive unemployment he has caused. This is one more shameful attempt to buy our way out of our problems. It is clear that the Government has turned its back on the structural reforms required to really get employment growing again. It has all become too hard. These Bills are looking for an easy solution, but they will only disguise the problems in the short term and worsen the economic prospects of the economy in the medium term. The failures of this Government's policies are reflected in the failures of One Nation and in the failures of the Budget, which the Government has recognised, as seen through its back-pedalling on some of its One Nation and Budget commitments in these Bills. But it is still on the wrong track.

What were the promises of One Nation? They were: more jobs, tax cuts, increased infrastructure spending and, in the words of Mr Keating, `A statement to get Australia moving; a four-year strategy for growth in the nineties'. Those were the promises. What has materialised? Since February, for every new job created in Australia two have been lost. Tax cuts were premised on totally unrealistic growth forecasts and with recourse to secret tax increases. They cannot be delivered. These Bills show how much of the promised increased infrastructure spending is now being diverted into other things.

As for being a four-year strategy for growth, in February the One Nation growth forecast was 4 3/4 per cent. In June it was reduced to 4 per cent. By the Budget in August it was down to 3 per cent. Now it is anyone's guess how much lower still it will go after the release of today's national accounts figures. Three wrong estimates in nine months. So much for the promises of One Nation, in which the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1992 we need recovery and we need jobs.

Keating's One Nation statement has failed to deliver on any of its promises. What the Prime Minister did not say was that an export-led recovery is what we need. Just how far we have to go on that front was shown in the October balance of payments figures, released yesterday, which revealed a massive $1.8 billion deficit—the highest in nearly three years—and an incredible 11 per cent fall in exports in just one month. As for unemployment, the Prime Minister said in February this year:
If the economy grows, employment grows . . . If we can't do better than 4 per cent GDP growth, we should pack it in—me, the bureaucracy, the Parliament, the lot of us . . .

But full time employment is now lower than it was in February when that statement was made, which shows again that we just cannot trust Labor with our jobs or our money. We need change in Australia; we need it desperately. We need commonsense change and we need it now.

PARA.TAB: Every piece of economic news since the release of One Nation has shown just what a sham that One Nation document was. The lies behind the outrageously optimistic forecasts and the platitudinous statements by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to gild the budgetary lily are now all being exposed. How could anyone have claimed in One Nation that the Budget would be returned to surplus in four years? It has not taken long for that Labor lie to come unstuck.

In February, the starting point for this year's Budget deficit was projected by the Government as $8 billion. In May, that was revised to $10.5 billion. The August Budget said $13.4 billion. The Government's own financial estimates from the Bureau of Statistics last week now suggest $14.5 billion and even this $14.5 billion already looks highly optimistic. The Prime Minister has backed right off his promise of a return to surplus. The One Nation statement says:

SPEECH.PARA: With our strategy, within four years the Federal Budget will return to surplus.
But in a pathetic interview with Kerry O'Brien on Lateline less than a fortnight ago he said:
But since when did we have to get back to surpluses? Since when are they holy writ?
The Prime Minister himself seemed to think that surpluses were pretty important, and rightly so. In the 1986-87 Budget, when he was Treasurer, he said:

We must save for the future rather than spend for the present. The Government can help this process directly by spending less and borrowing less, thereby improving the climate for lower interest rates and for private sector investment.

There have been numerous statements since then about the importance of Budget surpluses. In the 1990-91 Budget Speech he said that the Budget will `build on the fiscal achievements secured to date and maintains fiscal policy as the Government's principal weapon in the fight against the current account deficit and our overseas debt'. In the accompanying Budget statements, the then Treasurer said:
What is vital is that those policies—including maintenance of high levels of public sector saving—continue over the 1990s.
Even Treasurer Dawkins's last Budget Speech contained the same theme when he said `the Government will eliminate the deficit as soon as possible'. The accompanying papers to this year's Budget state:

The Budget deficit will need to be progressively wound back. Fiscal policy can then resume its important medium term role of increasing national saving and reducing recourse to foreign financing of domestic investment.

Where are all those fine and correct sentiments now? The political heat has been turned up and the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have welshed on all of that. They have given up on fiscal policy and instead they have chosen to play subsidy politics. Dr Ross Garnaut, a former economic adviser to the Hawke Government, has strongly criticised the so-called fiscal boost of which the spending in these Bills is a part. Asked last week if short term Budget stimulation would aid the recovery, Garnaut said:

I think if you pump up domestic demand—a bit more government expenditure—that's an illusion. That slows down the fundamental structural change that'll end up delivering more good jobs at high incomes.

Like so many others then, Garnaut is focusing on the importance of structural change, so-called micro-economic reform. But not only is the fiscal house out of control, the Prime Minister has given up on micro-economic reform as well. A fortnight ago, again in the same infamous Kerry O'Brien Lateline interview, the Prime Minister said that the great micro reform agenda was mostly completed. That is another lie which was exposed with the release of the Industry Commission's annual report last week. That report stated:

The imperative is to act quickly and to tackle reform on a broad front . . . However, in light of what governments must do to lift Australia's economic performance, reform initiatives have been lacking in number and scope.

In fact, the Industry Commission report makes it clear that not only is the Government's agenda not broad enough, but also it has let many promised reforms slip, including backtracking by the National Road Transport Commission, increasing assistance for footwear, delayed reforms in the sugar and dairying industries and many more examples stated in that report. In a total reverse of the Prime Minister's statement, the report states, `Clearly, much more remains to be done'. So much for the Prime Minister's statement that the great micro-economic reform agenda has been almost completed. What absolute nonsense.

PARA.TAB: These are not the only problems highlighted in the Industry Commission report. Elsewhere in this very carefully considered document there is direct criticism of other Government policy areas. For example, in some areas the gains do not seem to have been passed on to users. Through the national procurement and development program there is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a danger of damaging Australia's competitiveness by encouraging subsidy dependence and weakening the capacity of markets to determine R&D priorities.

Dr Hewson has said that the IC report shows the fictional nature of the Government's incessant boasts about micro-economic reform. They are incessant boasts, and they are absolutely fictional. The Industry Commission report makes a very strong case that, without accelerating the pace of micro-economic reform on a broad front, unemployment will remain at high levels for the rest of the decade, even if our underlying GDP growth is strengthened. It is no surprise that the labour market is seen as the area in most need of reform. The report states:
Much more is to be gained from extending reform . . . particularly removing impediments to the efficient operation of labour markets.

But labour market reform has been in the too hard basket for this Government throughout its whole term of office. The Commission report again makes it clear that the training levy is the last way we should be looking to improve our productivity, and it emphasises clearly the need for more flexibility in the labour market. Here is just some of the flavour of the report's statements on this issue:
Increased flexibility in wages and conditions would allow current and prospective employees to judge where skill shortages are greatest and where there would be pay-offs to additional training.

Precisely; that is just what the coalition's labour market reforms would deliver. The report endorses very strongly what the coalition has been saying in this area of labour market reform. The report goes on to say:
More closely aligning remuneration to skill levels would see some unwinding of currently compressed wage relativities.

Again, that is precisely what a coalition government would deliver. They are not just propositions to get Australians back into jobs. They are not just our propositions; they are also the propositions of one of the Government's most respected advisory bodies.

PARA.TAB: It is not only Government reports making such claims. Douglas Myers, a leading New Zealand businessman and the Chief Executive of Lion Nathan—which owns the Swan, Tooheys and Castlemaine Perkins breweries—has criticised the economic and industrial reforms in Australia as moving far too slowly. Indeed he, with vast business experience on both sides of the Tasman, says that in Australia the reforms have been so slow that he considers Australia is now a decade behind New Zealand. How could anyone have believed that that could be the case just five or 10 years ago?

The Chief Executive of Heinz Australia has pointed out that labour on-costs in Australia—which include payroll tax, work premiums, rostered days off, sick leave, long service leave, annual leave, leave loadings and shift premiums—add 33 per cent to wage costs, whereas in New Zealand the figure is closer to 16 per cent. In total, the cost of employing people in New Zealand is only 64 per cent of what it is in Australia. That is why Heinz Australia is using New Zealand, not Australia, as a base for the whole of its South East Asian operations.

Faced with these facts, the Prime Minister and the Government have decided that they will turn their back on the only road to real solutions and, instead, put a few bandaids on the massively haemorrhaging economy with these Bills that we are debating today. This is in the hope that things will hold together until the election is over, in the hope that we will be able to hide some of the one million Australians who are now unemployed.

The mickey mouse job creation schemes which are added to in these Bills just do not work. All the statistics since One Nation show that. Yet this Government is simply trying to deliver more of the same. When the money runs out—and that is our money; the taxpayers' money—so will the jobs. There will be no long term jobs, just a bigger debt bill to hang around our necks for decades to come. This is a blatant attempt to get people off the dole queues until after the election.

Labor fails to see that real job creation requires the lifting of the load from business. After all, it is business, not governments, that creates real jobs. This is one of the central planks of the coalition reform agenda. That is why we will remove a massive $20,000m tax burden from business and why our industrial relations reforms will allow us to have the flexibility and innovation to not only take on the best of the world, but also beat them. We can do it together, but the Government has to stop getting in the way and it has to be prepared to create the right environment for commonsense change, which is what our reforms are all about.

Criticism is even coming from within Labor's own ranks. The former Premier of Victoria, John Cain, stated the other day that the Keating Government is in an `economic policy vacuum' and in no shape to govern for three more years. Bob Carr, the Labor Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales, said much the same thing yesterday. He laid the blame for the disgrace of youth homelessness and the million unemployed in Australia fairly and squarely on this Federal Labor Government. Let us have a look at the results of 10 years of hard Labor. Again, I quote the Government's own expert advisory body, the Industry Commission. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Comparisons with other countries, and between firms producing comparable outputs—both here and overseas—provide a means of assessing whether an economy is realising its potential. From an international perspective Australia's productivity record suffers by comparison with the achievements of other countries, while at the industrial level there is generally even less to boast about.
The solutions again accord with coalition policies. The report continues:

. . . a consistent message to emerge is that large gains can be achieved through better use of labour and capital resources already employed. The key is better management and a more flexible workforce.

The attempt to generate jobs through the programs in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) will prove just as ineffective as those of One Nation and the Budget. If the Government had not wasted 10 years sitting on its hands, if it had been prepared to act on the structural problems which the coalition has spoken of and addressed in its policy reform package, we need not be in this current malaise.

PARA.TAB: These Bills are not about job creation; they are about vote creation. Let us bring on the election. What the Government is trying to do here is buy votes. Let us put it to the test with an election. The time is right for real change. We have the answers; the Government does not. It has absolutely run out of any answers for the future. It relies totally on the failed policies of the past.

We have very real concerns about these Bills. Quick fixes of the type contained in these Bills are not the answer. I therefore foreshadow that at the conclusion of this second reading debate I will be moving that these Bills be referred to the appropriate Estimates committees for normal consideration and report to the Senate before they are further considered in the Committee of the Whole.

It is very appropriate that the Senate is debating these Bills on this particular day. It comes the day after we have had the worst balance of payments result in almost three years—the ninth successive increase in the balance of payments deficit. In an hour or so we will have the national accounts figures for the September quarter, which are almost certain to show that the economy continues to wallow in the trough of recession and despair. This Government is fairly and squarely, absolutely and totally responsible for the dreadful hardship that most Australians feel nowadays. It is fairly and squarely responsible for the one million Australians who are now unemployed and the further million who are either underemployed or who have dropped out of the work force in despair.

Today is a very significant day in Australia's economic history. It is about 6 1/2 years since the famous banana republic day of May 1986. Today I believe will go down in Australia's economic history, coupled with yesterday's balance of payments result, as a day when we will say to this Government that everything it said correctly about the difficulties facing us in 1986 are still there to be revisited. Not one thing has been done in those last 6 1/2 years to repair that fatal damage that this Government has caused to the community. The sooner we have an election and throw this Government out and introduce a government that has the solutions for the future, that can give hope, growth, prosperity and opportunity for the future, the better it will be. From our point of view, that cannot come a moment too soon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) reallocate the various appropriations to implement the allocation of spending announced recently by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). Appropriation Bill (No. 3) amends Appropriation Act (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) amends Appropriation Act (No. 2). Broadly, money earmarked for infrastructure, specifically $150m for rail projects and $24m for electricity transmission projects, is being reallocated to other functions. The projects have been deferred, as I understand it, not abandoned. This is particularly important in the case of rail projects because the level of Federal Government involvement in developing a national rail system has been improving in recent years. The upgrading promised in the One Nation statement was years overdue and hence very welcome. It would be a national tragedy if the projects were abandoned.

PARA.TAB: The reallocation has apparently occurred because some money could not be spent on the original proposals. In the case of the rail proposals, the relevant planning and design work was not complete and the economic viability of the upgrade of the transmission links between the south-eastern States is dubious at this stage. Given the low level of activity in the economy, the Government has decided to spend this money on alternative projects which can commence and hence generate employment quickly.

The Australian Democrats do not oppose this proposal. Indeed, we support programs to end the misery of unemployment for Australian families. The Opposition cannot have it both ways. It cannot condemn the Government for failing to create jobs and at the same time condemn the Government for recognising impediments to job creation and taking action to overcome these impediments. The replacement spending programs include various training initiatives, including a special package for large employers who are willing to offer to employ at least an additional 100 people who have been unemployed for at least six months, or who qualify as young trainees. A similar scheme is available for regional authorities who employ an additional 200 people. The subsidies offered are substantial. They represent roughly 30 per cent to 40 per cent of the wage cost for each new employee.

I noticed that in his discussion of labour costs, Senator Short did not mention that company executives salaries' rose at more than five times the rate of ordinary employee wage rises over the last year. That is always conveniently overlooked. There are other subsidy arrangements for small business employers in this package in such areas as traineeships and apprenticeships. There is also a program to build sporting infrastructure and a further $30m for the Federal black spot road safety program. Further local government based infrastructure programs receive $55m. There is also a refurbishment for the Old Parliament House.

I notice that we have in front of us a much expanded speakers list. There are now eight Opposition speakers, whereas previously there were four. We have one Democrat and one Government speaker. Obviously, the Opposition is seeking to make some political point of great moment, but I think I can already spot the message: you cannot trust Labor with your jobs or your money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or your money.

—Okay. The problem for the Government is that the people of Australia do not trust it. They do not trust anyone. They do not believe that anybody has the answers. They do not believe that Fightback will seriously create two million jobs over the next decade. That is the problem. I expect further Opposition speakers to berate the Government, but I think that what we ought to do is to say, `Look, it wasn't technically necessary to alter existing appropriations for the deferred expenditure'. As I understand it, appropriations are permissive, as opposed to mandatory. Just because an appropriation item is passed by the Parliament, it does not mean that the expenditure has to proceed; nor that it will.

PARA.TAB: An appropriation merely authorises the Government to spend the amount appropriated. Consequently, it is not necessary to reduce existing appropriations, merely to increase them in the reallocated areas. The Government chose to legislate transparently to show what reallocation was being undertaken. This is good practice. The Opposition wants to send these Bills off to Estimates committees. The Government is not seeking to hide anything. It is good practice and hopefully this will establish a precedent for similar action by future governments, should such reallocation be necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Totally incompetent.

—Senator Panizza should not think that he will get it all right. I believe it is far more preferable to review, to identify impediments and to act than to be wedded inflexibly to ideas which are not working for a range of reasons. The Australian Democrats do not oppose these Bills but we may have identified different priorities. However, given the priorities that have been identified by the Government, we wish them a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to contribute to the debate on Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4. I will concentrate my remarks on the matter of infrastructure that we are supposed to be dealing with. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), in his second reading speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The February One Nation Statement was specifically designed to both revitalise the nation's key economic infrastructure and to deliver a responsible fiscal stimulus to the economy.

We are now six months down the track. I wish Senator Kernot would listen to this statement: the Government now admits that everything has gone wrong. The Government has said that it has reviewed the progress and found that some or all of the allocations are not on track.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with reviewing it?

—There is nothing wrong with reviewing the progress. I am coming to that point. The Government has found that some or all of the allocations are not on track. It has made the startling discovery that logistic and design work for rail projects is behind time.In the Budget and the One Nation statement $283m was provided for the national rail system. That was an admirable allocation. Under this Government, for the last 10 years, rail has been neglected.

PARA.TAB: By introducing Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4 the Government is moving that funding for power transmission to the south-eastern States and it will not be required. I have not gone into why it is not required at this stage.

With respect to rail, if the Government or private enterprise allocates money for a major project surely preliminary design and logistic inquiries should be done. Six months later the Government says that the design inquiries are behind time and are off track. What a weak and stupid excuse. I praise the Government for making that allocation of $283m, but one would have thought that the design work would be on track.

Generally, it is not the fault of the engineers. They know how to get on with the job in hand. What is the problem? I think the Government allocated that figure in the hope that it would look good in the Budget and the One Nation statement. The Government has taken seven or eight months to come up with this excuse. If the Government's excuse that the design and logistic inquiries are behind time is correct, then it must have been a good idea at the time.

Rail will continue to be neglected even though it could have created jobs. Jobs in the area of rail are not mickey mouse jobs. Heavy construction is involved. The jobs are in the factories building the concrete sleepers, out where the track is laid, out where the track is cleared, or where the signalling gear is installed. Meaningful jobs are created. What I thought was the most important part of the One Nation package has been neglected entirely.

Furthermore, once this rail project is completed, and it should be close to completion by now, it will have other effects such as taking the heavy road vehicles off the roads on the long distances where road and rail run alongside each other. Every day we read in the newspapers about accidents with the long haul transporters. If we get more of that freight onto rail, there will be fewer road accidents, and road transport can be used closer to home.

It seems that the main reason for the hold-up of the project has been the failure of the Federal Government to get the concurrence of all the State governments for the link-up of the National Rail Corporation. I understand that Western Australia has finally accepted the package to join the NRC, but it has been a very slow process. The main reason it has been held up has been that the Federal Government wanted to buy out the Westrail section for almost zilch, and of course the Government of Western Australia would not accept that. Of course, it also had other problems with the unions.

Of the money that was supposed to be spent on rail, $1.74m is to be reallocated to more sensitive areas. Appropriation Bill (No. 3) seeks allocation of $125.39m for entry level training and $59.1m for labour market assistance and job seekers. There is also $18.75m for sport and recreation programs for the construction of facilities by local government. We have heard a bit in the press lately about local government with the local government capital grants. It seems to me that local governments are simply using these extra allocations to boost their own budgets.

This legislation also appropriates $30m for the Federal black spots program, to fix the accident black spots on the main highways. I commend that program, which was initiated by the previous Prime Minister and which does seem to be working, although I cannot really see why the accident black spots are in areas of high unemployment. This reallocation of moneys is supposed to create 31,000 jobs—all new positions. Let us see what happens. We certainly need some boost to employment with an unemployment rate in Australia at the moment of 11.1 per cent.

But let us look at what has happened in the past. We are only three months down the track since Appropriation Bills Nos 1 and 2 were debated and passed. We had a promise then that 13,000 new jobs would be created under the local government capital grants program. The Minister for Local Government, David Simmons, in a press release said:

SPEECH.PARA: New and expanded programs in several portfolios, including Employment, Education and Training, Primary Industries and Energy and Land Transport, will be available as part of the Keating Government's strategy to get employment moving at the local level.
In the same press release, under the heading `$350 Million for Local Capital Works Program', he went on to say:

This major new program will allow councils in areas experiencing high and protracted levels of unemployment to undertake capital works projects that they may have the need for, but not the financial capacity to see through.
The press release further stated:

Mr Simmons said this broad national coverage was a very important feature of the program, with metropolitan and rural councils all standing to benefit from projects that will boost local economies and employment and provide worthwhile permanent assets.

It went on further to say that under category 1 there would be a minimum labour force of 60,000 persons. What has happened with that local government employment program? I have said time and again in this place that the only people who will benefit will be those already employed in local government, or contractors for local government. I said it in the debate on the Budget Speech and I said it in debate on the One Nation statement—but, of course, no one believed me.

PARA.TAB: It is finally coming home to roost, as newspaper headlines show. A headline in the Daily Telegraph Mirror of 30 November 1992 reads, `$400,000 pavement scheme down the drain for jobless'. In other words, none of the jobless ever got jobs. Another headline in the same newspaper reads, `$345m empty promise'. Yet another headline reads, `$345m political bonus turns into big liability'. In other words, those local government capital works programs have not added to employment. I believe this will happen again. The work will go to people who are already employed.

Yesterday Senator Tate defended the non-event of 13,000 supposed new jobs. He said that the money would be used to retain jobs. I have gone through One Nation, through the Budget Papers and through Mr Simmons's press release and nowhere does it say that the money was to retain jobs. It was supposed to create new jobs. The best I can find out to date is that it has created four new jobs. Contractors do not necessarily buy materials in those areas where a boost to employment is needed. They buy materials where they can get them the cheapest, and that is not necessarily where grants are made. I presume that we have to agree with the Government that if this money is not getting spent it has to be reallocated. I wish the Government better luck than it had last time.

The leaked document of 12 November from the Taxation Office, as reported in the Australian Financial Review, says that the Tax Office has a $3.4 billion shortfall in tax collection so far this year. GDP was supposed to be a minimum of 4 per cent. I think Mr Keating said he would resign if it fell below that. It is now less than 3 per cent. As time goes by we will be looking for more Bankcard-type financing to try to get Australia's unemployment rate down and keep this Government going. I support what my colleague Senator Short said. The matter should go to a committee and be examined further to see what exactly the Government can do. I wish the Government better luck with this package than it had with One Nation.
Debate interrupted.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Before calling Senator Chapman, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of former Senator Don Jessop from South Australia and welcome him back to the Senate.
Honourable senators—Hear, hear!
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has a profusion of pressing problems brought upon it by a decade of incompetent Labor governments, not only this Federal Labor Government but also many State Labor governments. The most urgent problem is the lack of employment opportunity, which is becoming chronic, for more than 11 per cent of the working population. Virtually one million people are now unable to find a job as a result of the continuing uncertainties in Australia's economy and our lack of economic recovery. Our economy is now in a feeble state as a direct result of 10 years of too much talk and too much Cabinet bravado and far too little action and appropriate initiation of policy reform. The One Nation statement is a further example of too much talk and too little action. It represents a collection of statements, strategies, plans and figures but very little of it has been applied to good effect. The Keating Labor Government has been unable to spend as quickly as it thought a lot of the money it had planned to spend.

PARA.TAB: The Bills we are debating today, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4), demonstrate the complete failure of the Keating Labor Government's economic policy. Even while the annual Budget Bills were being debated in this place, the Government was effectively introducing in the other place a new Budget in the form of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4). This new Budget represents an even more desperate reversion to the old formula of pump priming than did One Nation. At least in the case of One Nation we were offered the possibility of additional provision of infrastructure, particularly in the areas of roads, rail and electricity generation, which have been so badly neglected by this Government. With Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) all we have is traditional, old-fashioned, discredited Keynesian pump priming.

When the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) launched One Nation nine months ago, he boasted that the forthcoming year would demonstrate a need for recovery and for jobs which One Nation would address. Where are the jobs he promised for Australia's one million unemployed? They will not come out of an even bigger deficit which has now blown out to $2.3 billion caused by the One Nation package—a package of promises which this nation simply cannot afford because it is being funded by borrowings.

The One Nation package promised that the Federal Government's Budget would make positive and beneficial contributions to national savings within four years—that is, by 1995-96. It was a package which promised that the Commonwealth's total deficit would peak at 2 per cent of gross domestic product in this financial year—1992-93. But the trouble with these promises is that that is all they are; they have not been delivered. They have never materialised as far as One Nation is concerned, as they have never materialised from past promises of this Government.

We can go back over Budget after Budget of this Government during its 10 years in office. The forecasts and promises which those Budgets made have never been delivered. Now we see that the present Budget deficit will rise to something in excess of 3 per cent of GDP. That is more than 50 per cent worse than the Government promised in its Budget just a few months ago. So the Government now has a very serious Budget deficit problem which it refuses to recognise and take corrective action on.

The only real solution to this country's economic problems is a Federal election and a change of government. We need that desperately because the Keating Government has presided over the worst economic record this country has seen since the Great Depression of the 1930s. The enormity of the Government's ineptitude is self-evident; it is there for all to see. Every day since it was re-elected in 1990 more than 450 people have lost their jobs. We are now fast approaching the situation where we have some 700,000 children whose only parental role models are unemployed. In the last eight years this nation has seen a 26 per cent increase in suicides, with the risk of suicide among unemployed people some 6 per cent greater than the general average.

During the month of the One Nation launch—traditionally the month when school leavers begin their tertiary studies—there were insufficient places at universities and technical and further education colleges to cope with the demand. Well over 200,000 qualified students went home disappointed that there were not places to accommodate them; they missed out on furthering their education for another year.

Australia's foreign debt has escalated so that it now stands at more than $19,000 for every taxpayer who is still lucky enough to have a job and to be paying tax. That foreign debt further escalated with the release yesterday of the disastrous trade deficit figures of $1.8 billion. In the last financial year this country had more than 18 1/2 thousand bankruptcies, the highest number on record for any one financial year. This figure represents a 278 per cent increase since the Hawke-Keating Government was elected, and a 117 per cent increase since the last election in March 1990. That represents nearly 40 bankruptcies a day since that election, which is a tragic yardstick of our economy's poor performance. Bankruptcies do not affect only businesses; they affect individuals. Nationally, it is worth noting that now one in every 255 households has a bankrupt amongst its members.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a disgrace.

—It is an absolute disgrace. In Senator Crane's State the figure is one in 174—which is the worst bankruptcy rate in Australia—demonstrating not only this Government's detrimental effects on the people of that State, but also the detrimental effects of the Western Australian State Government. In my own State of South Australia, one in 175 households has a bankrupt. In 1991 in South Australia the figure was one in 221, so we can see how the situation has worsened in the 12 months between 1991 and 1992. Nationally, the figure has worsened from one in 331 households in 1991 to one in 255 households in 1992. Those figures represent personal, individual bankruptcies, not business bankruptcies. They are bankruptcies which affect individual households and their capacity to provide for their families.

PARA.TAB: Since the first Hawke Government was elected nearly a decade ago, average farm income has fallen by 43 per cent from $29,280 to $20,500. We now find that 25 per cent of all broad acre farms have debts in excess of $130,000. There are staggering debts of more than $194,000 for 25 per cent of livestock and crop combination farming properties, and debts of some $350,000 for 12 per cent of wheat and other crop farms. Again, we find that a very important sector of the Australian community which is an important contributor to the Australian economy is in a very parlous situation.

The Government has an appalling record in a number of areas of its responsibility. Despite a massive increase in fuel excise receipts, we have not seen the level of road funding maintained. What we see at the Federal level is reflected in the individual States. In South Australia, in the 12 months to September 1992 unemployment increased by 9.6 per cent. New fixed capital expenditure fell by 25.3 per cent, and public sector outlays as a percentage of gross State product—that is, public sector spending—increased by 21.5 per cent, while the gross State product fell by 2.5 per cent. In South Australia we find a Labor government presiding over what is only too well documented economic mismanagement, just as the Kirner Labor Government did in Victoria and just as the Labor Government is doing in Western Australia. Sadder still, it is occurring at the national level.

Quite simply, we cannot trust Labor with money and we cannot trust it to manage Australia's economic problems. We urgently need economic reform. In particular, we need the abolition of those taxes which impact directly on the cost of producing goods and services in Australia, such as the wholesale sales tax, payroll tax, fuel excise, the superannuation guarantee levy and others—seven taxes which a Hewson Liberal-National Party government will abolish to reduce our cost of doing things. We also urgently need a stronger commitment to the reform of industrial practices with a greater commitment to freeing up the labour market, to the introduction of enterprise bargaining, and to new union structures, including enterprise unions, which will ensure that industrial relations negotiations occur genuinely at the workplace level.

Again, that is something that only a Liberal-National Party government under John Hewson will do. All of these urgent reforms are integral parts of the Fightback package which that government will introduce. With the election of a Hewson Liberal-National Party government at the next election and the implementation of that Fightback package, Australia can be assured that it has new hope—hope of recovery and hope of a prosperous future. The continuation of this Government offers no such hope. It condemns us simply to a future of dismal economic performance and a dismal life for the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1992-93 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1992-93. In doing so, it is worth looking at why we are here. We on this side of the chamber have been saying almost since day one that One Nation was a flawed document that would fail. Now the Government, through an unprecedented move, is acknowledging that: it is reallocating money that was allotted through the One Nation statement.

PARA.TAB: Why is this document flawed? Let us look at the roots of One Nation. It was a direct result of the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) stabbing the previous Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in the back. Having succeeded in that, he suddenly thought that he had better make some sort of national statement. So Mr Keating wrapped it up in a cosy name without really thinking the whole matter through.

We see from yesterday's current account figures, which have already been mentioned in today's debate that, in adjusted terms, there is a $1.8 billion balance of payments deficit. We also note that, only three months after the Budget, the Federal Government seems unable to meet any of its Budget targets. In fact, as usual, as has been its form, it is off-target.

As Senator Chapman has just said, Labor governments cannot manage money, nor can they run a business. History shows this. The history of the States over the last 10 years shows this. Not only did the Prime Minister stab the previous Prime Minister in the back, but also he has stabbed one million unemployed people, in excess of another million people who are partly employed and, in addition, he has delivered a real fall in wages in the process.

The time has come for this nation to stop fiddling at the edges. One Nation is a nice, cosy name. It sounds good, but it fiddles at the edges. All the Government is doing now is fiddling at the edges; it is not addressing the fundamental problems in our economy. The Government is not addressing what every householder knows; that is, if we spend more money from our week's wages or our month's wages than we earn eventually somebody will come tapping on our shoulder saying, `Because you cannot meet your mortgage payments you will have to forgo your home or your television set or some of your assets'. That is the situation Australia now faces. We in this nation are on the edge of a total collapse. Government members in this chamber and in the other place do not have the courage to address that simple little fact.

Last week a number of us were addressed by Mr Terry Ward, the Managing Director of Heinz Ltd. He gave us a personal explanation as to why Heinz decided to invest in New Zealand and not in Australia. It was very simple. He told us that the reforms that have been introduced in New Zealand—reforms which are reported to have put New Zealand 10 years ahead of Australia in a competitive sense—have lowered that company's business costs by 30 per cent. He said that, at the same time, the farmers who produce the goods Heinz needs to process to sell to the Asian market have also enjoyed the benefits of the lowering of those costs.

New Zealand has bitten the bullet. It has been prepared to address its particular cost structures; it has been prepared to address the industrial relations problem and move to a much more productive, rewarding system, but Australia has not. One must ask this Government: why does it want to allow New Zealand to beat the pants off Australia? This is precisely what is happening. This was borne out by what Mr Terry Ward told us last week.

I say to the Australian people that Australia must bite the bullet; we have no option whatsoever. I also say that to the Government and the Democrats. I listened with interest to Senator Kernot's unbelievable contribution when she became the apologist for the Government. The Democrats cannot see that One Nation has failed and that this Government has failed. In every aspect of economic management, and in most areas of social management, its answer is to put together more schemes, and not even address the issue of creating real jobs. It continues to talk about mickey mouse jobs. Yesterday Senator Tierney outlined to us the results of one of these mickey mouse schemes that produced no jobs. I have seen it in front of my office. The street has been pulled up and rebuilt three times in less than two years. God only knows what for. We just get different coloured bricks each time.

The answer to Australia's problems is twofold. The first involves a major change to our taxation system and the second involves a major change to our industrial system. I believe that most Australians recognise this. It was borne out by yesterday's fizzer on our national day of sabotage, the national day of shame.

The Liberal and National parties in government will be making a number of fundamental changes to the taxation system and to the cost of doing business in Australia. This will mean the introduction of a goods and services tax. Also, a number of very important safety nets will be put in place to protect the living standards of Australians. First and foremost there will be a massive cut in income tax. I will quote a few figures to show the effect of this on the Australian population.

Somebody who currently has an income of $15,000 will have a tax saving of $624 per year; somebody with an income of $20,000 will have a tax saving of $814 per year; and somebody with an income of $25,000 will have a tax saving of $1,185 per year. That is one safety net that will be put in place to offset the change in the taxation system. It will cut down the cost of doing business in this country so that we are in a position to compete with countries such as New Zealand. I understand that as of yesterday the Polish Government is moving down the line that New Zealand has taken, yet Australia hangs back in terms of being prepared to face the real issues.

Additionally, other safety nets that we will put in place to protect ordinary Australians will include reducing the price of fuel for motor cars by approximately $11 every time people fill up their tank, and businesses will be even better off. We will double the family allowance, from $520 a year to $1,040 per year for a family earning $30,000 or less with one child. Those who require the family supplement because of this Government will have that family supplement increased by 6 per cent. The income tax threshold will be raised from $5,400 to $7,000. All pensions will be raised by 8 per cent, and other benefits will be increased by 6 per cent.

Tax credits will be introduced for private health cover for people earning less than $30,000 per year. We will address the problems in our current health system—the long waiting lists, the demoralised attitude of people who work in the health system, and the problems that doctors regularly identify. Pensioners and self-funded retirees earning less than $30,000 per year will be eligible to apply for a special cash cheque of up to $2,500 for single people and $5,000 for couples to compensate for the effect of the GST on savings. All people over 65 will be given a pharmaceutical benefit concession card. I could go through the list of all the safety nets that will be put in place. Unfortunately, as we each have only 10 minutes to speak on this matter, I cannot touch on any more of these points at this time. However, I will address them later.

I conclude by saying that this nation cannot and should not go on in the way it is. It cannot afford the excesses of the current Government and its lack of policy. It cannot afford or tolerate any longer the Government's inability to come up with policies which will fundamentally address what we have to face today—our burgeoning debt; our burgeoning unemployment; the inability of the vast majority, if not all, of our businesses to compete; and the continuing blow-out in the number of bankruptcies in this nation. The time for change is here. The time for the Government, in the little time it has remaining, to show a little bit of courage and to address some of the issues before us today has long gone.

Even yesterday, the Government could not come out and say to the ACTU and to the Victorian Trades Hall Council, `Now is not the time to hold this country to ransom. Now is not the time to rule this country by anarchy'. Instead, the Government sat back in silence. It lacked the courage of its convictions to tell its masters that the time to pull off and let Australia get on with doing business was right now. In other words, the Government has no guts.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleagues who have spoken before me in this debate have explained the nature of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and their rationale. I commend to the Senate the contributions made by my colleagues, starting with Senator Short. I hope that Senator Gareth Evans and his colleagues listened to those things because they would really have learned something about what should be done with our economy to try to get it out of the mess that nine years of Labor rule have put this nation in.

PARA.TAB: Quite simply put, that mess is a tangible example of Labor's mismanagement—its inability to even manage this year's Budget. No wonder Labor has not been able to manage the country in the last nine years. The money simply could not be used in time. All the plans and projections that Labor had just a few months ago have proved yet again to be wrong. We have these additional Appropriation Bills coming in to reallocate some money for pre-election, gimmicky job creation projects to get people off the statistics and out of the dole queues, so that when the election comes up in March-April Labor will be able to say, `Look, there has been a fall. Our policies are working'.

The only thing that is working is Labor's political cunning in getting the statistics altered to suit its own political purposes. It will last exactly one month after the election, in the unlikely event of Labor being re-elected, and then things will be back to normal.

I have been told in my area that people who are long term unemployed, almost unemployable, are being forced into training schemes for 26 weeks simply to get them off the dole queues and put them somewhere where they will not be counted in the statistics. As this Government runs into this election, it will try anything to alter that unemployment figure.

That is happening in my little area. I will guarantee that the same thing is happening everywhere else in Australia, in every small town, provincial city and large town. This Government is doing anything, spending any amount of our taxes, simply to get those people off the statistics in time for the election. It does not matter what it costs or what it does to the economy, to the ALP it only matters that they are off the statistics.

I am ashamed to hear that a fellow Queensland senator, Senator Kernot, simply as an apologist for the left wing of the Labor Party, has supported the sorts of things the Government is doing. The Labor Party understands this but does it deliberately for political purposes; I do not think the Democrats understand. I say to Senator Kernot, `We cannot go on with these sorts of unfunded projects'. The Government is borrowing more money on the international Bankcard and adding to our $150 billion debt simply for political purposes. Senator Kernot should know that we cannot keep doing that. What we have to do for this economy is to attack the root cause of the problem, and implement the major reform that is needed; not just splash about money that we do not have to get people off the dole queues for a short period.

These Bills again exemplify the shambles of management of this Government; the absolute failure of, and the death knell of the One Nation statement—that much lauded statement that was going to save Australia. Again, it proves that, where money and jobs are concerned, we simply cannot trust the Labor Party.

To put that statement in perspective, if the three eastern States were to devote all of their expenditure to the repayment of debt, the entirety of the debt owed by each State would be completely paid off in the following number of years: in Queensland, which had 26 years of sensible non-Labor rule, if all the expenditure of those three States were used, the Queensland debt would be paid off in 1.5 years; in New South Wales the total debt would be paid off in 8.5 years; in Victoria it would take 111 years to pay off the debt. That just shows that Labor's management of money is an absolute tragedy and disgrace.

In South Australia there has been the State Bank collapse. That is more evidence of the Labor Party's financial irresponsibility, proving again that we simply cannot trust Labor with either money or jobs. Then there is the scandal of Western Australian Inc. It proved only one thing for the Labor Party in Western Australia: the only way it can handle money is when it is sent around in brown leather satchels for Labor Party political purposes. When it comes to managing the economy of that State—as it is in this Parliament, Victoria and South Australia—the Labor Party is completely incapable and irresponsible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep your voice down. You are shattering the peace.

—We have one million unemployed. I have to shout because I want Senator Evans to take note of this. He should hang his head in shame that he has been part of a government that caused one million of our fellow Australians to be unemployed and another one million to be underemployed.

PARA.TAB: The Director of Access Economics says that 900,000 full time workers are presently working for a shorter time than they desire. There are 200,000 part time workers looking for full time work, 300,000 part time workers who want to work longer hours, and 250,000 people have simply given up looking for work, they have just dropped out.

The real figure of unemployment and underemployment is closer to two million. We are seeing the death knell of the One Nation statement, which was the sixteenth, seventeenth or eighteenth major economic statement since this Government has been in power. None of those statements has worked. Why would the Budget statement be any different from the others? None of them has worked because the Labor Party is simply incapable.

These Bills also involve bringing forward for this year $55m out of next year's allocation for the local capital works project. I have challenged Mr Simmons, and I challenge Senator Evans and anyone else in the Labor Party who might care to respond, on how many additional jobs will be created by that creative accounting—fiddling the funds by bringing them forward from next year's allocation to this year's allocation. Not one additional job will be created because the rules of that local capital works program were such that the projects had to be commenced by 1 December this year—today—and finished by December next year.

Bringing $55m forward from next year's Budget into this year's Budget will not create one additional job for Australia. The Government will fiddle the figures yet again before the election to try to pretend that more people are working so that it can manipulate a fall in the statistics before the election. The Government does not care what happens after that. That is what is wrong with the local capital works project—once the money stops, the jobs stop.

More than half the local authorities around Australia are very unhappy about this project because they all have pockets of unemployment in their shires. Yet more than half of them did not get one cent. This project was originally called an employment creation project. That is what the Government talked about initially. It then dropped that term and simply called it a capital infrastructure project.

I can understand why the Government dropped the term because I can quote from the Municipal Association of Victoria, which advised me that 48,900 jobless residents out of a total of 195,000 for Melbourne lived within 16 unfunded municipalities. This equates to something like 25 per cent or one in four jobless people in Melbourne who live in a municipality which did not get any funding for those supposed job creation projects.

I would like to cite some other statistics, kindly provided to me by the City of Moorabbin. In the City of Knox, which I was privileged to visit yesterday, some 5,375 people are out of work. What did that municipality receive as a local capital works project grant? Absolutely nothing—zero; zilch. And it has 5,375 people unemployed. In Altona, in the western suburbs—a good Labor heartland area—there are only 2,194 people unemployed, but it received a grant of $1.29m. In Port Melbourne, which I understand is a very marginal Melbourne seat—is that the one Senator Evans tried to get preselection for but missed out—

TALK.START.PARA: —Jagajaga.

—Jagajaga, was it? Port Melbourne has only 512 people out of work and it received $261,000. The City of Moorabbin, with 4,784 people out of work, received absolutely zilch—zero. The whole thing is a sham. The formula is all wrong. I am sure it was done for political purposes. Even then, some of these projects are not designed to create jobs. They are not even capital infrastructure investments, which they should have been. Most local authorities around Australia are responsible, and most of the projects I have seen from these local authorities are very worth while and are investments in the future. But a number of them are simply decorative; they are not creating jobs and are not investing in our future infrastructure. I challenge Senator Evans or anyone on the Government side to show me where this $55m being brought forward will create any more permanent jobs.

PARA.TAB: The only salvation for Australia is not these make-work projects or this practice of `borrow money you do not have and throw it around before an election'; what Australia needs is a new leader, a new direction and a set of new policies. The old ways of borrowing moneys and creating training schemes and putting people into them—what for, I do not know; there are no jobs for them when they come out of training; what are we training them for?—are finished. What Australians have to do is sell more of our goods overseas. We have to make ourselves more competitive. We do that by removing all of the taxes we put on our exports. When we remove those taxes, we will find that our goods are cheaper and that we will sell more, because we are selling more competitively. If we sell more, we have to create more and produce more. If we produce more, we need more people employed to produce the goods. That is what Australia needs. We need to get rid of those taxes that we currently put on our exports and to create more jobs in that way. Only the Liberal and National parties have the plan to do that.

If we abolish seven taxes that are currently imposts upon our exports and businesses—such as the wholesale sales tax, the fuel tax of 26c a litre, the training guarantee levy, payroll tax and the superannuation levy—we will make our goods more competitive overseas. In that way, and only in that way, we can create the jobs that Australia needs, get people back in real jobs that count and get rid of this mickey mouse socialist dogma that we have had from the Labor Party in the couple of months before the election.

While we will be dealing with these Bills in the way that my colleague Senator Short has mentioned, I urge the Democrats and the Australian Labor Party to think beyond the next election, not just to introduce programs that get people off the unemployment queues so that the statistics are right, but to do something for the good of the nation and implement a program such as Fightback which will create real jobs for Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) to express my disgust with the failed economic policies of this Government. These Bills are unprecedented in that they are additional Appropriation Bills, created even before the original Budget Bills had been passed by the Senate. It proves that this Government has lost control and has run out of ideas. The present Government has a long list of failed policies. There was the May 1991 economic statement, the 1991 Budget, the November 1991 jobs statement, the One Nation statement delivered last May and the 1992 Budget. All these policy announcements were a mere tinkering at the edges.
—There were another 12 before them.

—What Senator Macdonald says is true: there were another 12 before the ones I mentioned. We should look at the legacy 10 years of Labor Government has left this country. One Nation was supposed to be the showpiece to get us out of all this. It is the failed policies of One Nation that these Bills before the Senate today seek to correct. These Bills make it very clear that One Nation has failed the people of Australia. This Government's policies fail to address the problems that we face. The end result has been record unemployment and the shocking trade deficit released yesterday of $1.8 billion for one month.

PARA.TAB: Let us be very clear on who has been creating these problems. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), when Treasurer, originally led us into this recession. This is something we should not forget. For years we were forced to endure interest rates of around 20 per cent. When the inevitable recession came, the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, promised to engineer a soft landing for the previously overheated economy. Instead, with Mr Keating at the helm, Australia led the world into the worst recession in 60 years. I want to repeat that point to make it crystal clear. While two to three years ago the rest of the world was in the midst of a boom, Mr Keating, our former and failed Treasurer, deliberately led Australia into a recession. He even boasted about it when he said that it was the recession that we had to have.

Australia desperately needs a government that can recognise the problems facing this country. With almost one million people looking for work and an additional 1 1/2 million underemployed, one would have thought that this Government would recognise that serious policy changes are necessary. Instead, it keeps bumbling along, attempting to glaze over the structural problems that have led us into this economic mess, and producing patch-up jobs that do not work. One Nation was typical of the Government's poor attempts at reversing Australia's economic fortunes. One Nation was presented by Mr Keating as a visionary blueprint for strong economic growth that would get people back to work and bring the Budget back into surplus in four years. Sun-Herald columnist Bruce Jones said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . since then it has fallen in an ignominious heap: the growth and jobs forecasts proved wrong, the projected surplus is looking sick, infrastructure spending has been revised and promised tax cuts are hardly credible.

One Nation predicted economic growth of 4.75 per cent. At the time, Prime Minister Keating said he thought that was conservative. He said, `If we cannot make 4 per cent growth a year, we should give the game away'. Well, he should. That is exactly what he should do. He should have given it away before Christmas and given this nation the chance to elect a government which will do something about it. Only six months later, the Budget's economic forecast was a meagre figure—way under what he predicted. Mr Keating should give the game away.

PARA.TAB: The One Nation policy was meant to fix the problems facing this country. It has not done that. What we have experienced from this Government over the last 10 years is not the creation of one nation but the creation of two nations. The two-nation problem that has been created by this Government is shown up in a number of ways. One way we have two nations is that we have eight million people employed in this country and one million unemployed. Another way it has shown up is that we have three-quarters of a million small businesses in this country, but there is another group in which 43 businesses are going bankrupt each day. We have another two-nation measure in this country, and this is probably the most tragic measure of the lot. Three-quarters of the children of this nation go home to a family in which at least one person is working, but one-quarter of the children of this nation go home to a family in which no-one is working and which is welfare dependent.

We have another example of two nations in this country: the north of Australia and the south of Australia. The northern States—States such as Queensland and New South Wales which have been dominated by coalition governments over the best part of the last 10 years—are relatively prosperous compared with the poor southern States of Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia in particular which have had to face the legacy of appalling Labor mismanagement. This is evidenced by the banking and other financial scandals of those States. Again, this proves that we cannot trust Labor with money. The Labor Party has not created one nation; it has divided Australia into two nations in the ways I have indicated and has created the greatest economic disaster since the Great Depression.

In February, when One Nation was released, Australia's unemployment rate was 10 1/2 per cent. That meant that 908,000 Australians were looking for work. Today we have an unemployment rate of 11.3 per cent, which means that 979,000 Australians are unable to find work due to the policies of this Government. The increase of 72,000 Australians looking for work since the release of One Nation is the greatest condemnation possible of the failed policies of Mr Keating and this Government.

The failed policies of this Government, particularly One Nation, can be highlighted through the example of the local government capital works program. Senator Macdonald in his speech mentioned a number of examples of how this ludicrous program had gone off the rails. An amount of $345m was supposed to be used to create 13,000 jobs by providing `funds for projects which will directly create jobs and benefit the economy and the community'. But it is not happening. The Byron Bay Council typifies this appalling targeting of policies that the Government has implemented with One Nation. It shows that this Government has no idea of how the country operates, of how its policies are administered, or of how its policies impact on the community. It also shows that its policies simply are not working.

Under the local government capital works program, the Byron Bay Council was given $400,000. With this money it resurfaced the footpaths in the main street. It took out the footpath that originally existed—I believe it was quite a reasonable footpath—and has replaced it with bricks in a wave pattern. Senator Crane gave a similar example of work done in his own town, outside his office.

Byron Bay, the area in which this project I referred to was undertaken, has an unemployment rate of 21.8 per cent, yet the Government does not deem it serious enough to warrant ensuring that the money is spent under the program in a way that would ultimately create new jobs. This is typical of the operation of the program as a whole. Councils are using existing staff or contracting out and many of their projects have a restricted capacity to give work to anyone. The projects themselves are frequently one-off activities that will not boost productivity or employment in the years ahead.

Yesterday's editorial in the Telegraph Mirror came close to the mark when it said that it would have been preferable to fund projects which improve facilities and would make it easier for private industry to employ people, because it is private industry that creates real long term sustainable jobs. The attempts at policy by Mr Keating and the Labor Government neglected this very important point. The Government thinks that it can create jobs by throwing government funds into ad hoc programs, but the jobs that are created cease to exist when the money runs out.

The Government has not really addressed the structural problems facing the economy and so the unemployment problem remains. The coalition's Fightback package addresses the structural problems that are facing Australia, in stark contrast to the Government's failed policies. The fundamental objective of Fightback, and the one task which all our policy changes are ultimately directed towards, is the creation of more jobs. Expanding job opportunities and stable economic growth cannot be achieved without our economy becoming more internationally competitive, without higher rates of productivity, without a more dynamic and expanding private sector, without higher levels of skills and investments, and without higher levels of savings. The only way this Government can provide a framework in which these objectives can be achieved is to implement a wide ranging reform program focused on building more cooperative workplaces, more competitive businesses and lower and fairer taxes. The coalition's Fightback program is directed at removing the cost disadvantages that are impeding business investment and thus destroying job growth.

Our reforms are designed to create two million jobs over the remainder of the decade. Our industrial relations reforms will ensure that antiquated rules do not stand in the way of people obtaining work. Our tax changes will give people more incentive to find work themselves and more incentive to create work for others. Our sweeping micro-economic reforms will take the shackles off Australian business and give our managers and entrepreneurs the chance to take on the best and win. Our education and training policies will make sure that Australia has the knowledge and skills to take advantage of the opportunities that will open up as a result of the policies I have mentioned. Fightback stands in stark contrast to the Government's failed policies.

The Government and One Nation have failed Australia. Unemployment continues to rise and the economy has continued to nosedive. This was evidenced by the figures that were released yesterday. Further figures are coming out today which I believe will show in a devastating way how this Government's policies have failed. Fightback is what is needed. Fightback will create jobs and bring us back from the brink of disaster that Mr Keating and this Labor Government have led us to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating today Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4), which seek to transfer moneys that had been set aside under One Nation for capital expenditure or infrastructure to short term bandaid repair jobs, and which signal the collapse of the shallow One Nation statement.

PARA.TAB: Australia is in a crisis. It is on the brink of economic disaster. This was shown yesterday by the fact that we had a current account deficit—in other words, our imports exceeded our exports—for the month of October of some $2,000m, the highest figure for three years. This, in turn, adds to our foreign debt, which is now fast approaching $160,000m net. In this climate, massive bankruptcies occur. In the main, they occur not because of the fault of the businesses concerned, but because of external forces: high interest rates imposed by this Government to cut back on the level of imports, which it did, but it shot all the bystanders.

When the Government killed those businesses through bankruptcies, they took with them an awful lot of unemployed people. The sad thing about that is that, when these businesses go bankrupt, in the main they never emerge again and those jobs are lost forever. This was the situation that the Opposition saw coming two years ago, notwithstanding the comments made by the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and others that we were somehow enjoying this. It was perfectly obvious that Australia was going down what I think Senator Peter Walsh called `the road to Argentina'.

A number of options were open to the coalition. I suppose we could have done nothing, but we believed that would have been totally and utterly irresponsible, so we decided to bring out an exciting plan to rejuvenate the Australian economy. That is what is needed. It is no good going into bandaids, and short term political fixes are no good. Incidentally, most of them will expire some time in May because this Government is thinking only of the next election. It is not interested in the one million people out of work; it is interested in its own lousy jobs.

We decided to bring out the Fightback package, a most exciting package which offered something for the future. It offered hope to the unemployed and it offered hope to people who would like to invest in wealth creation but have been prevented from doing so because of the structural problems confronting this country.

The whole basis of Fightback is to recognise the fact that if a country does not have a viable and growing private sector—a wealth creating private sector—no revenue is generated to provide the essential community services that government wishes to provide. Without a healthy private sector, we cannot have a good education system, a good health system, good roads and so on. The whole aim of Fightback is to give a massive injection to this country's wealth creating private sector and give it an enormous boost.

This is to be handled by taking some $20,000m in taxes off the private sector. These are input taxes which currently are paid by the private sector and which, compared with overseas countries which do not have these sorts of taxes, put it at a disadvantage, not only in respect of exports but also in respect of making the goods in Australia that Australians want to buy.

The first tax that would come off under Fightback would be payroll tax. This is a tax that has been criticised for generations. It has been a State tax. The States have said, `Well, we would like to get rid of it, but we can't afford to'. We will give them that opportunity under Fightback. Those taxes will be removed and the States will be reimbursed for their loss of income. It is crazy, particularly in the current economic climate with unemployment the way it is, to still have a tax on employing people. It is one of the most ludicrous things that one could possibly imagine.

It was decided to get rid of the ramshackle, indirect sales tax—a sales tax that is imposed at the wholesale level and which affects the input costs of business and the final outcome as to the price. A major change we want to make, which I think was probably a surprise to most, involves the removal of the fuel excise levy. The Australian Democrats come in here and say that they want to increase the fuel excise levy by 16c a litre. They are not happy with 26c; they want to make it 42c a litre. That brings it up to the price of petrol today without the fuel excise levy.

The reason we want to remove the fuel excise levy is that Australia is a large country where goods are transported from one end of the country to the other.
