This levy impacts on almost every stage of production: for the farmer who brings in his fertiliser before he grows his wheat, in the transportation of the wheat to the mill, from the miller to the baker, and from the baker to the retail shops.

The cascading effect of getting rid of that fuel excise levy will be enormous. It will save every business 26c a litre in fuel costs. In addition, the ordinary household will, of course, pay 19c a litre less. That means people will pay $11 less every time they fill up their cars. It is all about giving this great adrenalin injection to the private sector so that people can confidently invest their money in wealth creating industries, whether that be in exports or import replacement.

The next matter which has to be addressed is one that we debated yesterday. This country cannot go along with the old-fashioned, centralised industrial relations system that we have had since 1901—for 90 years. There has to be a better way, and we propose a better way under the Jobsback package. I make it very clear that Jobsback is all to do with increasing productivity. I have said time and time again in this place that wage levels per se are not the problem in Australia. If we look at the actual wage levels paid in Australia compared with, say, Japan, we will see that the Japanese wages are double the Australian wages. The reason they are double is that the Japanese are more productive. Because they are more productive, they are able to be paid a higher real wage than we can pay in Australia.

That is the whole thrust of our package: to be able to give people the freedom to engage in enterprise based bargaining with their employers. We need an attitudinal change so that there is a recognition that upon the success of a company depends the success of its own employees. If the company succeeds, the employees succeed. They benefit: they get an increase in real wages because of an increase in productivity. Of course, if the company fails, they lose their jobs.

Another part of Fightback is most important. Under our income tax system at present, there is the most incredible disincentive for people to work a bit harder or even to invest. There is also a disincentive to save. For example, if anyone in Australia today earns more than $20,000, whether that additional income comes from work or whether it comes from some investment in a building society or a bank, that person pays 38c in the dollar in income tax. Once people make $35,000, which is just more than average weekly earnings, they pay 46c in the dollar. That is an intolerable situation, and it is one of the reasons why a lot of Australians decided it was better to spend money than to save it. For God's sake, where is the incentive to save or put money in investments when people pay either 38c or 46c in the dollar in tax? That is an incredible disincentive.

An effort had to be made to reduce that burden. The Fightback package promises that the threshold below which people will not pay tax will be increased from $5,200 to $7,000. This will mean that an awful lot of casual employees on incomes below $7,000 will not even have to put in a tax return. The tax rate on incomes between $7,000 and $20,000 will be reduced to 16.2 per cent. This means that someone earning $20,000 a year will pay a tax rate of about 11 per cent. That is below Hong Kong rates. There is an incentive for people to work and retain some of their hard-earned income. The tax scale will be reduced so that some 90 per cent of all Australians will pay a tax rate of 30c in the dollar or less under Fightback.

That is the sort of incentive we need. These are the sorts of structural problems that we must address. The bandaids being offered by the Government are exactly that—bandaids. It is quite apparent that this Government has absolutely no policies to address the disaster that I mentioned earlier—the economic crisis in which Australia finds itself.

Fightback offers that incentive. It offers the incentive to business to get up, to move, to export and to start making goods in Australia that people want to buy. It offers the incentive to people to work a bit harder and retain more of their incomes. The alternative of the Keating Labor Government is more of the same. Frankly, I do not think this country can afford any more of what we have experienced under this Labor Government in the past seven or eight years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4), Bills which I believe are a symbol of the failure of this Labor Government. Senator Ray may recall—certainly my colleagues on this side of the chamber do—that on 26 February a statement called One Nation was put down by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). These Bills which we are debating today emphasise the failure of this plan.

PARA.TAB: One Nation was brought down because the Prime Minister felt that he had to have a plan to counter the Fightback strategy launched by the Leader of the Opposition, John Hewson, and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Peter Reith. So we had the One Nation plan, whose forecasts have been shot to pieces and whose programs have had to be revised constantly as a result of the poor foundation on which One Nation was based.

This is an extraordinary Labor government by any standards. It is interesting that there has been an attempt to attack the Jobsback package of John Howard on the basis that it will lead to lower wages and salaries in the community. I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that we do not need to model the policies of this Government because all the figures show that as a result of nine years of the Keating-Hawke Government average earnings are now lower than they were when Mr Hawke and Mr Keating came to office.

For almost a decade we have had these constant promises by the Labor Party that it will look after the living standards and jobs of ordinary Australians. Well, the scores are now on the board. I say to Senator Robert Ray that average earnings have fallen under his Government—
Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, he is ashamed of it; so he should be. Average earnings have fallen under his Government and his policies. That only applies, of course, to the people who are lucky enough to have jobs during the recession which he and his colleagues created. There are one million unemployed and average earnings are falling. That is the record of the Hawke-Keating Labor governments. They are a disgrace by any standards and they are particularly a disgrace by the standards and values of the Labor Party. It is no wonder that this smokescreen has been thrown up.

PARA.TAB: How could the modern Labor Party have any connection with the Ben Chifleys and the John Curtins of old? We have a Prime Minister who is arguably the wealthiest Prime Minister in Australian history; a Prime Minister who, with an investment of $430,000, in just six weeks was able to show a return of $4.2m—and that is only the start of the story. So how could this man have any connection with the great traditions of the Labor Party? The John Curtins and the Ben Chifleys were not worried about making money outside of politics. They were principally concerned with running this country and trying to better achieve the values that they thought were important. That is not the role in which Mr Keating, this so-called Labor Prime Minister, sees himself.

I am not surprised that the record of this Labor Party is so appalling, because these modern Labor men have very little connection with the traditions of their own Party. They have shown that when the national interest and the interests of workers are at stake, they do not address those issues; they address the narrow political interests of the political elites who have captured the Labor Party. They are concerned about maintaining the power and the privileges of union bosses.

I believe that Australia is now in a very serious crisis, a crisis of a magnitude that we have not seen since the Great Depression. This country is crying out for leadership—not the political stunts, the deceit, the untruths that this Prime Minister channels out day after day. We are after real policies to address the real concerns of ordinary Australians, who are worried about their falling living standards and their jobs and are horrified at the fact that a Labor government has allowed employment to reach a record 11.3 per cent, without any action or concern being expressed by the senior Ministers of that Party. Senator Ray tries to portray himself as some sort of moderate in his Party. Senator Ray supported this disgraceful strike we saw on Monday. He did not have the guts of Bob Carr to come out and say that with the crisis Australia is facing this strike was utterly intolerable. That is what the Labor Leader in New South Wales said. The Labor Leader in Canberra, Mr Keating, was behind the scenes promoting this strike for his own narrow political interests. As a result, there will be more losses to the Australian economy, more damage to the balance of payments, more people in business going broke and more jobs lost.

These are the standards of the wealthiest Prime Minister in Australian history. He does not have to worry about what happens when he loses his job. Boy, has he got a cushion to fall back on, a $4.2m cushion. Regardless of what happens at the next election, Mr Keating is going to be perfectly all right. It is about time this so-called Labor Party Prime Minister started to worry about the interests of the nation and the interests of those people who used to be part of the Labor Party constituency.

I now refer to a number of quotations from this morning's newspapers which I believe demonstrate very effectively the sort of issue this nation is facing. I suspect that Senator Ray will be interested in this comment from Terry McCrann in the Herald-Sun:
Now we have a government ruthlessly feeding on our fears and uncertainties about the reforms we desperately need.

Let this be crystal clear. We either embrace the reforms proposed at the state level by the Kennett Government and federally in John Hewson's Fightback to change Australia quickly and fundamentally to all our benefit or we slide from one pointless and destructive Keating recession to the next.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the view that was put by Terry McCrann, the leading commentator in the Herald-Sun, this morning. I do not know whether those on the Government side have seen the headline on the front page of the Australian—I suspect Senator Robert Ray closed his eyes when he saw it—which says, `Economy sinks, protest fizzes'.

PARA.TAB: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know the honourable senator is sensitive. He is on record as calling the Prime Minister a clown. I think Senator Ray is being soft on the Prime Minister; he is the wealthiest clown in Australia's history. We know that the Prime Minister calls him names. I put it to the Senate that there are fundamental issues now facing this nation. I turn to the comments made by Mr Alan Wood on the front page of the Australian. This is what he had to say about the Keating-Halfpenny strikes which occurred in Australia yesterday:

PARA.TAB: The industrial action tells us that the unions' national leadership remains emotionally tied to an outmoded and destructive turn-of-the-century model of industrial relations based on class warfare.

SPEECH.PARA: The article goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: But while the Labor leadership in Canberra understands the need for urgent change, election-year politics see it playing a shabby game that will culminate early next year in the sham of another Accord with the ACTU.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the view that is spreading around Australia. We have seen these political stunts by the Prime Minister. We have a series of senior Ministers who seem to have no principles other than, `For heaven's sake, get us back into office'. That is not good enough for Australia; it is not good for the workers of Australia. It is bad for politics in this country because it means that short term considerations are constantly being elevated above the national interest.

PARA.TAB: We in the coalition parties have a plan to turn this economy around. We had the honesty to come out and put that plan before the public over 12 months ago. This is the only plan which is now on the table which offers any hope to Australians; it is the only plan which offers the prospect of rising living standards and more jobs for Australians. The Labor Party has failed, and failed disastrously, and the sooner this crowd of rich spivs are thrown out of office the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —These additional Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4 that we are debating today are unprecedented, as all my colleagues have pointed out. They represent, more than anything else, that Labor is a failure, that it cannot handle the economy and, as John Hewson said so eloquently, `No Labor government seems to be able to handle money'. We have only to look at WA Inc, South Australian banking and the dreadful mess that the Labor Government got Victoria into, to understand fully that Labor cannot handle money responsibly.

PARA.TAB: Many people have asked why we have put forward a policy whilst in opposition called Fightback and why we have this particular plan. All we had to do, they tell me, was to sit back and let government fall into our lap because this Labor Government has created the most unimaginable mess in Australia's history. We have an unprecedented one million unemployed and another million underemployed. Let us make sure that we get the detail right. If people work one day in the week they are not classed as unemployed. So we have one million totally unemployed and one million underemployed. We have the greatest number of bankruptcies on record. Bankruptcies went up 28 per cent last year—another 17,000—and this year we have a foreign debt running at $187 billion.

The current account deficit is increasing at the rate of $1 billion a month. The current account deficit figure released yesterday was $1.8 billion. Something has to be done. Honourable senators should think about the debt we are leaving our children, and I would like to go into that a bit. If one thinks about it, the mind boggles. We are not even paying the interest. When the coalition parties left government 10 years ago, Australia's foreign debt was $740m. Now it is $187 billion. That is the magnitude of the problem. Yet, we seem to be accepting it. When bankruptcies go up, when unemployment goes up, when our foreign debt goes up, if it is just under business expectation, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) says that they are `beautiful figures'.

What are we waiting for? Are we waiting for Moody's Investor Services to downgrade us again? Moody's have done so three times already. In 1983, when we left government, Australia had the highest credit rating available. Two years later, under a Labor government, it went from AAA plus to AAA. A year later, it went from AAA to AA1. In 1989, it went from AA1 to AA2. Most people do not understand what that means to them personally, but every time business, governments, farmers or private individuals borrow, we all pay an additional risk premium of between 1 per cent and 2 per cent. Australia is just not considered to be a good risk. That 1 per cent to 2 per cent additional interest that we pay flows on to the domestic economy.

So, how are our children going to pay back the deficit? If they could pay it back at, say, $1 billion a month—and that is not even in the realms of possibility in the next couple of decades—it would take them 15 years to do so. If we all think of the age of our children now—it depends how old your children are—if they are 15 years of age, in 15 years, they will be 30 before they pay it back. But if we are a little more realistic and say that we could pay it back at $500m a month, it would add another 30 years. The 15-year olds would be 45 before it was paid back. So they would be well into their middle age and getting a bit past it before they could repay the debt that this Government is leaving them.

We have alarming information about how tough it is to get an education. There are 50,000 to 60,000 qualified students unable to get into universities. Nearly 100,000 students did not get into TAFE or other technical or further education institutions. Yes, Labor keeps telling us how wonderful it is; the kids stay on longer in school. They have no alternative. If they did not stay at school, they would be in the dole queues. So they stay on longer at school, and those who cannot get into TAFE or other further education institutions or universities go on to the dole queues.

We know the pressure that our children experience at exam time. I think that many parents in this place would have just experienced some of those pressures that their children have been going through. It is just not fair. These days the children have to get such a wonderful pass to get anywhere. The pressures on them are just not fair.

Unemployment tears families apart. It is the greatest socially disruptive thing that is possible. One in three of our children are unemployed. One in three children in my State, Tasmania, are unemployed. There is no indication at all that the situation is improving. It is of no use Government members saying, as did the honourable member for Denison, Duncan Kerr, last weekend that `it is a world recession; there is nothing we can do about it'. Well before the world went into recession, Mr Keating said that we were having the recession we had to have. Honourable senators will remember that he personally took responsibility. He said, `It is my fault'. He apologised and gave every family an additional $10 in family allowance. That was his apology for the recession that we had to have—well ahead of the world recession—so it is of no use Labor saying that it is a world recession. Mr Keating deliberately held interest rates so high that bankruptcies had to happen. No business which had borrowed money and no farmer who had borrowed money could cope with 25 per cent interest rates.

As I said, something had to be done. So John Hewson announced the Fightback package. A tremendous amount of work went into Fightback. It is the Opposition's plan to get Australia out of this mess and turn it back into the competitive nation that it used to be. The Opposition has made its plan very clear. It will abolish $20 billion worth of taxes on business. Why will it do that? It is so that business can expand and so that our exports will be competitive overseas. At the moment, we cannot send any of our exports overseas without taxes being levied on them. We cannot be competitive while those taxes remain on our exports. Other countries do not have those taxes on their businesses. We, in Australia, do.

The Opposition will abolish wholesale sales tax, payroll tax, the petrol excise, customs duty, the training guarantee levy and the lump sum on superannuation and will freeze the superannuation levy. Since those opposite have been in government, wholesale sales tax has increased by 60 per cent. Not 1c of compensation has been given. How many people realise that at the moment 20 per cent wholesale sales tax is paid on washing powder? That is just one example. Have honourable senators ever wondered why washing powder is so expensive? I certainly know. Twenty per cent of the price goes to the Government. What compensation does anyone receive for that—not 1c.

Wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and petrol excise are levied on everything. The Government tells us that the tax is not applicable to butter and bread. Of course it is. Wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and the petrol excise is paid on bread and butter from the farm gate right through to the manufacturer. All the manufacturers in Tasmania, my State, pay payroll tax, wholesale sales tax and the petrol excise, which adds to the cost of transport. All the farmers pay those taxes on the goods that they buy. It comes through the whole way to the price of butter in the supermarket.

The GST that the Opposition will be putting on butter will not be on the present price of butter; it will be on a much cheaper commodity. The Government is not telling the truth when it says, `All those things will go up by 15 per cent'. It is not a fact; it is untrue. The Opposition has been trying to get across the point that, if we abolish all these taxes on business, the things that we buy will be much cheaper. Then the goods and services tax applies.

At the moment business pays to the Government 26c a litre in fuel excise. That will come off under Fightback. There will be no capital gains tax on businesses sold for retirement purposes, so a businessman can sell his business for retirement and he will not pay capital gains tax. We will introduce compensations for the introduction of a 15 per cent GST. I underline that the GST is not a tax on business; every single business input is rebatable. There will be no tax on business, so businesses can expand.

I will go through the benefits that we will give to compensate for that 4.4 per cent—not 15 per cent but 4.4 per cent—increase in the cost of living. There will be substantial reductions in income tax. For instance, those earning $25,000 a year will have their income tax reduced by $1,185. The tax free threshold will be increased from $5,400 to $7,000. The family allowance will be doubled for those on incomes under $30,000 and will go up by 50 per cent up to $40,000. The dependent spouse rebate will increase by $300 a year for spouses with children. All pensions will go up by 8 per cent even though, according to the Treasury, the CPI goes up by 3.6 per cent; we say 4 per cent. All benefits—sole parent benefit, unemployment benefit, Austudy et cetera—will increase by 6 per cent. Health is zero rated; so there will be no GST on health, or on education. Everyone over the age of 65 will have a pharmaceutical benefits card and thus will not pay for drugs; this also applies to self-funded retirees.

There will be no tax on up to $2,000 in interest on new savings, so people can save interest of $2,000 a year without paying tax on it. The price of petrol will be reduced by 19c a litre, which will be of great benefit when I go round doing my shopping. For first home buyers where the family income is under $40,000 and the applicants are under 35 years of age, there will be an allowance of $2,000.

The Fightback package will pick up the black economy so that all those people who are presently avoiding tax will have to pay it. Mr Kerr has said in Tasmania that the Fightback package is so good that Dr Hewson will not be able to keep his promise. This is the first time that an opposition in any country—and in particular in Australia—has had a plan for Australia that is fully funded. It is because it is fully funded, and because the Government cannot find any problems with it or any holes in it, that it tries to get away with besmirching the Leader of the Opposition by saying, `Oh, he is a cold-blooded economist'. The reason those opposite say that he is a cold-blooded economist is that he has financed and funded this package completely—right down to the last dollar. Because they cannot find any holes in the package, those opposite just have to denigrate him with those sorts of expressions.

Every single one of our promises in Fightback will be carried out because they are fully funded, unlike what has happened with the Government. Where did the One Nation policy go? It was not fully funded; there was no attempt to have it funded, so it has completely disappeared—out of existence.

I am being looked at by Senator Short, so I will have to wind up. I will finish my contribution to this debate by saying once again that these additional Appropriation Bills before us today are here because our economy is out of control and the Government has had to do an unprecedented thing by bringing in additional Appropriations at this stage, after Appropriation Bills Nos 1 and 2 had already passed, because it has run out of money and because, frankly, Australia is going bankrupt.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was my great fortune this morning to be involved in a series of meetings; hence I was not able to listen to any of the speeches from those opposite until I came into the chamber. Having listened to those since, there is nothing worth while to respond to, so I wish the Bills a speedy passage.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)That these Bills be referred to the Estimates committees for consideration and report by 8 December 1992.

(2)That the Estimates committees consider the proposed expenditure contained in the Bills in the same manner and in the same groups as the committees considered the particulars of proposed expenditure for 1992-93 referred to the committees on 20 August 1992.
(3)That, subject to a subsequent resolution, the Senate adjourn after question time on Thursday, 3 December 1992, to allow the Estimates committees to meet.

The matters that are the subject of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) are very important matters. Despite Senator Ray's somewhat gratuitous remarks at the end of the second reading debate, this has been a very important and constructive debate and it has been so because the contents of the Bills are very important. What we have in these Bills is a reallocation of considerable amounts of money that had earlier been appropriated in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2). Indeed, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) made the announcements that formed the basis for Appropriation Bills Nos 3 and 4 before the Senate had even passed Appropriation Bills Nos 1 and 2. So we have in these Bills changes in some important aspects of the Budget. Those matters had been considered by the Estimates committees in the normal process following the introduction of Appropriation Bills Nos 1 and 2. The Estimates committees concluded their deliberations and thought that was the end of it. We passed the Appropriation Bills and then found in here Bills that, in effect, amend the Bills that we had considered in great detail in the Estimates committee process.

PARA.TAB: As there have been some important changes, we believe it is very important for the Senate to have the opportunity, through the normal Estimates process, to consider these appropriations. Some people may be concerned—I guess I direct my comments essentially to the Australian Democrats on this—that there will be a time loss involved in the course of action that we are proposing. I believe that the contrary will be the case because, if these matters are not referred to Estimates committees, which would meet concurrently and therefore save time in that sense, we will have a lengthy debate in the Committee of the Whole, and that is a much more time consuming exercise than having the debate conducted essentially through the Estimates committees, with the debate in the Committee of the Whole being concentrated just on the key issues that might have emerged from the Estimates committee hearings and consideration.

So I believe that it is not just proper and due process; it will also save the time of the Senate. Certainly, we have no intention to be here longer than necessary. There is also a recent precedent to some extent for this in the sense that the Senate last week agreed to refer back to Senate Estimates Committee F various matters dealing with Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) which had not been able to have due consideration in the Senate because of the application of the guillotine.

So for all of those reasons I have moved this motion on behalf of the Opposition. I hope that it will have support because it will accord with the normal, proper processes of the Senate that we have been rightly jealous of ensuring that we do follow so that legislation can be properly considered. This is very important legislation. I hope that the Senate will, therefore, support my motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with care to what Senator Short has just said. We recognise, as he does, that these Bills do not alter the global limits within which expenditure is to be made but they do alter the way in which that money is to be expended. We would certainly not stand in the way of the proper scrutiny of that process through the Estimates committees. However, we do feel that it is inappropriate to adjourn the Senate after Question Time on Thursday and essentially to dispense with consideration of all further legislation on Thursday afternoon. Therefore, appropriately, we would move an amendment to paragraph (3) of the motion. We move:

PARA.TAB: Paragraph (3), omit the paragraph, substitute:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) That the committees meet on Friday, 4 December 1992.

That would allow the Senate to continue with its business on Thursday, as has been laid down—and we all know the amount of legislation which we have before us—and would allow the whole of Friday for the Estimates committees to meet. So it would satisfy the criterion which Senator Short has outlined, namely, that the committees be given an opportunity to look at this change in the way these amounts are to be spent.

PARA.TAB: We also recognise, as Senator Short has done, that in many respects sending these matters off to the Estimates committees could potentially reduce the total amount of time spent in their consideration in the chamber. We would, therefore, have liked to have added a fourth part to this motion which would have read, `That consideration of these Bills for the remaining stages be limited to two hours'. So there would be a full consideration in the Estimates committees but those matters which were of some substance would be limited in the debate when they came back to the Senate to be considered in the Committee of the Whole.

However, I am informed that to attempt to place a limitation on consideration of legislation through this process is not an appropriate way to proceed. So, correspondingly, I would like to indicate that, if the Government chooses to introduce a motion to limit the consideration of the remaining stages of these Bills to two hours, it would be supported by the Democrats.

It seems that that would satisfy both considerations, namely, the Opposition's concern that these changes be considered in the Estimates committees, that the consideration of legislation not be impeded by moving the consideration of the Estimates committees to Friday, 4 December and also that there be a firm undertaking that the consideration of the remaining stages be limited to two hours. I think that should satisfy all the requirements in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not too sure whether Senator Coulter moved an amendment or indicated an attitude. I think he indicated an attitude.
—I moved an amendment to paragraph (3).
—That was that the Committee meet on Friday, 4 December. That Committee or the committees?
—The committees.

—I have a further amendment which would amend paragraph (1) and paragraph (2) of Senator Short's motion and add a fourth paragraph, and which I foreshadow now. The amendment to paragraph (1) is that it read, `That these Bills be referred to Estimates Committee B for consideration and report by 8 December 1992'. The amendment to the second paragraph of Senator Short's motion is that it read as follows, `That Estimates Committee B only consider proposed expenditure contained in the Bills in the same manner' and then it flows on into Senator Short's motion. The amendment adds a fourth paragraph to the motion in the following terms, `That the remaining stages of the Bills be limited to two hours'. The reason for the amendment to Senator Coulter's amendment is one of practicality.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Minister, I am advised that you might like to seek some advice on this. I understand that you need to do that limitation by way of some sort of guillotine.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had a feeling that might be the case. The amendment was drafted in response to Senator Short's motion. Madam Acting Deputy President, I suggest you take my amendment as foreshadowed, less part (4). In effect, the only change I am suggesting is that one Estimates committee do this rather than a series of them because I think it is going to be difficult to get them all together in one spot. I think what I have suggested is a much more practical way of doing it. Therefore, the Government will be accepting Senator Coulter's amendment to paragraph (3) and will seek to amend paragraph (1) and part of paragraph (2) to insert `Estimates Committee B'.

—We would have had a strong preference to have met in Estimates committee on the Thursday because there are a large number of commitments that many senators have on the Friday and it will involve, at short notice, changes to their programs. We are sitting six weeks out of seven. To be locked into Canberra for another day is not advantageous and I doubt whether it will speed the overall process. But if that is the only way we are going to get the Estimates committees to meet, then we would reluctantly accept that change to Friday.

PARA.TAB: So far as Senator Ray's foreshadowed amendment to paragraph (1) and paragraph (2) is concerned, namely, that the Bills be referred to Estimates Committee B, we would not agree to that proposal because the matters that are dealt with in the Bills are the subject matter of issues that are dealt with by other committees in addition to Estimates Committee B. Estimates Committee C, for example, in particular deals with transport and communications. The essence of the Bills in terms of the money actually lies in the area of transport. TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

—by leave—As I understand it, the Government is now saying that we will be able to consider these Bills in one Estimates Committee, namely, Estimates Committee B, but that at the appropriate times the composition of the membership of Estimates Committee B could change to take account of the different facets of the Bill being considered—

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL TRAINING AUTHORITY BILL 1992VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the Australian National Training Authority Bill 1992 and the Vocational Education and Training Funding Bill 1992. Both of these Bills concern TAFE. The first seeks to establish the Australian National Training Authority and the other is in the usual annual form to provide moneys for technical and further education throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: I speak on behalf of the Opposition in noting that we will not be opposing the second reading of either of these two Bills. However, I make it clear that, in the Opposition's view, there are some significant questions to be asked about these measures—particularly whether the policies they embody for training are the best ones for Australians and for the economy into the future.

I am glad to see that the Selection of Bills Committee has already had its report adopted, which will see the Australian National Training Authority Bill 1992 referred to a sitting of the Senate Standing Committee on Education, Employment and Training in the coming weeks. On behalf of the Opposition, I requested the Selection of Bills Committee to make that reference. We will certainly be looking forward to the most careful examination of the Bill by the Senate Committee. I am confident that all of the members of that Committee will be able to hear witnesses from the States, the States being the principal area of government that is currently responsible for technical and further education, and to hear witnesses from the TAFE systems themselves. We do not want to see any lack of clarity in the Senate dealing with the proposal to establish the Australian National Training Authority. In my speech, I will be referring to a number of the questions that I believe ought to be examined by the Senate Committee to which this Bill will be referred at the end of this second reading debate.

The Australian National Training Authority Bill implements the compromise agreement reached earlier this year between the Commonwealth and the States for a national framework for technical and further education in training. The authority to be set up by the Bill will be the channel through which both Commonwealth and State funding in this area will be provided and will answer to a council of the relevant Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers where, I observe, the Commonwealth seeks to maximise its influence by claiming two votes and a casting vote.

In the Senate we need to ask: what are the short and long term training needs of our economy—the needs over the next few years and over the coming decade or two? Will the legislation for this proposed ANTA structure really be the best way of meeting those needs? There has already been a lot of debate about this by State Ministers, not least by the Labor governments in South Australia and Western Australia, because, as the Senate will recall, it was the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, who, in a quite unrepresentative and provocative way, announced a national, central, unified training authority through which decisions about technical and further education would be made and that the States would just have to accept that.

Yet the Constitution outlines the rights of the States of Australia to determine technical and further education. Those rights would be grabbed by the Commonwealth and the bait, or the reason for the States succumbing to the Prime Minister's rather provocative statement, was that all Commonwealth money for TAFE was contingent upon the States accepting this new centralised, national authority.

The outcome of the debate that ensued after the Prime Minister's statement has led to a much more diluted compromise outcome. It is an outcome which it appears the State governments have accepted, but with some genuine reluctance. A number of details involved with this authority concerning staffing, funding and the actual mechanism of how money flows from the States to this authority and then back to the TAFE system in the States is the thin edge of the wedge to subvert TAFE from the States. In the same way it could be argued that 20 years ago universities and their governance were subverted from the States by the Whitlam Government. Again, it was on the basis of moneys from the Commonwealth being available to the States for their universities only if the States agreed to the conditions that were being laid down by the Commonwealth.

I believe that the argument for a national framework for higher education is compelling and convincing. The Liberal and National parties seek the return of autonomy to individual universities now that that 20 years of national framework has been achieved. We want to see an end to centralism in higher education. These are early days with regard to TAFE. This legislation takes tentative steps.

There is much less of an argument for taking the initiative away from the States in an area in which training needs can be defined by the States, with national input; in which those who do receive training will be employed locally; and in which the employers and employee organisations can have a large say in how that training is defined and provided. For those reasons there needs to be a careful examination of these issues by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. There are grounds for real doubts about the effectiveness of the Government's approach, and the Senate is entitled to inquire further into what is being proposed. I ask that the Committee, in considering its evidence, not shorten its examination. I contemplate that it will be in the New Year that we will receive the report of that Committee.

The Vocational Education and Training Funding Bill provides funding for TAFE in the usual manner for education funding purposes, with supplementation for 1992 and then funding for each of the years of the coming triennium—that is, 1993, 1994 and 1995. The Opposition accepts the need for increased levels of funding in this area. We accept the advantages of triennial provision. The Liberal and National parties' commitment is to an even higher level of resources and an even higher level of Commonwealth assistance for technical and further education in the coming triennium.

The Government has promised an increase for technical and further education of $720m over the coming triennium; the Liberal and National parties promise an increase of $945m. On the election of a Hewson government early in the New Year, we will see that promise brought into effect, to the enhancement of technical and further education throughout Australia. For the time being, we do not oppose the funding provided in the normal way in this Bill.

I want to elaborate on my concerns about technical and further education. I remind the Senate that the coalition when in government had a very good record on vocational education funding. A former colleague, Senator Sir John Carrick, when Minister for Education in the Fraser Government, did an enormous amount to uplift the status of the TAFE sector. It received substantial boosts in funding at a time when other sectors of education were not so favoured. Important foundations were laid in those years. The history of TAFE over the last decade under Labor rule is, in contrast, by no means satisfactory.

When the Prime Minister described the present situation in Australia for TAFE he said that we were in a training emergency. That is after 10 years of Labor. These are the Prime Minister's own words. That was how he described our plight when he announced the formation of this training authority. This reflects very badly on Labor's policies over the last 10 years. This is an abysmal achievement by the Labor Party.

We see in this Bill Labor's approach of seeking to have Canberra dominate decision making and intrude on the decision making that occurs at State and local levels. There are requirements for the States and the authority to develop training profiles for the training agencies of the States. I am reminded of the massive changes and disruption this Government has caused in the field of higher education with centralised intrusion, including compulsory profiles to be submitted to the bureaucracy.

I have no wish to see that type of failed approach being inflicted on TAFE. The provision of growth moneys over and above present funding levels is to be conditional on satisfactory profiles being developed. Again, that is central intrusion. This is not an approach that gives me any confidence. We know that the Prime Minister wanted a much greater level of Commonwealth takeover of TAFE than is in this Bill, but his first moves were thankfully resisted right around the country and we have this compromise that I have described.

Labor's whole approach to training is, of course, part of its wider agenda for industrial relations in this country. We see Labor clinging to its centralised system, not seriously moving away from it, as the Opposition urges. Many of the proposals coming out of Labor's present system tie training to nationally imposed standards and criteria and link training with national awards. There is no recognition that our focus must primarily be on the enterprise, not the industry, if we are to make the progress and productivity that Australia needs. Training must relate to the needs of enterprises if it is to serve a useful purpose. That is why the Opposition's plans for decentralising decision making and maximising the autonomy of TAFE colleges are the right way to go, so that colleges are responsive to the requirements of the firms in the areas they serve.

The Government is clearly locked into the highly interventionist pattern of the ACTU document Australia reconstructed and the Carmichael report. We have seen the failure of the Government's Australian traineeship scheme, based on employer subsidies. The Government had set this up with a target of 75,000 each year. But the numbers being trained in this way have never reached such a target. In the last two years, I understand the numbers involved have been only 9,000. That is a long way short of the Government's aspiration. So the history of this Government's efforts help us to understand why the nation is now facing, in the Prime Minister's own words, a `training emergency'.

The Bill as it stands has some odd features, which deserve careful inquiry by the Senate Committee. For example, the States are to pay their own funding for TAFE to the Authority and are guaranteed by the Bill that they will then get that amount back. This seems to me to be rather pointless. The aim of the Government is, I suspect, that this process is part of building up the involvement of a national level authority in the funding process, so that it becomes a lot easier for nationally determined priorities to be imposed upon the States and colleges, regardless of their own wishes. I oppose centralism. The Liberal and National parties oppose centralism. We welcome national inputs to form goals and objectives, but we do not wish to undermine the autonomy of the States or colleges in the important area of education.

There is also curiosity about the staffing arrangements. The Bill allows the Authority to hire staff, either under the Public Service Act or independently under agreements. This may partly be to cover the transfer of some staff from the Department of Employment, Education and Training, but the Bill seems to go much wider than is necessary to provide for that.

The challenge for this authority will be whether it can be an effective means for the development of a national training market that is diverse and responsive to the needs of industry or whether it will become just another source of bureaucratic rigidity in the system. I remind the Senate that the Opposition has declared its own policies in this area. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard my eight points of summary of the Liberal and National parties' approach to technical and further education.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: KEY POINTS ON TRAINING IN LIBERAL-NATIONAL POLICY
1.Increased funding for vocational education and training of $945m for 1993-96 triennium ($225m above Government's proposals) with 220,000 new training places.
2.Increased funding of at least $75m per year in 1997-2000.
3.Youth Pledge—all young Australians to have access to post-compulsory schooling or technical and further education or opportunity for fulltime employment involving on-the-job training.
4.Minimum Youth Training Wage to greatly enhance opportunities for jobs and training for unemployed youth people.
5.Youth Training Voucher providing two days per week off-the-job training to all on Youth Training Wage.
6.Training vouchers for long-term unemployed aged over 45.
7.Need for national goals for levels of attainment of essential knowledge and skills, and targets for lifting levels of qualifications.
8.Thorough review of TAFE arrangements to increase autonomy and flexibility of TAFE colleges.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I have referred in the first point to the $225m that the Opposition will make available to TAFE over the coming triennium, in addition to the $720m that the Government is providing. This is consistent with our Fightback declaration that we would make available $75m a year for the seven years remaining in this decade. It happens that that $75m, in the three years involved, is the $225m in addition to that which is already being provided by this Government. The Opposition's commitments and approach stand out clearly from those of the Government. To underline this point, I move:

PARA.TAB: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate condemns the Government for:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)its failure over nine years to ensure the satisfactory development of vocational education and training in Australia and for creating a training emergency; and

(b)the excessively bureaucratic and centralist character of many aspects of the Government's national training agenda and for the confusion, complexity and uncertainty created by its current proposals".

It will be clear to all senators, and indeed the Australian public, that whilst the Opposition does not stand in the way of the additional moneys provided by the funding Bill that is now before us—we do not oppose it at all—we will do more. With the election of a Liberal-National Party government, technical and further education will have a further boost in what is, I believe, the critical area of need in education across Australia.

PARA.TAB: TAFE has been the Cinderella for too long in Australia. We have rightly given more resources to our schools and universities, but the resources allocated to TAFE have not kept pace with the needs of that sector and the training requirements of a wide range of professions within Australia. Whilst the Liberal and National parties will give additional resources to schools and higher education, we will give double additional resources to technical and further education.

In speaking on behalf of the Opposition in regard to these Bills, I am all the more confident of seeing improvements in at least the level of resources made available by these measures. There would be even further improvements, the kinds of improvements that technical and further education has been calling for, if a Liberal-National Party government were elected.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to the release today of Australia's foreign debt figures, which show another record level of net external debt of $163 billion, with gross debt exceeding $200 billion for the first time, or more than $11,000 for every man, woman and child in this country. I note that these debt levels are almost 10 times greater than when Labor came to office in 1983, and that, in every year Labor has been in office, Australia has had to borrow $14.5 billion from the rest of the world to pay for our declining living standards. I ask: in the light of this staggering increase in debt, which is continuing to increase at the rate of $1.5 billion each month, when, under this Government's policies, will this mountain of foreign debt start to be wound back?

—That question is charged with economic illiteracy and a lot of rhetoric. When we come to address some of the fundamental issues of this country and look at what the Opposition says about these issues, we get some clue as to what this is all about. His Deputy Leader and colleague, Senator Short, who has been on the attack about some of these issues, was saying 18 months ago that the current account deficit, which is one of the main problems with the level of debt, was a symptom of the real cause of the problem which he said was inflation. We have about the lowest level of inflation in the OECD. Senator Short's prognosis of that period shows just how ridiculous the Opposition is on these issues.

PARA.TAB: What matters most about foreign debt is the ability to service that debt. It is all very well to give these dramatic sorts of figures—$11,000 per household and all that sort of stuff—but the debt servicing ratio has fallen as interest rates have fallen and exports of goods and services have risen. The ABS figures show that the economy is better able to service foreign debt than it was a year ago, with the debt service ratio being 15.4 per cent, coming down from 19.1 per cent a year ago. Rather than 19 per cent of exports of goods and services being required to pay the interest on the net foreign debt, now a lesser figure of 15.4 per cent is required.

I make the point again—I think it is an important one in view of some of the economic illiteracy on the other side—that the private sector continues to be responsible for the bulk of Australia's external debt. Private debts account for 61 per cent of the net foreign debt, State governments owe 21 per cent and public enterprises owe 21 per cent. This Government was a net foreign lender to the tune of $4.7 billion. The Commonwealth Government contribution reduces the foreign debt—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is irrelevant.

—It is not irrelevant because members of the Opposition come in here trying to compare us with Mexico and the South American countries when it happens to suit them. It is not irrelevant because in those countries it is sovereign debt they are talking about.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—I understand that, as always, nothing is more uncomfortable for Opposition senators than to hear a few facts. That is why there is continued uproar and interjection when I start to give them a few facts. It is nonsense to equate this country's debt situation with overseas governments which have huge public sector foreign debts.

PARA.TAB: The $13.9 billion increase in the gross foreign debt in the September quarter was also artificially inflated by revision of borrowings since 1987. That is a statistical method. It is not important to the argument, but I simply make the point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has done his best to talk down what he should regard as incredibly alarming figures. But the question remains, and he did not even attempt to answer it: as debt has increased ten-fold during this Government's term in office, when, under this Government's policies, will we start to see it being wound back?

—The answer to that question is quite simple. This country has been going through a period of structural adjustment which was never attempted by those opposite when they were in government. For 27 years, they sat on their backsides and did nothing about structural adjustment in the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: The diversification of the export mix from this country is an enormous structural adjustment. Last year, for the first time in the history of this country, manufacturing exports were, by value, the same as rural exports. That is a huge structural adjustment. When those structural adjustment consequences come to fruition, as they will in the next two or three years, Opposition senators will see a winding down of Australia's external debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask the Minister whether the Government is going to introduce a system of individual contracts for workers covered by Federal awards. Are workers likely to lose wages and conditions under a system of individual contracts? Finally, is the Minister aware of any such agreements that have been proposed? If so, can he provide the Senate with some details?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government stands by the award system in Australia which has served this country well for nearly a century and offers minimum protections for workers so that they cannot be exploited. I have a document which I will table which is a proposed individual employment contract put to workers in Victoria. It is the sort of contract which establishes beyond any doubt, according to any reasonable judge, that the offer is based on a `take this contract or be sacked' style of negotiation. It is in fact a contract which reduces significantly the income of workers, despite the undertakings of the Victorian Liberal Party before the election that it would not do so; undertakings which have an ominous ring of familiarity in relation to those given to Australians by Mr Howard and Dr Hewson.

PARA.TAB: It is a contract to a first senior assistant in the retail store Copperart. A first senior assistant equates with the classification job manager in the State electrical, furniture and hardware shops award. The contract proposes a $12 hourly rate for 38 hours, with an abolition of rates for working late on Thursday and Friday nights and no special rates for working all day Saturday. Sick leave entitlements have been reduced and a number of other allowances that workers are entitled to as minimums under the State award are reduced as well.

When we total up the effect of this contract, the reduction in wages for a person who signs on—threatened with the only alternative of being dismissed—is $41.86 per week. This is a reduction of $41.86 per week for a worker who is not, by any stretch of the imagination, a highly paid worker. Under this contract, there is no provision for better productivity, further training or anything of that nature at all.
The actual effect is greater than $41.86 when we consider the other benefits. Before the State election in Victoria, a document was circularised by the Liberal Party in Victoria which says:

ANSWER.PARA: . no person in employment will suffer any loss of award wages or conditions.

It went on to say that this will ensure every worker who does not voluntarily enter into an agreement with his employer will not lose a cent in salary. The contract by Copperart gives the lie to that undertaking and proves that employers, in some cases, will attempt to use the provisions in the Kennett legislation to exploit their work force in a way which allows them no access to their award and no access to independent arbitration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As the Minister has referred to other possible losses under these individual contracts, can he detail to the Senate any of those losses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of them. They relate to loss of annual leave loading, loss of proper sick leave entitlement and loss of access to the full level of superannuation entitlement. They include a series of other losses, which go to accident pay, clothing allowance, compassionate leave, excess fares, holiday pay, meal breaks, meal allowance, overtime, protective clothing, redundancy, rest periods, Sunday work, termination of employment, transport allowance and a number of other things. This contract also contains a series of conditions, and if someone signs it he can be summarily dismissed for misconduct. One of the conditions is loitering in the toilets unnecessarily; they are instantly dismissed with total loss of entitlement. One of the other conditions is that if they engage in gambling or lottery activities on the premises they are dismissed. So that is the end of football pools and the end of lottery tickets. If they are caught doing that, they are out.
—Order! The time has expired.
—I draw the attention of all honourable senators to the presence in the public gallery of a distinguished former senator and a former Prime Minister of Australia, the Hon. John Gorton.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to today's national accounts figures, which in per capita terms represent virtual stagnation, and in fact on a per hour worked basis real national production actually fell by 0.2 per cent. Given that Australia requires real economic growth well in excess of 3 per cent per annum to even halt the rise in unemployment, let alone reduce it, I ask the Minister: does he concede that today's economic growth figure of 0.5 per cent means that unemployment will continue to rise under this Labor Government until well into the new year and almost certainly beyond if the Government persists with its present failed policies; and, further, does he finally concede that the Labor Party's phoney growth forecasts contained in the Budget of 3 per cent, just as with the One Nation forecast of 4 per cent, will not be met?

—That is a smorgasbord of a question. Let me try to answer it as quickly as I can. Today's figures are not incompatible with the 3 per cent growth rate set out in the Budget. As we have said on a number of occasions, we expect growth to improve progressively and the national accounts figure shows—
—You have been saying that for five years, John. When is it going to happen?

—Senator Crane would not know. For three of the five years we had one of the highest growth rates we have ever had; so what is Senator Crane talking about? The national accounts figure shows that the economy continues to grow slowly out of the recession. It grew at 0.5 per cent in the September quarter, to be 2.1 per cent above the level of a year earlier. Despite the worst efforts of the doomsayers here, there is no double dipping in this economy. Australia's growth figures are relatively good in international terms.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Knowles should listen. Australia is doing well by OECD standards. Australia has the fifth highest growth economy in the OECD. I know Senator Knowles does not want to hear this, but our economic growth is of the order of fifth out of 17 published by OECD countries.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at some of the Opposition's models. There have been nine quarters of negative growth in the Thatcher-Major model in Britain. That is still a declining economy. Switzerland has had five quarters of negative growth. Sweden has had eight quarters of negative growth. Germany has had four quarters of negative growth. Finland has had eight quarters of negative growth. The Government never said that the growth figure would be huge. In the Budget forecast we said that we believed it could reach 3 per cent, and we still do.

In terms of employment, which Senator Short asked me about, he ought to look at the 3 per cent figure and the predictions made about employment in the Budget on the basis of a 3 per cent growth figure which is still attainable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's absolute refusal to answer the essence of the question that I put to him. I ask him again: given that Australia requires real economic growth well in excess of 3 percentage points even to halt the rise in unemployment—and that is a figure that is subscribed to by the Government—does he concede that today's economic growth figure for the national accounts means that unemployment will continue to rise under this Labor Government well into the new year? Does he accept that proposition or does he not?

—Senator Short's question had no essence. His questions never have any essence. They are just a waffly statement of Liberal Party rhetoric. I thank the honourable senator for using a supplementary question to explain the essence of his very long and wordy question. As I said to Senator Short in answering the first part of the question, the growth rate predicted in the Budget Papers, which has not been revised, is 3 per cent. The forecast unemployment figure is in the Budget Papers. Senator Short should study them carefully.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister outline the main elements of the resolution on Cambodia adopted by the UN Security Council last night in New York? Does the Minister expect the resolution to have any positive result in moving the peace process forward from its current impasse?

—The Security Council has very strongly reaffirmed its commitment to the peace settlement process with Resolution 792 passed last night. It covers four main areas: the conduct of elections, responses to the Khmer Rouge's present intransigence, a reshaping of the UN's military role, and the question of economic and financial assistance. The elements of the resolution are broadly in accordance with the agreement that emerged out of the Beijing consultations which I attended a few weeks ago.

PARA.TAB: On the subject of elections, the Security Council has reiterated that general elections must go ahead as scheduled in April or May 1983, but without closing the door finally on Khmer Rouge participation. May I say in this respect that the auguries for those elections in organisational terms are very good. By the end of this week 2.5 million people will be on the rolls of registered voters. Repatriation of the 350,000 displaced persons is expected to be completed, on present rate of progress, by the end of February.

The elections are to go ahead in all areas of Cambodia to which the UN has full and free access as at 31 January 1993. That sets, in effect, that date as a deadline beyond which the Khmer Rouge cannot expect to participate in the elections even if they state an intention to do so after that time, because of the practical difficulty of organising an election with their participation. The resolution also refers to the possibility of early presidential elections, but only on the basis that they are held around the same time or in conjunction with the general election for the constituent assembly.

Secondly, the resolution condemns the Khmer Rouge's intransigence and demands that they fulfil their obligations immediately under the Paris agreements. It proposes a number of measures which are designed to put pressure on the Khmer Rouge and at the same time demonstrate that their intransigence will not be cost free. The parties concerned are to take measures to prevent the supply of petroleum products to any Cambodian party not complying with the military provisions of the agreements. UNTAC is to establish all necessary border checkpoints. Neighbouring countries are asked to cooperate in that.

The moratorium on the export of logs which has already been agreed will be implemented and enforced by UNTAC from 31 December. The Security Council has requested the SNC in Cambodia to consider adopting a similar moratorium on the export of minerals and gems. The Security Council has also foreshadowed some other measures, including in particular the freezing of Khmer Rouge assets outside Cambodia should the Khmer Rouge continue to obstruct the peace process.

Thirdly, the resolution sets in train a reshaping of UNTAC's military role in view of the impossibility of completing the disarmament and demobilisation process as a result of KR intransigence, with an emphasis being placed on the need for an UNTAC military component to protect the electoral process.

Finally, it calls for a meeting of donors to take place to review the current state of economic assistance to Cambodia in the wake of the pledging conference in June in Tokyo, which has not yet resulted in any great flow of funds. The Secretary-General was requested to report back on all of this by 15 February on the implementation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I would like to pursue the question of Khmer Rouge intentions and ask the Minister: can he add anything on assessments regarding the intentions of the Khmer Rouge, particularly in light of the latest resolution?

—We have not yet had any reaction from the Khmer Rouge to the resolution last night, but there is no particular reason to assume in the short run any change in their position of political opposition. They have announced, however, the formation of a new political party, the National Unity of Cambodia Party, to coincide with the adoption of the resolution, but they have not yet sought to register it with UNTAC. In a statement accompanying the announcement of the new party, they repeated their former unacceptable conditions for re-entering the peace process, namely to do with Vietnamese presence in the country, allegedly, and the operation of the SNC, and those conditions cannot sensibly or easily be met. As a result, there is no great expectation that they will change their spots. The big question is whether they will translate that political opposition into any full scale military reaction of a kind that would require some rethinking of the whole peace process. Our assessment is that there are still very reasonable grounds for optimism that the basic elements of the settlement will be able to be implemented to enable a democratic election to take place in April or May next year. I emphasise the importance of the Security Council resolution, demonstrating the commitment of the international community still to achieving that.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Does the Minister accept that Australia's chronic balance of payments deficits represent an economic time bomb which can be defused only with urgent and substantial changes to industry policy? Will the Government abandon its hands-off approach to industry development and, instead, identify those imports which Australia has the greatest potential to replace with local production and provide temporary protection and assistance to help new local industries get started? Thirdly, if there is to be no major overhaul of industry policy, is it not inevitable that Australian industries and jobs will continue to be replaced by imports?

—There are a few assumptions in the question with which, as I have indicated on a number of occasions, I do not agree. The first assumption is that the unemployment problem confronted by Australia—which is confronted by every European country in the same proportions and which is confronted by Canada and America in similar proportions—
—Nowhere near like Australia. We are the worst. We are the worst in the OECD.

—Senator Kemp says that we are the worst in the OECD. That is ignorant and wrong. If I might proceed without being interrupted, I will get back to the answer. The fact is that many countries, because of the present recession, have these high levels of unemployment. The assumption in the question is that that is all because jobs are being replaced by imports—and it is not an assumption with which I fundamentally agree. There are all sorts of structural reasons for unemployment in Australia, but the current level of imports is not one of them. For example, in the current account figures for the last month recorded, imports actually declined—not, I agree, by a significant amount, but they did decline. The real problem for this country is to generate greater levels of exports.
—The real problem is the government that it has.
—The real problem above that is Government Ministers being interrupted by idiots when they are trying to answer questions; that is a very difficult problem.

PARA.TAB: What I have said is not meant to be a reflection on what I believe to be absolutely genuine and real concern about this issue. I just do not agree with the assumptions that are made about the solution to that problem. We could do much better in this country if we had a financial sector that was more responsive to the requirements of industry; we could do much better if we had that. But, if the solution is seen in terms of raising tariffs, that is an old paradigm for industry policy which is not relevant to what this country is confronted with at present.

I agree that there is always room for improvement in the process of industrial structural adjustment. There are many factors which contribute to that process. There are no simplistic solutions. Only the Opposition has simplistic solutions to these problems. Nobody else who knows anything about them does.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I draw the Minister's attention to the table of imports from the Australian Bureau of Statistics for the quarter ended September 1992 and remind the Minister that in that month we imported $2.7m worth of mineral water, lolly water. In total we imported $94m worth of beverages—all products which we produce in Australia. Would it not be wise to do what a family does when its expenditure exceeds its income and cut out those things which we do not need to import?

—Senator Coulter should not think that there is not room for concern about these issues. The fact of the matter is that any decent Australian should buy Australian mineral water because it is better than the overseas product anyway. If one adds up all these little consumer items such as champagne and mineral water, one finds that they make a minuscule contribution to the total import bill which this country incurs. The big ticket import items in this country are aircraft which we do not make in Australia, certain types of ships which we do not make in Australia and a range of computer hardware which we do not make in Australia.

PARA.TAB: If we say to any of our trading partners, `We are closing off imports of these products from your country', there will be retaliation. As I said before, what this country has to be about is more and more exports. If we knock off imports—mineral water from France, or wherever—we will get retaliation against our export products in those markets. That is cutting off one's nose to spite one's face—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you remove some taxes off the exports?

—which Senator Macdonald does all the time, with his silly interjections. This is the sort of problem which we are confronted with in considering these issues. It is minuscule in terms of the total issue.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Today is World AIDS Day, and that recognises the importance of that disease for all countries. Can the Minister explain the special emphasis of today's theme and the relevance of that theme for Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is World AIDS Day. I notice that several honourable senators are wearing ribbons indicating their commitment to no male violence against women. But the ribbon that I am wearing today represents the World AIDS Day theme. The red ribbon is for compassion for those living with HIV or AIDS and the multicoloured part represents the rainbow, a universal symbol of hope. If there is any hope, it lies in the commitment of the world theme to involving the community in the battle against this pandemic which is ravaging the world.

PARA.TAB: Within Australia, the Government has taken a leading role, with other jurisdictions and also based on community groups, neighbourhood networks and various voluntary organisations, particularly within the gay community, in trying to get strong preventive measures across. The Prime Minister only the other day sent a message to the AIDS conference to this effect:

ANSWER.PARA: In particular, I want today to pay tribute to those in the gay community where HIV-AIDS remains largely confined, who in the midst of tragedy have worked hard to provide education and support.

Whilst that is true, it is quite clear that a lot more needs to be done. Young male homosexuals need to be especially targeted with the various programs of information on this matter. It is not simply a question of information. Only before lunch I was reading the Australian Youth Policy in Action Coalition's November newsletter which, amongst other things, for example, speaks of non-penetrative sex being an area where norms and attitudes are changing amongst young male gay people. This is an important aspect of the cultural change that needs to occur in relation to the presence of this epidemic. So there is a gap between knowledge and behaviour. I believe that the behavioural change needs to be fostered by many methods.

PARA.TAB: Within Australia many groups are working to deal with the tragedy of those many Australians who are living with HIV or AIDS. Within my own small Tasmanian State community some 80 persons have contracted the HIV-AIDS virus, and some 19 fellow Tasmanians have died over the last several years. In Launceston last Sunday I was able to unveil a plaque commemorating those who are living with HIV or AIDS. I think it is in local communities that we get the strong networks of support and carers who can help alleviate to some extent the suffering and trauma that is associated with the presence of this disease in our community, and amongst friends and companions, many of those with whom I met in Launceston last Sunday. This is a matter for local communities and for Australian commitment. I believe the commitment of the Australian Government is probably without parallel around the world in dealing sensibly with this epidemic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. That answer focuses mainly on Australia. Given that AIDS is an international disease with a very different profile in other countries—for example, in South Africa it is a homosexual disease amongst whites and a heterosexual disease amongst blacks—can the Minister outline world perspectives in management, including Australia's contribution through its foreign aid projects?

—I am not as aware as Senator Crowley is, apparently, about the South African profile for the spread and transmission of this disease. Certainly, in sub-Sahara Africa, there is no doubt that it is wiping out whole populations. In our own region I understand that Mr Howe, after a very recent visit to Thailand and the Philippines, was able to enter into agreements—and in Jakarta, too, I believe—with high officials to ensure that Australia's experience is made known in the preventive and education programs and in the involvement of community groups, those at risk groups, which is so essential to getting an education message across. I believe that those countries are looking to Australia to assist them in devising good programs to deal with this disease, but, as Senator Crowley I think hints at, ones that are culturally sensitive and aware of the differences not only in the way in which the disease is transmitted in the South East Asian countries but also in the way in which one should approach the education of the populations most at risk.
—Under standing order 72—
—Oh, no, not another stunt.
—I would not ask Senator Cook a question because he never answers them.
—Order!

—Mr President, if I could ask my question. Under standing order 72, my question is addressed to Senator Short. It relates to his notice of motion No. 1300 about the policy failures of the Keating Labor Government, which draws attention to the balance of payments crisis and plunging living standards. Does Senator Short regard this as an urgent motion and, if so, does he intend bringing it forward for debate?

—I thank Senator Kemp for his question. The answer, in brief, is yes, this notice of motion is urgent because it highlights the major economic crisis this country is now facing. The horrendous current account deficit of $1.8 billion in October looks even worse now that we have the foreign debt breaking through the previously unbelievable thought of $200 billion barrier—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite laugh at the foreign debt going through $200 billion. That is just typical of what they are.
