We need to debate the crisis that 10 years of Labor government has produced. We now have net debt as a percentage of our national income up from 10 per cent in 1982 to a whopping 42 per cent today. Our debt to the rest of the world is now more than $11,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia. Even in Paul Keating's banana republic days of 1986, net debt was less than half of what it is today. Mr Keating called that a crisis, so what on earth have we got now? Where are we now? The September quarter national accounts figures announced today show a truly staggering net foreign debt position in excess of $162,000m—a growth of 9 per cent in the last three months alone.

PARA.TAB: The gravity of our position is indicated by the fact that net exports actually made a negative contribution to the growth figures announced today; so there is no comfort there at all. Australia now has one of the worst performing economies in the industrial world, and it is even more urgent that we debate this motion today because it is clear that the Government has no answers at all to the tragic situation which it itself has created.

In his press conference today following the release of the figures, the Treasurer commented on yesterday's call for a White Paper by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Bernie Fraser. Do honourable senators know what Mr Dawkins said? He said that there would be no point in the Government having one of those because White Papers require new policies. Of course, the Government does not have any of those, and that is despite the abject failure of every so-called initiative since the banana republic statement of May 1986, almost 6 1/2 years ago.

Barry Jones, Labor's Federal President, said yesterday that the Government would need to do more than just knock the coalition's policies to win the election. Barry Jones was dead right. Labor now should be out supporting the policies of the coalition because they are the only policies that will put Australia back on the road to recovery, job creation and growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Might I say what a pleasure it is to get a clear answer to a straightforward question. Thank you for that, Senator Short. I draw Senator Short's attention to my original question, where I mentioned falling living standards. It has been quite remarkable that under a Labor government average earnings have been cut. Can Senator Short explain to us why, under the Keating-Kelty-Senator Cook model, real earnings have actually been cut by a Labor government, and what would the coalition propose to do about that?

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—You cannot take it, can you? I thank Senator Kemp for pointing out that, under this Government and its policies, average wages have been cut in clear distinction to our neighbours across the Tasman—New Zealand—where they have gone up. This is the case because of the failure of this Government to introduce the necessary policies to make Australia more competitive. As a result, our productivity growth is being far outstripped by most other trading nations and, unless we change direction, unless we introduce policies to make Australia more competitive and more productive, real wages will continue to decline. The tragedy is that we do not need to be going down the path that we are under this Government. The only way we can start to go forward now is by embracing the policies put forward by the coalition in its Fightback package.
—Order! The time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Firstly, will the Minister confirm that the seven Chinese people who were forcibly repatriated to that country are now imprisoned in China? Secondly, for what period will the Government continue to monitor and publicly report on the safety of people who are repatriated to their country of origin? Thirdly, will the Government continue to repatriate Chinese and others if past and present experiences indicate possible imprisonment upon their return? Fourthly, will the Government give an undertaking not to forcibly repatriate those held in the centres at Westbridge and Port Hedland during the forthcoming holiday season when access to lawyers and courts may be limited?

—In my latest brief from the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, I certainly have no information that any particular returnees are in fact imprisoned in China. We have received assurances from the Chinese Government that those returned will not be punished for their illegal departure. It is understood that under Chinese law returnees may be detained for a short period while their identities are confirmed and inquiries are made concerning any criminal elements involved in arranging illegal departures.

PARA.TAB: All honourable senators will know that people who apply for refugee status in Australia have their claims very thoroughly examined. It follows that those who are refused have been assessed as not having a well founded fear in the terms of the international conventions which would militate against their return. And we do not, as a matter of course, monitor everyone's return to his or her home country.

Senator Chamarette asked whether we will continue to repatriate Chinese and others. One cannot give global or group answers. Each case involving the removal of a person from Australia is judged on its individual merits. Persons will only be returned when the Government is convinced that they do not satisfy the criteria which would expose them to their fears being realised through actual persecution.

As to Senator Chamarette's last question, the law is clear: when boat people are assessed individually and their case is thoroughly examined, where their applications have been refused, the law requires that they be removed from Australia as soon as is practicable, once the scope for appeals and other relevant action has been undertaken or finalised.

The law makes no allowance for the holiday season. Therefore, the Government is certainly not in a position to give an undertaking not to remove people at this or at any other time of the year once the process of their proper assessment has been completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister prepared to table the evidence that he repeatedly refers to regarding the assurances that those repatriated to China will not be imprisoned?
—I understand that these would be at a level between the Australian and Chinese governments. If I can get some sort of access to those assurances, I will make them available to Senator Chamarette.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the John Curtin Memorial Address which was delivered by the ALP Federal President, Mr Barry Jones, in Fremantle on Sunday last. In the course of this address, Mr Jones said that the Government `still lacked positive ideas to put to the electorate'. And he added:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . we are still lacking in what George Bush called so eloquently `the vision thing'.
Does the Minister agree with the ALP President, Mr Jones, that the Government lacks positive ideas and any visionary ideas?

TALK.START.PARA: —I ought to tell the Opposition that government is about hard work and getting things done. It is not about the sorts of visions the Opposition's Deputy Leader described yesterday as stuffing copies of Fightback up people's drainpipes. If that is the vision of the Opposition, then it is in a pretty sorry state.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday morning on radio, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that 80 million copies of Fightback had been distributed and `we are even stuffing it up drainpipes'. What an extraordinary vision for an Opposition to have! Mr Jones is not a member of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —He happens to be your Federal President.
—Yes, of course. And John Elliott used to be the Opposition's Federal President but it never talked much about him at the time, or since.
—Get back onto your bloke.
—You made the interjection; you have to cop the answer.
—And answer the question.

—Steady down, you are getting too excited and red in the face. Come on, poke your tongue out. So far as the major questions confronting this economy are concerned, of course the Government has made a number of major statements, of which One Nation is the most important. It is a stimulatory package for the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: I know the Opposition does not believe in stimulatory packages—its Leader said so the other day. Instead, the Opposition is just going to inflict a bigger tax on the Australian people. But, so far as positive ideas and what the Opposition is calling the `vision thing' are concerned, when we have an election the Government will announce its policies and the Opposition will have to deal with them then.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to reports that independent motion picture exhibitors are being forced by motion picture distributors to conform to practices that disadvantage them in relation to the large theatre complexes, specifically in relation to no-share arrangements where a movie screen must be solely dedicated to one film for weeks at a time. Will the Minister take steps to prevent the closure of independent theatres throughout Australia? What steps does he propose to ensure that these restrictive trade practices are outlawed?

—Senator Sowada has taken on the role of the Trade Practices Commission, or at least of some court, in the latter part of her question in assuming that there has been a breach of the Trade Practices Act. Whilst what she is referring to may involve practices which would call for investigation under that statute, I certainly cannot answer the question in terms of her assertion that that has been the case.

PARA.TAB: There have been representations made over the years in relation to film hiring practices and other practices of the major film distributors. I recall that recently—I think it was earlier this year—the Prices Surveillance Authority intervened when a film distribution chain tried to charge a flat per capita fee of $5.15 for Lethal Weapon 3. There was a great outcry from the smaller independent movie houses. The Trade Practices Commission took up the matter and I believe that that proposal from the main distributors was withdrawn. In some instances, the spectre of the TPC carrying out an investigation has been enough to prevent practices which would have the damaging effect that Senator Sowada is concerned about. It has had the effect of stopping them going ahead.

I think independent cinema owners are like many small businesses in Australia which are confronted by highly concentrated industries dominated by a few large players, particularly where there is dependence upon some of those large players for wholesale supply. In this respect I can understand their raising their voices, like many small businesses have, seeking the protection of the Trade Practices Act. Section 46 deals with abuse of market power and section 47 deals with exclusive dealing. It may be that the complaints can be brought within the purview of those sections.

Before anything could be undertaken by the Trade Practices Commission, evidence would need to be brought forward—if it can be brought forward—to the Trade Practices Commission, directly or through Senator Sowada's good offices. We would be prepared to forward that to the Trade Practices Commission for its consideration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to the statement he made in an interview on 13 May 1990 in relation to the current account deficit, when he said that unless the Government could improve the current account:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . it would be very unlikely and not deserving for a government to win in those circumstances.

As yesterday's balance of payments figures for October 1992 showed that Australia recorded its worst balance of payments figure in almost three years and was the ninth successive monthly trend estimate rise, does he still stand by his remarks that the Government does not deserve to, nor can it, win?

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do not stand by the proposition that this Government cannot win.
—You are standing there as Goebbels, are you? Repeat a lie often enough.
—I ask Senator Baume to withdraw that remark.
—If the honourable senator is offended by it, I withdraw it. I do not know why he is offended, but I withdraw.

—The fact is that there are certain fundamental issues in relation to the Australian economy about which the Opposition has a purported solution which is not a solution at all and which does nothing about the sorts of problems which Senator Bishop's question purports to address.

PARA.TAB: Last month 75 independent economists, asked whether employment would be worse under the Liberal Party or us, said that it would be worse under the Liberal Party. What does Fightback say about the current account—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. You repeated your ruling only yesterday in respect of members of the Government debating Opposition policy. I ask you to direct the Minister to the question.

—On the point of order, Mr President: just last week Senator Ray produced a sheaf of references in which Senator Hill and Senator Crichton-Browne and other senators had asked questions on Opposition policy when they were in government. Now we have exactly the reverse. This is a double standard. You should rule that point of order out of order.
—I ask the Minister to reply to the question he was asked.
—The point about the current account deficit, for Senator Bishop's information, is that it is lower as a percentage of GDP than it was in 1990—
—Oh, it is good news, is it?

—Yes, it is. It is an improvement. To take the raw figure, as those opposite do in all these questions, worked out by some B-grade illiterate adviser and say, `It is bigger in total number than it has been before' makes it worse. Senator Short comes in here and says that the debt is $11,000 per family and all that sort of stuff. That is all bunkum in terms of dealing with the issues relating to this economy. As a percentage of GDP, the current account deficit is not worse. We debate these issues in an environment in which not one alternative policy is offered which has any relevance to this particular problem. I have not been discussing Opposition policy; I have been saying that there is not any and that is a very different thing.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As the Minister has just advised the Senate that he does not stand by his word, and I quote him, and as the Prime Minister has frequently had to recant from his, would the Minister confirm to the Senate that indeed that proves that the Government's word cannot be trusted and one cannot trust Labor with money?

—This is using the procedures of the Senate to try out another cheapjack slogan from the Liberal-National coalition. That is all the supplementary question is about and Senator Bishop ought to know better. She is a little more articulate than the rest of them. She ought to know better than to try that sort of stunt. As I said, the important thing about the current account deficit is its proportion to the GDP. GDP has grown in this country and it is growing again. That is the important issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving a motion in the following terms:
That the Senate censures the Government for:
(a)continually misleading the Australian people over the nation's economic prospects;

(b)continuing to implement policies which have failed causing nearly one million Australians to become unemployed, Australia's foreign debt to blow out to $200 billion and now the nation's balance of payments to again worsen with Australia recording the worst figure in three years; and
(c)the Keating Government's steadfast refusal to embrace alternative policies to address this national crisis.

SPEECH.PARA: If this Government would take Question Time seriously, it would not be necessary to intervene in this way, but we have asked today a series of questions relating to the economic crisis which is befalling this nation. We and the Australian people would have thought that we would have received serious answers in respect of these issues. These issues are of critical importance to all Australians, and perhaps most of all to the one million Australians who are currently out of work as a result of this Government's policies.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday we got the balance of payments figures—$1.8 billion, again in deficit. Despite the recession, the trend is going up. The trend line has gone up for the last nine months to the highest figure yesterday of $1.8 billion. We have gone back to the awful figures of a few years ago.

Did the Government seriously answer questions relating to that? No. There was no attempt. Of course, as Senator Knowles will tell us, it did not answer the questions relating to the cause because it does not have the answers. It has caused the problem; it cannot fix it.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: I ask a question so that I can be clear about my duties as a Minister at Question Time. Does this bring Question Time to an end for the purposes of either the chamber or the ABC broadcast? I need to know so that I know whether to stay here and prepare to answer further questions.

—On the point of order, Mr President: the question that is being asked of you is whether the Minister is required to stay here for the balance of Question Time. I would have thought that a motion of this nature would have compelled him to stay here regardless. Of course he has to stay here.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I will answer the points of order when there is silence. As I understood it, a contingent notice of motion could be moved only between items of business. But it was moved during Question Time, and I was not so sure about that, so I let it continue. It is up to the Leader of the Government as to when Question Time ceases.

—I have five minutes to establish urgency. I would not think it would require any time at all because everyone else in this country sees these matters as urgent except that lot on the other side of this chamber. I was saying that yesterday's appalling balance of payments figure is something that should have been addressed seriously by this Government, and it was not. It was basically dismissed. Yet today the position has worsened again with the national accounts figures.

—On a point of order, Mr President: I thought you just indicated that a contingent notice of motion should be moved only between items of business. Therefore, is the Leader of the Opposition out of order?

—On the point of order, Mr President: would it make Senator Hill's motion in order if Senator Button were to ask that further questions be put on notice? Then we would be between items of business and his motion would be in order.
—Order! I said to Senator Tate earlier that I was unsure about that. I therefore allowed it when there was no objection to it. I will check whether it was right or wrong.

—It is apparent that the Government still does not want to debate these important issues. Today's figures indicated that our gross foreign debt had risen to an incredible $200 billion. It has increased by 10 times since this Government has been in office. Our first question of the Government today was how it explains that and what it is going to do about it. Senator Button sat there and did not make one attempt to answer that very serious question. He talked about the claimed economic illiteracy of other people, but the Australian people are sick and tired of that.

PARA.TAB: Ten years ago the foreign debt of this country was one-tenth of what it is today—now over $200 billion. As I said, that is $11,000 for every man, woman and child. The causes of that enormous foreign debt are the economic policies that the Government has pursued so unsuccessfully for 10 years. That is why I say in this motion that its economic policies have failed, and that is why it should be able to address that failure. We would have thought—most Australians would have thought—that the Government would be coming in here with a change of direction of economic policy, because the one million unemployed is good reason for it to do so. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill is seeking to suspend Standing Orders because he wants to put on a bit of a stunt. He wants to take questions away from the Democrats and the Independent senators by putting on a stunt which he thinks is important.

PARA.TAB: The Government is not for a moment prepared to accept this sort of procedural motion in the middle of Question Time from the collection of economic illiterates on the other side of the table. Senator Hill continues to refer to trend lines, but the trend line which really worries the Opposition is the trend line showing the falling popularity for an Opposition—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will quote Senator Hill in a minute.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The motion before the Chair is to debate a question of urgency. I ask you to direct the Minister to put his attention to the question of why the Government says it is not urgent to debate these balance of payment figures.
—This is a motion to suspend Standing Orders. The five-minute time limit was allowed and it has been a convention that people speaking on both sides have allowed wide-ranging debate.

—The point I was making was that Senator Hill's speech was cluttered with references to trend lines. The trend line that is bothering those opposite—and this is why the urgency—is that they complain about all these dreadful situations in this country and when Senator Hill gets up and purports to speak for the Australian people, they do not think too highly of him, I can tell him, in spite of all these circumstances which he describes. That is the trend line that is bothering those opposite. That is what makes this a matter of urgency.

PARA.TAB: What bothers them most is that they have articulated a set of policies which have nothing to do with the issues about which they now complain. They talk about unemployment. As I said, 75 per cent of Australian economists surveyed think unemployment would be worse under a coalition government, if there was one. Those opposite came in here today complaining that we dismissed the current account figure yesterday. Not at all. But as I said yesterday, and as I said again today in answer to a question from Senator Bishop, the current account deficit fell from 3.8 per cent of GDP in the year to the September quarter 1991, to 3.4 per cent this year, in spite of weak commodity prices. That is the important measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good news?

—No, not good news, but better news than those opposite would want to make out. They come in here and they talk about the deficit, they talk about the national debt and all those things in simple slogans and economic illiteracy. There is no cause for urgent consideration of these matters because the only urgency is the declining popularity of those opposite. That is what really bugs the Opposition. In the traditions of this place, we do not normally pull stunts like the stunt Senator Hill pulled in the middle of Question Time.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I refer you particularly to the standing order that refers to reflecting on the motives of senators. This is not a stunt. It is reflecting on Senator Hill to describe it as a stunt and I ask the Minister to withdraw.

—It is just a matter of debate. I do not think it is unparliamentary. In reply to points of order and questions I was asked earlier, the televising will cease when Senator Button ceases his contribution.
—I am happy to withdraw, if that offends people over there, provided this man, the shadow Minister for a hundred failed shadow ministries, the noisy grub of the Senate, who accuses me—
—I raise a point of order.
—Order! I do not need a point of order. You cannot call anyone a grub, Senator Button.

—Mr President, I withdraw that allegation. I will deal with it later. There is no urgency. Excited as Senator Hill always gets when he thinks he sees a bad figure in the Australian economy, he has tried to turn it into an urgency motion, but there is no urgency about this and we will not support the motion.

—Senators will recall that the week before last we sat right through the night until a quarter to six in the morning dealing with the Appropriation Bills. We came back on the Monday of the following week with a suspended debate, and the Opposition insisted that it have a Question Time because Question Time was just so important. It had to keep the Government on its toes; it had to question Ministers and without Question Time this place would simply fall apart. That was its argument then. Despite the fact that it had had 200 hours of Estimates committees and debate on the Appropriation Bills, it still had to have a Question Time. Yet, today, what does Senator Hill do? Senator Hill truncates Question Time and says that he does not think that Question Time is very important. This mob over here are not to be believed. They use one argument one day and, when it suits their purpose, they use a totally different argument on another day.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections. One of the problems with the acoustics in this chamber is that it is very hard to hear who is making the interjections up in that corner of the chamber. There are too many of them. I ask that they cease.

—Senators would also remember that we have argued interminably in this place hour after hour about how many questions are asked at Question Time, about the amount of time to be allowed for each question. The Opposition argues that it must ask these questions; it must ask the Ministers these things; it must keep the Government on its toes. Yet today Senator Hill turns around and says, `We can dispense with Question Time. We don't need Question Time. We can get away with suspension of Standing Orders'.

PARA.TAB: This motion by Senator Hill, quite simply, is an attention seeking attempt. There were people in the gallery. Question Time was on. Of course, most of the people in the gallery have now left. Perhaps Senator Hill has achieved his objective. The Opposition's word when it argues about the importance of Question Time simply cannot be accepted at all. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I place that on the record. We will remember it the next time the Opposition comes along and wants our support for modification of Question Time.

Turning to the substantive issue, it is absolutely on the record that under the Fightback package unemployment will actually rise. The Opposition will accept a 4 per cent increase in inflation. Dr Hewson has said that the only instrument left to the Reserve Bank will be to increase interest rates to control the economy. If we allowed a suspension of the Standing Orders, the proposals which the Opposition would seek to put forward in debate would simply be to put in place an extension of economic rationalism, which has been shown over the last 10 years not to work.

There is substantially no difference between where the Government is coming from and where the Opposition is coming from on the sorts of mechanisms, the sorts of levers that they would use—I was going to say to control the Australian economy but, of course, it is not to control the Australian economy; it is to pursue a hands-off, deregulatory, leave it to the market, abandon the Australian people to international forces approach. That is certainly no solution to the predicament in which Australia finds itself. We do not need to hear from the Opposition any further. That would be a waste of time. We know that it has no solutions to our problems.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by Senator Hill. This is a matter of extreme urgency. There are just no answers coming from the Government. Its defence is to attack the Opposition. Honourable senators on this side of the chamber, and the rest of Australia, are sick of having no answers. We come into this Parliament continuously and ask, `What are your policies? What are you going to do?' We get a diatribe of tripe on what the Fightback package will not do. It is just Goebbels at his worst.

PARA.TAB: The Government has brought in eight economic statements. Eight times it has tried to correct the economy and it has gone down at every hurdle. With every economic statement that it has brought forward, it has gone down. It has tried eight times to correct the economy. Things are so bad that today Mr Fraser has said that the Government ought to bring down a White Paper. That is what happened after the Second World War: a White Paper had to be brought into the Parliament. And Mr Fraser is saying that things are so bad now that a White Paper should be brought into the Parliament and debated.

I think that the Government should bring in a white flag and surrender. That is what it is all about. It has had eight tries and it has failed eight times. Every figure that comes in here is one of disappointment. Someone remarked—I think it was Senator Button—that Senator Hill is in a state of excitement every time he sees a figure that is bad. Well, Senator Hill would be in a continual state of excitement because we never see a figure come into this place that has any certainty or any promise of recovery in it. We see one bad figure after the next bad figure after the next bad figure.
Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what the Australian Democrats are getting so excited about today, but they are certainly showing their true colours because they are really putting the boot into the coalition. I do not understand what their position is, but I can assure them that the matter is urgent. The debate should proceed because the people of Australia want answers. They are demanding answers on what the Government policy is and where it is leading us. Where we are being led at the moment is down the track to disaster. We are going downhill from one disaster to the next disaster. So let us debate this issue freely now and let the Government tell us how it will correct the $1.8 billion current account deficit figure yesterday or the foreign debt that has run up by 9 per cent to $163 billion net today, or why the growth figures are only 0.5 per cent for the September quarter. That is what we want to know. That is what the Parliament is demanding. That is what the people want—just some plain, simple answers of what the Government intends to do in the next three months to correct the economy. That is all we want. Surely on the Government side there is someone who can string together a few answers in the next hour or so. That is why I believe this is a matter of urgency that should be debated straightaway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not support this motion because it is based on a fraudulent proposal. The fraudulent proposal is that we are not prepared to debate the economy. That is just untrue. We are prepared to debate the economy, but in its rightful place. The stunt by the Opposition of aborting Question Time—after holding Question Time up as the paragon of virtue in this place—and pretending that the genuine interests of senators in asking questions can be swept aside, is inappropriate.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday in this chamber we had a debate about the economy. The debate about the economy was during debate on a motion of censure of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and me concerning the industrial relations issues of yesterday. What actually happened then? I rose to speak on that motion. The time allotted for my speech was 20 minutes. I got to within eight minutes of concluding and then we had an organised, systematic and concerted campaign of endless points of order, and finally a quorum called, to prevent my speaking—to deny my right of reply to the criticisms that had been made of me and the Prime Minister. So, when the Opposition did have an opportunity to debate the economy, what did it do? By resorting to technicalities and devices, it intended to silence the Government by successive points of order. I would be surprised if I am able to complete the balance of what I have to say now without a point of order from the Opposition to try to stop me, but I will make the effort.

The Opposition is not concerned about the economy. The Opposition is concerned about all the opinion polls that are being published lately which converge on one unassailable conclusion: if an election were held in Australia, Labor would win and the Opposition would lose. All of the opinion polls quote that.

One of the other reasons why we ought not to go into this debate now is that the Opposition as a corporate entity does not tell the truth about key economic statistics. Only in Question Time today we had, in a staged and ham-fisted way, an organised question to an Opposition front bencher using the Government's Question Time. What did we hear? We heard, as I understood the answer, that productivity in New Zealand was higher than productivity in Australia. I got on the phone and checked with my advisers, who checked the statistics. That assertion by Senator Short is not true. Productivity in Australia is higher than productivity in New Zealand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Says who?

—If the Opposition wants to have a debate about that in its place, at its time, we will go to the statistics and I will establish that point beyond reasonable doubt. The Opposition uses these occasions to cry crocodile tears about its alleged and faint-hearted concern for the unemployed. That is what this is—a stunt to pretend sympathy and concern for the plight of the unemployed. A mark of true concern about the unemployed would be what the Opposition is proposing to do about it—and kicking unemployed people off the dole after nine months, as the Opposition proposes, is not a sign of compassion. It is not a sign of concern. Consigning people to the scrap heap with no unemployment benefits after nine months—the Opposition's policy under Fightback—is not a sign of concern about unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition wants to talk down the economy continuously. This is the fourth quarter of sustained positive GDP growth. Company pre-tax profits in Australia rose by 26 per cent in the October quarter, 67 per cent above the recession low. Talking about unemployment, CES unfilled vacancies were up by 24 per cent over the last quarter, the highest since June 1990. Over the quarter, CES job placements were up by 119,000, of which 27 per cent were placements of the longer term unemployed, and ABS job vacancies were up by 10.9 per cent in mid-May 1992.

The economy is coming into recovery. The recovery is not as strong as anyone would like, but it is there and it needs to be encouraged. Talking it down—the Opposition's stunt—may have electoral advantages for the Opposition, but it does not help Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to support the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders because today we have seen that Australia's foreign debt has blown out to $200 billion. That is an amazing and incredible figure. Australia's foreign debt is a matter that concerns a lot of ordinary people in the community. They are most concerned as to what burdens they are placing on the shoulders of their children, who have to repay the debt. I listened to Question Time and I listened to the answers from Senator Button. I am not satisfied with those answers. Senator Button has indicated that we are in a better position to service the debt, growing though it is, than we were 12 months ago. He also said that it is not all public debt; a lot of it is private debt.

PARA.TAB: What I had hoped to hear from Senator Button was something about banking policy. A lot of industries nowadays, small and large, cannot get the banks to lend on cash flows. The banks are putting the screws on small business. They have had their fingers burnt, but they have not had them burnt by the people who are asking for loans just to keep their businesses going. Where are those people going to get the money? They are going overseas to get the money. It is a situation that I thought the Minister may have addressed.

I am sorry that the Leader of the Opposition chose to move his motion with seven minutes to go in Question Time. I do not think it is appropriate for Question Time to be thus interfered with because of its importance. But the Leader of the Government is the one who declares when Question Time will cease, and no doubt Senator Button after this debate will give us another seven minutes of Question Time. Nevertheless, as the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders has been moved, I will support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us another one of these attempts to feign concern about the state of the Australian economy in the hope that the reiteration of bad figures will continue to talk the economy down. Let us remember that there are really four key issues before the economy today: jobs, prices, wages, and the provision of services to people in need. What have we got as a proposal from those opposite? Solving the jobs problem by sacking people; solving the inflation problem by putting up prices; solving the problem of the living standards of workers by cutting their wages and working conditions; and improving services to the poor by slashing Government spending on services. No wonder that at the polls the Australian people have said time and again that they reject the Opposition's proposals.

PARA.TAB: When we look at the four key issues before Australians today, we see that those opposite have precisely the wrong remedy. The problems are clear and their remedies are just wrong; they are absolutely inappropriate. The rest of the world is going in the opposite direction. Dr Hewson says, `Stimulatory policies are entirely inappropriate'. Perhaps we should send him to Japan; he can be a consultant to the Japanese Government, which has just given a massive fiscal stimulus to its economy. After that, we can put him in a plane and fly him to London—anywhere but Australia. He could advise Mr Major about how inappropriate is the massive fiscal stimulus he has just given to his economy. Then he could fly across to Washington and advise President Clinton about the appropriateness—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the Japanese balance of payment's position?

—Does the honourable senator want me to talk about growth rates in Japan and the creation of jobs in Japan? Ours is higher. Those opposite try to pluck statistics out of the air. The fact is that on all those policies they are going in the wrong direction. The Australian people know that, and that is why they reject the Opposition again and again. It is for exactly the same reason, as everybody knows, that every Western economy is going through a difficult economic time, and the Australian people understand that. The Opposition's attempt to pretend that it is exclusively an Australian product will not wash because people know it is not true. The facts are quite clear. The August edition of the Economist in a survey of international economists asked: `Which economy is likely to grow most quickly in the OECD in 1992?'. The answer was Australia.
—They got it wrong?

—No, they got it right. They predicted in 1992 that Australia would be the fastest growing economy, and they are right. They predicted that in 1993 Australia would be the fastest growing economy, and they are right. That is not a case for any complacency. Of course we need to do better; of course we need more growth. But the last thing we need is a government that is proposing to pull out the fiscal stimulus and slow the economy, slow the rate of economic growth, and therefore destroy more jobs. The last thing we need is a government that comes to office proposing a massive increase in prices, a one-off surge in prices—let us not talk about the equity side of it. Even if the policies of those opposite work as they say, there will be a one-off surge in prices. If their policy works, then they will have exactly the wrong policy with regard to prices.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the living standards of Australian workers, the policies of Kennett, and the policies that those opposite have endorsed, make it absolutely clear that the living standards of Australian workers would be under significant attack. Now we have a fourth arm. We have always had the three conservative arms—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented and seek leave to make a short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of his remarks during the debate on the motion to suspend Standing Orders, Senator Cook claimed that I said during Question Time that the level of increase in productivity in New Zealand had been greater than that in Australia in the last year. My clear understanding is that I did not; certainly my intent was not to say that. I think when Senator Cook checks the record he will find that I said that in the last 12 months in Australia the

SPEECH.PARA: level of real wages has fallen but has risen in New Zealand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop this day, relating to the balance of payments.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue that I wish to address in relation to this answer revolves around the comparative state of the balance of payments crisis in Australia compared with other countries. Senator Button tried to down play that comparison and tended to argue that other countries were experiencing a similar balance of payments crisis. In his answer, if I recall, he again drew attention to what he regarded as the poor economic performance of the British economy. Those are two matters I wish to briefly address.

PARA.TAB: In the Economist of 14 November there is an interesting table which looks at the balance of payments figures, amongst other things, in the major industrialised countries. The figure used measured the current account as a percentage of the GDP. If we look at the year 1992 and the forecast for 1993, according to the figures—and the figures were compiled before the current blow-out in the balance of payments—the deficit in Australia as a percentage of GDP in 1992 was 3.5 per cent. I stress that this does not take account of the recent dreadful figures. When we look through that table—Belgium, Canada, France, Germany, Holland, Italy, Japan, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the UK and the US are listed—we see that only one other country, Canada, has a higher deficit as a share of GDP. In other words, Australia is one of the worst performing countries amongst comparative economies.

When we go to 1993—I stress again that these figures were compiled before the recent figures were produced—the Economist forecast that the current account deficit as a percentage of GDP will be about minus 3.9 per cent. No other country amongst the countries I have named has a figure as high as that. In other words, the crisis in Australia with the balance of payments is very serious, and we are certainly amongst the very worst. As far as the Economist is concerned, for next year Australia will stand alone as having the worst balance of payments crisis.

If I can now make some quick remarks on the relationship between the performance of the Australian and UK economies—Senator Button has ceaselessly raised this in this chamber—I invite him to look at the comparative figures and the performance of the two economies. It is my belief that the UK economy is not a particularly well-performing economy—there are serious structural problems in the UK—so I certainly do not believe it is the best model. Its problems are different from those of Australia.

Between 1983 and 1991, consumer prices rose in the UK by 57 per cent and in Australia by 67 per cent. When we consider average weekly earnings, how did the Thatcher and Major Governments deal with the issue of trying to increase real wages and salaries of workers compared with the Labor Government in Australia? As everybody concedes, in Australia earnings for the married man are below the average whereas in the UK they have increased substantially. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to my colleague Senator Kemp for obtaining leave to take note of Senator Button's answer to my question because I, too, wish to add a few remarks on that answer. I asked Senator Button whether he would stand by the comments he made in 1990 that unless the Government could improve the current account, it would be very unlikely, and not deserving, to win. He said that he did not stand by his remarks.

PARA.TAB: I pointed out that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) makes remarks which he has to back away from. There is the infamous One Nation statement where all the projections have been found to be wrong and where all the so-called jobs that were to come from the expenditure outlined therein simply have not occurred. Again and again we find that the Labor Party simply makes forecasts or statements which it will not honour and which prove to be false. I said very simply that one cannot trust Labor with money.

There are two things I want to say about the figures for this month. Of that seasonally adjusted $1.8 billion deficit figure—the real figure being in the vicinity of $2 billion—the vast, overwhelming proportion is the cost of servicing our existing debt. To find that Australia puts herself into debt to between $12 billion and $18 billion each year adds to our international debt while the Government stands up and says `It is really okay; we are all doing terribly well' is really tantamount to Nero fiddling while Rome burns.

If these were our personal finances and our personal circumstances, and if we had a mortgage on our house as this nation has a mortgage on its future, and we were not earning enough money to make the monthly repayments on the mortgage—as this country is not earning enough money to make the monthly repayments on our existing debt—we know what would happen. The bailiffs would come in and sell us up, and down would go our standard of living. That is exactly what the IMF will do to us if we do not implement the sorts of policies recommended by the Fightback package that will indeed address the need for Australians to again save and to create our own indigenous capital which we can then draw upon to develop our own nation.

According to the seasonally adjusted figures as published, the debt servicing component is $1.4 billion, the raw figure being $1.7 billion, out of a total deficit of $1.8 billion. This is a tremendous indictment. The fact is that Government senators stood there today, barefaced, with the assistance of the Democrats, and refused to debate the seriousness of the continuation of this Government's policy. If they had had a mind and taken the opportunity to take a leaf out of Fightback's book and started to introduce a change in policy, we might then have started to see an improvement.

Basically, we have a Government that has no policy at all—no policy to address a relieving of our current account deficit, the one million unemployed and the plight of this nation. The sooner we go to an election and this Government is voted out of office and we can put into place a policy that will abolish seven taxes, lower income tax and raise pensions to again give hope to this country, the better we will all be served.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL TRAINING AUTHORITY BILL 1992VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING BILL 1992

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to discuss the Australian National Training Authority Bill and the Vocational Education and Training Funding Bill 1992. The former Bill seeks to establish the Australian National Training Authority and outlines the framework within which the Authority will operate. The absence of a national training board has been sorely felt in this country. It is our view that the establishment of ANTA is long overdue, as is a uniform and disciplined national training sector.

PARA.TAB: Australia's further education system reached crisis point this year when over 100,000 applicants for technical and further education courses missed out on places. Together with 48,000 unsuccessful applicants for university, these people created the largest bottleneck in our education system in history.

This year we have had the highest youth unemployment rates since the Second World War. In this climate of diminishing job opportunities and climbing poverty, secondary school retention rates have soared from 57 per cent in 1983 to 67 per cent in 1990, to 71 per cent in 1992, with expectation that these will reach 95 per cent by the turn of the century. The great shame has been that, while our youngest are better and brighter than ever before, we cannot secure employment for them, nor can we provide them with education or training opportunities.

Government outlays on education as a proportion of gross domestic product have plummeted by almost 10 per cent in the five years between 1984-85 and 1989-90, despite an increase in the GDP of 71 per cent. Our tertiary institutions are overflowing with undergraduates who have to contend with substandard conditions that include overcrowded lectures and tutorials and inadequate laboratory equipment which contravene occupational health and safety standards as well as a scarcity of library books and insufficient staff.

A feature of the education and training system this year has been the number of unsuccessful applicants for university who then applied for TAFE colleges in the desperate hope of gaining some formal qualification—often in an area that was not of particular interest to the student. With the abolition of entry-level jobs for many young people, formal training is often the only way of obtaining work.

The dangerous trap we are falling into, however, is that of producing thousands of graduates each year with little or no prospect of employment. The most recent ABS education attainment and labour force statistics show 59,400 unemployed young persons with a degree. Australia is fast becoming the most highly educated unemployed community in the world. For too long this country has lacked a coordinated national body designed to facilitate the training needs of all Australians. I hope that this legislation will fill that gap.

The decision to establish ANTA came hot on the heels of massive youth unemployment and was the main outcome of the Government's youth summit in July this year. The training debate has occupied centre stage for the past 18 months with a proliferation of reports and papers.

Unfortunately, earlier debate over training was characterised by blackmail and bluff. The threat of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to the States that they would lose responsibility for TAFE was tantamount to blackmail and made the Prime Minister look like he was riding roughshod over the States and their Ministers. Thankfully, the debate is now more structured and cooperation between the States and the Commonwealth, and between the Commonwealth and the industry sectors, is taking place. This Bill is an outworking of that process.

The Finn review in July 1991, chaired by Mr Brian Finn, Managing Director of IBM—who will head the ANTA board—established new targets for participation in schooling, and post-compulsory education and training. Following in these footsteps were the Mayer committee and the Carmichael report, which ensured that training matters remained central to Government policy.

Recommendations outlined in Carmichael's report focused on competency based training and the sponsorship of industry-education network committees at a regional level. Pivotal to the implementation of this plan will be the Australian National Training Authority. ANTA will act as an independent statutory body responsible for overseeing the emergence of a national training system in Australia.

ANTA will be assisted by the current private and State training networks such as the industry training advisory boards which will play an important role in this process. Membership of the board consists of a distinguished panel of representatives whose expertise and industry experience should serve this board well.

Industry has an exciting and vital role to play in the creation of flexible pathways in training and in employment. I am glad to see that ANTA will foster close industry involvement in the growth of a network of training providers. Although interaction between universities and industry has been heightened through technology transfer companies, research syndicates and science parks, in the words of Laurie Carmichael:

SPEECH.PARA: A substantial shift in industry towards ownership and responsibility for training and its recognition is needed in the workplace.

However, it is important that the needs of our training and education sectors are not usurped by those of industry. The Opposition has raised serious concerns about basing a national system of certification exclusively on industry standards. We share that concern.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats also consider flexibility within the TAFE system important in ensuring that the varying demands of enterprises within an industry are met. This does not, however, necessitate a fully decentralised TAFE sector. The Carmichael report envisages a simple structure of vocational training that promotes and enables progression from one level to another in all industries. This incorporates traineeships and apprenticeships but extends them to a much wider range of occupations.

ANTA will oversee the implementation of such a system and the industry led board will nurture a closer relationship between TAFE and industry in order to meet training needs into the next century. Rapid expansion of the TAFE sector should not be regarded by this Government as a simple solution to the high levels of unmet demand. Simple expansion of the TAFE sector is not a valid means of alleviating the effects of overcrowding, nor of diminishing the dole queues.

The Government has yet to grapple with the marked increase in university places and the lack of funds for those places. The solution centres on a target level of growth that is sustainable and ensures that those students undertaking further education are not working in substandard or unsafe environments.

Despite a marked increase in the interest in university between 1984 and 1990 for 15- to 19-year-olds—15 to 31 per cent—interest in TAFE has fallen from 22 to 12 per cent for 15- to 19-year-olds. It is interesting to evaluate the problems affecting the TAFE sector and why secondary school students prefer university as a post-compulsory option. This board must iron out existing anomalies amongst TAFE funding and course provision. ANTA must ensure the uniformity of TAFE courses and seek to avoid the problems that beset the college sector in the late 1980s.

There is growing recognition amongst education and training sectors and government that university is no longer the only post-compulsory schooling pathway. Many negative images about the TAFE sector need to be dispelled, which I hope the ANTA board will be involved in.

TAFE colleges are plagued by high levels of attrition and enrolments tend to be concentrated in short term courses which do not necessarily contribute towards long term acquisition of work skills. There are concerns that traditional TAFE clients such as those undertaking apprenticeships and traineeships and adult education students may suffer under a national training system.
We must be wary that TAFE colleges do not mirror the role of the colleges of advanced education in the middle level of higher education and the poorer cousin of universities.

Another issue confronting the tertiary sector is that of competency based training and the not inconsiderable tension between the standards of the professions and those of the work force. Educational institutions and professions have questioned the legitimacy of competency based training in the professions which, by tradition, are considered self-regulatory and strive for excellence, whereas competency based training standards define an acceptable minimum.

The decision of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) to make the implementation of competency based training within educational institutions optional is appropriate, given the disparity between the vocation and training sector and the universities. However, this issue requires further investigation. Along with competency based training, the development of more flexible education and training pathways will be underpinned by effective credit transfer arrangements. Industry sectors have identified concerns with existing credit transfer arrangements and I presume there will be a role for ANTA on this issue.

I understand the coalition's fears about ANTA becoming a bureaucratic nightmare, with the proposed funding arrangements by which State funds are pooled with ANTA and then channelled back to the States. In this scenario the States will maintain their training Budgets and the Commonwealth will be responsible for financing the growth in TAFE places. I also concede that the role of the Employment and Skills Formation Council needs closer analysis in relation to ANTA, given that there seems to be considerable overlap in the responsibilities of the two bodies. The needs of people from non-English speaking backgrounds and disabled people in a national vocational training system must be considered and ANTA must seek to ensure that all groups in the community are given equal opportunities.

The establishment of ANTA has not been without some controversy. The location of ANTA was a matter of debate for some months, with Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane vying for the Authority. Also, the future of as many as 180 public servants has been in doubt, as DEET staff are not allowed to follow their functions into the new Commonwealth-State Authority. All too often, Parliament is expected to rubber stamp the creation of a statutory authority without the implementation of a mechanism through which to scrutinise the workings of these bodies. At the committee stage, I will be keen to see the insertion of a clause that will enable the careful evaluation and scrutiny of this body. Regular monitoring of the board's actions and affairs should take place as a means to not only ensure accountability and effectiveness but also maintain a dynamic approach to industry and training needs in Australia.

I bring the Senate's attention to an advertisement which appeared in today's Australian Financial Review calling for a chief executive officer for the Australian National Training Authority. I note that at this time we are still only considering this legislation—we have not even passed it—yet we find that the Government has already taken it upon itself to advertise for the position of a chief executive officer. I put it to the Minister and to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the bureaucrats' taking it upon themselves to put an ad in the paper is a huge presumption on this Parliament that we are prepared to simply rubber stamp a piece of legislation and that we will simply pass this legislation without a great deal of comment.

Honourable senators would be aware that this legislation has now been referred to a Senate committee. As Senator Teague indicated, the Committee may choose to report some time in the new year although, as a member of that Committee, I would be a little nervous to consider this legislation for that long. I believe that there are some issues that need serious examination. It would be extremely embarrassing for the National Training Authority, or those bureaucrats responsible for its establishment, if that report were not to come down until some time in January. Yet advertisements have been put in national newspapers calling for a chief executive officer.

That is another example of the kind of arrogance we have come to expect from this Government on a whole range of education issues. This Government presumes that the Parliament will rubber stamp its decisions—rubber stamp yet another statutory authority—without proper scrutiny and without ensuring that all senators have a chance to have their say.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are correct.
—I thank Senator Teague. Yes, I am correct. It is not the first time that this has happened in respect of education and training issues.

PARA.TAB: In the Australian Democrats' blueprint for an ecologically sustainable and democratic future, Getting to Work, we consider vital to this future an education and training system that meets the needs of all Australians, regardless of sex, age, health, race, socio-economic background, racial or ethnic origin, or place of residence.

To this end, we support a publicly accessible and equitable education system. Fees and charges are a financial disincentive to enter and participate in higher education for disadvantaged groups in the community. Up-front charges, such as those supported by the coalition—and in some cases in postgraduate and non-award courses condoned by this Government—are unacceptable. Artificial barriers that determine entry into education and training on the basis of wealth and privilege have no place in our society.

The Democrats look forward to the creation of a diverse and flexible education system that will lead us into the twenty-first century. Education and training represent the best investment we can make in that future. It is no secret that a prosperous society is one that is well educated. The formation of skilled labour through the education system contributes to the economic development of the nation. I strongly support the establishment of the Authority but wish to see resolved some of the outstanding questions about its specific functions, its relations with other boards such as the Education and Skills Formation Council and its administration.

I do not suggest that the Australian National Training Authority will solve all our training needs, but in our belief it will go a long way towards identifying those needs in the present and into the future. I look forward to hearing the Opposition's concerns and examining some of its amendments when this legislation is put before the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training.

We support the second reading amendment that Senator Teague has circulated, as we do agree that the Prime Minister's statement that we are in a training emergency, after some 10 years of Labor Government, is an absolute outrage. It is an astonishing fact that the Government, after 10 years in office, has suddenly realised that training is an essential element of a competitive economy and an educated populace. We do have concerns about the excessively bureaucratic and centralist character of the ANTA board. We do believe that the Government is creating another layer of bureaucracy without sufficiently retiring some of the existing structures in the Education Department that overlap the functions being created here.

It is a very confusing time for employers; there is no doubt about that. There is a massive proliferation of schemes, labour market programs and training pathways. The jargon is very difficult for many employers to get their heads around. There is no question that there are many confused employers—and academics, I might add—who are finding that they cannot keep up with the debate. The debate is moving ahead very rapidly.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are right and Labor has failed the TAFE system.

—It certainly has; that is why we are supporting the second reading amendment. The confusion, complexity and uncertainty that has been created—not only by these current proposals, but also by the great shambles that is our training system in Australia—is tremendous. The Government needs to recognise that and to take responsibility for it. I commend the Bill to the Senate and indicate that we will be supporting the Opposition's second reading amendment.

—The Australian National Training Authority Bill 1992 and the Vocational Education and Training Funding Bill 1992 are designed to establish and fund the Government's new National Training Authority. This Authority, which will have responsibility for establishing a new national system of vocational education and training, is very much needed. The Authority is designed to report to the Council of Ministers concerned with the vocational education and training systems, comprising the Commonwealth and State Ministers in this policy area.

PARA.TAB: The Authority will advise the Council on a strategy plan for the development of vocational education. It will also have responsibility for determining whether the plans for the development of vocational education for each State fit in with the national plan. If they do, the States will be eligible to receive growth funding from the Commonwealth. If they do not, growth funding will be denied to those States.

The Opposition does not oppose this legislation. However, honourable senators should not think that the mere establishment of this Authority will, by itself, offer a satisfactory national system of vocational education and training. There is a huge task ahead of this nation in this area and a great deal of uncertainty and many unanswered questions still remain on how this particular Authority will operate. Very real dangers exist in the charter and framework being provided for this new body. The size of the task facing ANTA is all the greater because of the quite dramatic failure of this Government in its almost 10 years in office in pursuing policies which would lead to the development of a vocational education and training system of international standard.

The development of a national training framework for vocational education and training is essential. Employment opportunities and international competitiveness are dependent on the work force with skill levels of an international standard. However, it is crucial if this country is to have a national framework for vocational education and training that it should be appropriate.

This Government does not have a very good track record in terms of appropriate frameworks, particularly in the area of education. The Government has destroyed the colleges of advanced education that were flourishing in this country. These were institutions focused on high quality higher education. In doing so, Australia lost a number of institutions which had established strong regional links. The CAEs had also developed courses which were appropriate for the vocational needs of students in the region and tied in with particular local industries.

The Government started out with a very strong foundation in this area of vocational education with the policies of former coalition governments in the late 1970s and early 1980s. It threw this away and neglected the sector for the next 10 years. The result has been devastating.

This devastation was clearly pointed out in the Finn report, which pointed to the very serious deficiencies that young Australians are exhibiting in their job-related competencies. Quite simply, the Finn report concluded that there is overwhelming evidence that a very large number of young Australians are emerging from the schooling system with inadequate literacy and numeracy skills. This will not fit them for employment in internationally competitive industries and they may find themselves unable to get jobs at all.

The Carmichael report was produced by the Employment and Skills Formation Council to address the serious shortcomings of the 10 years of Labor neglect as outlined in the Finn review. The formation of ANTA is a direct result of these recommendations. The Opposition supports the concept of a national system of certification for training. However, we have very serious concerns over a system of certification that is to be based exclusively on industry standards. Where industry standards which are appropriate to all enterprises within an industry can be developed, such standards should be welcomed.

The driving force of national prosperity is not industry itself, but the enterprises that make up that industry. It is vital that the individual enterprises of this country are not trapped into training frameworks that force them to pay for training they do not need. They must also not be locked into training frameworks which discourage training innovation at the enterprise level.

One of the key questions regarding this legislation is: will the Authority be an effective vehicle for encouraging the development of a national training market responsive to the needs of industry, or will it become a new source of rigidity and bureaucracy in the training area? Enormous amounts of public money are already supporting the current bureaucracy. Currently, $15m is spent on industry training advisory bodies and there has been no evidence of improvement in the Government's handling of the vocational education and training sector as a result of this expenditure. In fact, it seems that the opposite has occurred as Labor has ignored this sector and now threatens to centralise it as it has done in the university sector. I refer there to the discredited national unified system. We do not want a repeat of that exercise.

It has to be seriously questioned whether the Australian National Training Authority will continue to develop a national training system. Will it be flexible enough to have an effective enterprise focus, or will it persist with the Government's approach of compulsory industry-based standards which may or may not be appropriate to the needs of enterprises?

This Bill also provides for the development of State training profiles. This is another area of serious concern. Each State is to give the Authority a profile of its training plans and if the Authority likes these plans it will provide the State with growth money. The system of profiles has failed completely at the university level. It is not an effective system for planning the university system and it is most unlikely to be an effective system for planning the future development and growth of the technical education area. Indeed, it is a system which has a real danger in it in that it will lock TAFE systems into a uniform framework when we need to see developments in the direction of greater flexibility.

We do need a national framework, but that framework should concentrate on providing for national certification, ensuring that it is flexible. Training should have an enterprise focus and excellence in programs for both public and private providers. The coalition acknowledges that there is a clear public responsibility for entry level general vocational training. However, that training must be appropriate to employment opportunities in industry and the training system must be closely linked and responsive to the needs of enterprises. The aim of skills training in particular should be to increase productivity and competitiveness and should be cost efficient for enterprises.

The coalition has set out in Fightback the principles that we believe are important for vocational education. Vocational education and training should be provided through a flexible and open training market with a variety of public and private providers. As far as possible government funding should be directed to people rather than to courses and institutions. This will maximise choice of provider to the person seeking training and avoid the problems which have arisen from centrally regulated and bureaucratic modes of provision. The appropriate national framework is one which provides national standards and national certification rather than one which seeks to detail central regulation of courses and providers.

TAFE must be flexible and responsive to the needs of local industry and be able to provide the training courses which industry requires. Structural reform of the TAFE system is essential to achieve greater autonomy in relation to staffing and conditions of employment, independence for college managements and the ability to charge fees where appropriate.

Following our jobs forum in July, the coalition gave further expression of these principles with a commitment to introduce training vouchers for employees on the youth training wage and for the long term unemployed, and a commitment of $945m to the expansion of vocational education and training over the period 1993-95. That is $225m above the Government's now failed One Nation commitment.

A coalition Government would require a body responsible for providing a framework of national standards and certification. It would also require a means of further developing the concept of the funding of vocational education through voucher mechanisms to strengthen the idea of a national training market.

The Australian National Training Authority as set up under this Bill would not meet our requirements. Therefore, although I do not oppose the Bill, I think the structure of ANTA and its operation needs to be watched very closely so that it does not become yet another instrument of government centralism and bureaucracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—We are dealing with the Australian National Training Authority Bill 1992 and the Vocational Education and Training Funding Bill 1992. I do not want to reiterate those things about which I think the Senate is essentially in agreement, but I think in discussing those things about which we are in disagreement we can too easily overlook the fact that we have here legislation to implement a major step forward, a very positive contribution to the Australian national training arrangements.

PARA.TAB: When the Opposition moves amendments to a Bill's second reading, one tends, in summing-up on behalf of the Government, to respond to negatives. However, I want first to make it clear that the most important part of this is the recognition that what we are implementing here is a major step forward, something that is very important for Australia now and into the future.

It is also important to recognise that the predominant responsibility for TAFE has always been with the States. This Bill is instituting a change in the balance of responsibility between the Commonwealth and the States for technical and further education. I think that is an appropriate move by the Commonwealth, but not one that has been easily made. It is in the nature of our Federation that such changes are often resisted. If they are going to be implemented on an agreed basis rather than through a process of confrontation, it often takes time and compromise. We often do not wind up with what would be the ideal model if we were proceeding under a unified system.

Having made these two opening remarks, I would like to respond briefly to the Opposition's amendment and to one issue that was raised by Senator Sowada. In response to the Opposition's amendment, the Government has been actively pursuing the goals of increased participation in post-compulsory education and its policies have seen significant improvements in school retention rates and a substantial growth in higher education places. These improvements have been accompanied by an active role in pursuing a national training reform agenda, the goals of which have included a significant expansion in both public and privately supported funding, the development of a competency-based rather than a time serve-based system, and the development of industry defined skill standards and national recognition of trainers and credentials.

The Government has also in its approach acknowledged, and acknowledges, the constitutional powers of the States in education and training, but it recognises as a parallel issue the need for a truly national and properly funded vocational education and training sector. The decision to establish the Australian National Training Authority is part of a broader agreement between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories to establish a national vocational education and training system with a secure funding base, a consistent national approach to planning, and an independent statutory authority to oversee the vocational education and training system, with a board of acknowledged experts and strong industry representation. The Authority will be responsible to a ministerial council of Commonwealth and State Ministers. Senator Teague referred to the voting arrangements. These reflect the Commonwealth-State agreement.

There are often problems, in my view, of proper accountability in bodies that are established through these Commonwealth-State agreements. It has been a long-standing problem. It is inherent in the nature of Federation. I think parliaments around Australia need to give this more attention. In fact, we are getting an international equivalent of that. As we get, for example, agreements with New Zealand in the area of tax and other areas we will find problems of accountability where we have ministerial councils making decisions. The starkest example and the greatest failure was the National Companies and Securities Commission. I do not mean that the Commission as a whole was a failure, though there was some criticism of that, but there was a very real problem of accountability. It was not really accountable to any parliament, and Senator Tate has made that point effectively in the Parliament on a number of occasions. It is obviously a less than perfect model, but it is inherent in the nature of federalism.

State training agencies will be responsible for the operation or management of vocational education and training. Industry input into the national system, especially through ANTA board membership and the role of the national industry training advisory body network, will help ensure the development of an effective training market. Industry will play a key role in the development of the national strategic plan and the State training profiles. There has already been very strong industry support for the national system and the establishment of the Australian National Training Authority. That is a factor that needs to be taken into account.
