I think it is important. It is not the decisive factor in isolation, but it is important.

I know that the Bill is going to a committee after its second reading, so most of the matters of detail can be dealt with there. However, I sought some facts to respond to the issue Senator Sowada raised concerning the advertisement for the chief executive officer. This fits in with the timing of the announcement of the board membership by the Minister. The Government has explained in the second reading speech the need for preliminary work to be undertaken before the national system starts on 1 January 1994, and therefore certain contingent initiatives are taken. Obviously if the Parliament were to deny the Bill a second reading and defeat it, those things would have to stop. It is standard; it has occurred with the establishment of most such bodies. We get an interim board or an interim chief executive to get the system up and running. Where that has not been done, the Government is criticised for being dilatory, for not proceeding with due enthusiasm and speed to implement the program.

It is in the nature of government that to be in government is to choose. When we choose, people complain because we did not choose the other option. Being in government may have its difficulties, but I continue to say that it is a hell of a lot better than the alternative, so it is a criticism I am prepared to wear. I think I would rather be criticised for acting too promptly than for not acting promptly enough; but obviously the decisions are contingent upon the final approval of the legislation by the Parliament. It is such a valuable and worthwhile proposal that I am sure it will be endorsed by the Parliament.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Pursuant to the order of the Senate agreed to on 12 November 1992, the Australian National Training Authority Bill 1992 stands referred to the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training for consideration and report by 7 December 1992.

PROCTEXT.PARA: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING BILL 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say—with a little indulgence, I hope, because I will be less than a minute—that it may be wise for the Government to take steps to see ANTA proceeding, if it is approved by the Parliament, on 1 March or 1 April. It is a very tough task for this Senate Committee to report back to us on 7 December on this important matter. Given that the State governments and the TAFE systems in the various States and Territories would need to be able to put views to the Senate Committee and that the Senate Committee would have to consider at least the doubts and the matters that are already on the public record or that have been referred to in the second reading debate, it would be hasty for us on 1 December to contemplate that in six days' time it would be possible for the Senate Committee to bring back a report.

PARA.TAB: I note that it may well be that the legislation will be delayed by a report from the Senate Committee coming back to us on our meeting in late February, if we meet then. It would be a great pity for the procedures of inquiry in the Senate committee system if there were such haste in the matter that has been referred to the Senate Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —With similar indulgence, perhaps I may stray slightly from the Standing Orders to respond to Senator Teague. Others will be dealing with the Bill in detail rather than me, but I urge the Committee to do everything in its power to proceed with it in accordance with the timetable as set down at the moment.

PARA.TAB: We tend to turn every problem we have into a crisis. I do not want to exaggerate, but it is important that we proceed with as much speed as we can to get this bedded down and agreed so that the processes can be got under way and the objectives, which I think are broadly shared, implemented as quickly as possible. The Committee can make its own decisions, but I hope it decides to proceed quickly and in accordance with the original timetable.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of that Committee, I take the points made by both Senator Teague and Senator McMullan. We will be mindful, I imagine, of the time constraints, or at least the urgency that the Government has placed upon this Bill, but that will certainly not restrict a close examination of the legislation. We will proceed with whatever haste the issue deserves.
—I can assure the Committee that the Chair is very indulgent this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator McMullan) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 15 October, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1992, which contains a number of proposed amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984. Some of these results, recommendations or amendments are from the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

PARA.TAB: There is a lot of delicious irony in this Bill. It puts the final nail in the coffin of some of the more bizarre provisions of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1992, which set out to ban all political advertising on radio and television 365 days of the year. That Bill was first mooted by one Mr Bob Hogg, who was the successor, I understand, of Senator McMullan in the Labor Party. The Bill was introduced at the beginning of last year. As I mentioned, the whole aim of the Bill was to prevent political advertising on radio and television 365 days of the year, during Federal elections, State elections and local government elections. It was the most atrocious attack on freedom of speech and freedom of political expression this country had ever seen.

In the process of getting that Bill supported, the Government wooed the Australian Democrats, who in those days were led by Senator Powell. It was apparent from the discussions we had with the Democrats of that time that the Government had in fact made a deal with the Democrats, and they were hell-bent on introducing this legislation.

To counter that, Dr Hewson organised a task force, which was chaired by our ex-colleague Senator Olsen, which did an extraordinarily good job in attracting attention around Australia to this heinous piece of legislation. I myself spoke to many groups, and I think the only people who opposed us were Phillip Adams and the ACTU, apart from the Labor Party and some sections of the Australian Democrats.

As a result of the antagonism to the provisions of that Bill, the Democrats used the apparent deal made between Senator Bolkus and Senator Powell to dispose of Senator Powell. It was generally expected that, as a result of that, the incoming leader, Senator Coulter, and his team would not have anything to do with this ridiculous attack on freedom of speech.

As it turned out, the Democrats were prepared to be bought, except the price was a little higher. One of the amendments proposed by the Democrats, which was part of the buying price, was that we were to have a brochure sent out to every elector in Australia, with a photograph and a CV of every candidate in both the House of Representatives and the Senate. Apart from the logistics of that little exercise, which could well have meant that the Electoral Commission would have to receive photographs, a CV, a brief description of policies—I think a 250 word description of policies—over a 21-day period, the cost to the taxpayer was a minimum of $3m. That was the figure given to me in Estimates by the Electoral Commission, but I often thought that if all the costs had been calculated, bearing in mind that this brochure would have had to go to some 10 million people, the cost would have been closer to a figure of between $5m and $10m. However, this was the cost extracted.

The Government is now removing that provision from the Bill, much to the gratification of the Australian taxpayer, and also to anyone who has any understanding of the electoral process. Apart from the logistical nightmare, this requirement to send out a brochure showing the names and policies of every candidate opened itself up to mischief which could have been created in the electoral process. This opened itself up not only to mischief in the form of single issue candidates offering silly things, but also to the fact that even the major parties could have run so-called independents on single issue items in order to pick up a few preferences, particularly in marginal seats.

The other bizarre opportunity arose for local tradesmen in relation to House of Representatives seats. For a small amount of money, one could imagine a local tradesman or the local butcher deciding to run, not really intent on getting into Parliament, but getting his brochure into the hands of every person in the electorate to say he was offering the cheapest meat or the best meat or whatever it might be. So it really was a stupid piece of legislation, and a very silly amendment moved by the Democrats, for which the Government itself was castigated, not only by those members of the public who were aware of what was going on, but subsequently by the High Court which found that the ban on advertising was invalid according to the Constitution.

I do not intend to speak at great length, but there are a couple of other items in the legislation that I would like to mention. The brochure that was to go out was aimed at promoting single issue interest groups. Indeed, one of the problems in recent years has been caused by minority groups who represent single issue constituencies within the electorate. It is worth considering the danger of some of those minor groups who can control the Parliament. There are at present three States where the parties now in power owe their existence to independents, namely, Western Australia, South Australia and New South Wales. The Democrats hold the balance of power in the Upper House in the latter two States. There is an argument that such independents provide a check on public policy or serve as the true representatives of the electorate without the need to actually toe the party line. We have all heard that story; it is phoney.

The problem with the approach is that despite the superficial attractiveness of that argument, minor parties and independents, by their very nature, tend to represent very narrow views. Often they tend to represent the views of a vocal lunatic minority, rather than the silent majority of voters out there who are responsible for electing whatever party into power. The policies favoured by their parliamentary representatives do not have to be tested against the bulk of public opinion. As a result, there is likely to be a trend towards supporting pressure groups at the expense of the greater good of society.

Both of the major parties, whatever their policy differences may be, are concerned with a much wider span of interests than the typical independent. The tyranny of the minority is the problem for many Australian parliaments at present. We all live in the real world. The upshot of the advent of a few independents holding the balance of power means that each of the parties must come to an understanding with them in order that the business of government and opposition can go on. I think that we should witness the agreements which the Fahey and Arnold governments have been forced to strike in order to govern, the fluidity of independent support of Dr Lawrence in Western Australia and the mixed-up policies of the Green Labor Alliance in Tasmania, now replaced, of course, by a Liberal Government in its own right. They just do not work.

No incumbent government likes dealing with minority interests in this way; neither do oppositions like negotiating with them. It is not a matter, as the Democrats have often said, of keeping the so-and-sos honest. It is a matter of extracting deals, and I do not think that is in the best interests of government in this country.

There is little hope of any independent or minor party policies ever coming into effect, given the control of the government over Supply in each case. The great beneficiaries are the candidates who find themselves with the national soap box and power well beyond their electoral mandate. I make the point that the situation is perpetuated when candidates are faced with a further test at the hands of the electorate. This was, I think, one of the major problems of the publicly funded guide. It could happen. It could add to a problem that already exists in this country which I believe is not by any means to the benefit of the economy or to the Australian public.

I have one small concern. I may well raise it here. The Government has added a further amendment which entails a penalty on anyone who advertises a voting form which is not in keeping with the requirements of the Electoral Act. For example, I understand that in some past elections—maybe it was in Victoria where this occurred—an advertisement was made which tried to convince people not to vote in the normal preferential fashion. The Government has introduced a penalty for anyone who does that by way of advertisement.

The only concern I have is that if a person does vote, for example, where there are four or five candidates, in the form of 1, 2, 2, 2 as an example, it is a formal vote, yet it is not in accordance with the Electoral Act as a method of voting. It is formal because the intent of the voter is recognised for what it is. So it is there to cover people who do not intentionally do that. The only concern I have is that by placing a penalty on those who would try to persuade others to vote that way is a penalty on something that is, in fact, a formal vote. Perhaps the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in his response might like to address that question.

In conclusion, let me say that the aspect of the Bill that removes the so-called free brochures, the brochures paid for by the taxpayer, is the final nail in the coffin of what was a most outrageous piece of legislation which sought to ban political advertising on radio and television and thus represented a most atrocious attack on freedom of speech and political advertising in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill is the usual omnibus-type Bill that we get at this time each year. I have been here long enough to see a couple of them. I guess the major proposal that I would be expected to comment on in the first instance is the proposal to scrap the candidate information booklet. I heard Senator Parer talking about how the Democrats were prepared to be bought, but the price was a little high. Had I been here, I would have asked that he withdraw that comment. That view is something that he continues to perpetuate. It is offensive.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer talked about the cost to the taxpayer. For Senator Parer's information, I would like to put on the record that the Opposition's advertising on television costs the taxpayers millions of dollars. We all end up paying for the cost of advertising, either through tax deductibility—that is how taxpayers end up paying it—or through packaging or whatever. Consumers end up paying the price of advertising. Senator Parer cost the taxpayers millions by introducing tax deductibility for political donations. He did not want it to be limited to $100; he wanted it to be any amount for companies. He had no concern about the cost to revenue of that little measure. So he should not be hypocritical about taxpayers money and the use of it.

I noticed, too, that Senator Parer said practically nothing about the provisions of this Bill except for this booklet. He revisited the political advertising debate and attempted to discredit minority parties and independents. I will just go on to try to deal with what is actually in this Bill but, before I do that, I need to give notice that the Australian Democrats will be opposing at the committee stage the relevant clause which repeals the candidate information booklet.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot keep your snout out of the trough.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, can I ask for that to be withdrawn?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Senator Parer, that was not—

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that not parliamentary to say that the Democrats—
—Yes, exactly. It does not need to be repeated; it needs to be withdrawn.
—I withdraw then.

—I think we should ask the question: what price do we put on a politically literate electorate? This has nothing to do, despite what Senator Parer thinks, with being bought for whatever price one wants to put on it. We happen to have a commitment to finding a way through the propaganda that blitzes our television screens during every election campaign. The electors of Australia have a right to basic facts about who is standing in each election.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, what a surprise to see Senator Kemp here. They have a right to those facts beyond the fearmongering, beyond the glitz and beyond the lies, because there is no truth in advertising applied to politicians in election campaigns. It is a great rule, that one.

—I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Is it in order for Senator Kemp to enter the chamber wearing a white ribbon, which is a symbol of his refusal to abuse women, and then immediately to indulge in that with Senator Kernot?
—There is no point of order.

—I think this is a gender neutral debate, although I go on to make a sexist comment and say that I think the combined actions of the Government and the Opposition in opposing the proposals for truth in advertising that have been put forward in this chamber are simply a matter of the vested interests keeping those sorts of things in election campaigns `in the club'—and it happens to be a predominantly male club.

PARA.TAB: Anyway, it is my contention that the candidate information booklet would have levelled the playing field to some extent. What is wrong with adults having a guide to allow them to compare candidates before they vote—no hype, no gimmicks; just a photograph and a small section from all candidates stating their policies? To the extent that there could have been some administrative problems—and I understand the Electoral Commission had some concern—I do not think that those problems or concerns were insuperable. We just did not have a chance to test them.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a lunatic proposal.
—Of course it is lunatic to attempt to give people propaganda-free information on which to make a decision; that is a really lunatic proposal!

PARA.TAB: The Bill will also allow an indicative distribution of second and later preferences for the House of Representatives seats on polling nights. This will attempt to ensure that the result of a general election will be known on polling night. This is permissive, not mandatory, and the exact details are set in concrete in this legislation. This matter has been considered extensively by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. It is the subject of a new interim report following the original report on the previous election and it makes suggestions for the coming election.

The issue of a notional distribution on a two-candidate preferred basis was agreed to by the Committee, with the two options being whether the distribution should be conducted and observed by polling officials, or whether it should be facilitated by polling officials and observed by scrutineers. A subsidiary question was whether this should occur in all divisions or simply in those considered to be potentially close. We have had exhaustive discussion on this in the Committee. We have found a balance that will meet the needs of those who have to communicate the information on election night and those who need to know the results as soon as they possibly can. Through negotiation we have found a reasonable solution.

The Bill also proposes to adopt a recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade that the Electoral Commission have its functions broadened to include providing assistance to foreign companies and organisations where this is approved by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. We support this. One of the great lessons that Australia can bring to this part of the world is that democracy does work: it is self-sustaining if it is properly nurtured. One of the prerequisites, of course, is the right to basic truthful information.

Whilst recent figures show that we are having trouble exporting enough of our goods and services to the rest of the world, we have a good opportunity to get behind the Australian Electoral Commission and to export some form of democracy in our geographical region. Cambodia is probably a relevant country to think of in the short term. There are many Asian countries which are fledgling democracies. To the extent that Australia can help to strengthen democracy by providing technical, administrative or any other type of assistance, we should do so.

The Electoral Commission will provide supplements to the electoral roll to sitting parliamentarians and parties by way of computer tape or disk, free of charge to sitting members or parties with representatives in Parliament. Cost recovery procedures will apply to information provided to other political parties or other persons. The use of information from the electoral roll and the habitation indexes is currently limited for privacy reasons and to ensure commercial misuse is not made of information. I will ask the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) a couple of questions about this at the committee stage. A consequential amendment extends these limitations to information provided by way of a computer tape or disk.

The issue of privacy is a vital one, and is becoming more so, given the information revolution and the sophistication of the major political parties in direct mailing techniques. The Bill also provides for a new system of automatic enrolment for new citizens to be introduced so that persons applying for citizenship may make a provisional claim for electoral enrolment, which would be activated when citizenship was granted. This is like the provisional enrolment for Australians turning 18 of years of age. It is a good idea. It reduces administrative duplication. It links citizenship and participation in the electoral process.

The Bill also provides for a strengthening of the recently enacted disclosure provisions. These provisions should continue to help to clean up the political process. They appear, along with the recession, to have contributed to a marked decline in contributions to Federal political parties. The statutory report concerning the disclosure provisions, which is tabled in this place, is broadened to include a list of the names of the persons who are, or may be, required to furnish a return showing donations to candidates or parties. This is an important provision because it makes this additional category of persons subject to the compliance investigations under the principal legislation. The recent disgraceful WA Inc Royal Commission findings—the findings were not disgraceful, but what they highlighted about what went on in Western Australia was—and the recent comments made by anti-corruption officials such at Ian Temby demonstrate the need for a system of full disclosure laws in all Australian jurisdictions. Even though the Commonwealth laws are now of a high standard, there are still jurisdictions which allow secrecy, and these can be used as conduits for secret and dubious donations. I ask the Minister to respond to the issue of what the Commonwealth is doing to get some uniformity from the various States in this area.

The current law allows the Electoral Commission to deregister a registered political party if it has endorsed a candidate previously but not for the previous four years. This leaves a loophole where a party can register a name, and hence stop another group from using that name, yet never have to run any candidates in any elections. The power of deregistration is to be extended where four years elapse and the party has never endorsed a candidate.

A review mechanism is to be established for the cancellation of `silent' elector status. Also, a voter with `silent' status who has nominated as a candidate will not be required to show his or her address on the nomination form. I think there are good reasons for doing that in many circumstances. The Electoral Commission will not need to advertise the receipt of an initial application for registration of a political party where the Commission initially determines that the application is defective and that the applicant refuses to vary the application. These and other housekeeping matters are straightforward but necessary. The Bill will eliminate the need to send a non-voter's notice to an elector who has already shown that he or she had a valid reason for failing to vote.

Finally, three matters concerning legal proceedings are also proposed. Firstly, the service of court processes is to be allowable by mail delivery instead of by direct service, as required by some State and Territory legislation. Secondly, where a person has been named on electoral material, for example as the authoriser, then that fact can be used as prima facie evidence in proceedings against the named person for an offence against the Electoral Act. This provision is necessary because criminal prosecution is currently very difficult, if not impossible, in respect of false how-to-vote cards because of the rules of evidence which apply in court proceedings.

I know of one instance where this provision would have been particularly useful. It might have been a telling factor in a case in which the Democrats were involved. In, I think it was, the 1987 election for the seat of Petrie, Queensland, a Liberal candidate, Mr Hodges, issued a bogus Democrat how-to-vote card, directly attempting to link that how-to-vote card with the direction of preferences to the Liberal candidate in Petrie. That matter has not been satisfactorily resolved as far as I am concerned. So I welcome this extra provision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe they didn't happen to have the grounds.

—They did have grounds. The third matter is an extension of the immunity granted to officers of the Electoral Commission. This new provision will enable officers to refuse to supply enrolment claim cards in response to a warrant issued under the Crimes Act 1914. As I say, much of this is necessary housekeeping. The booklet Repeal, of course is of great interest to us, and I will speak more about that in the committee stage when we oppose that clause. Other than that, we wish the Bill a speedy passage.
—Madam Acting Deputy President—
—You are not on the list, Senator Kemp.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—He is not on the list, but he is entitled to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am entitled to speak. I know it is always a problem with the Democrats that they wish to stop people from making comments in this chamber. I did not plan to speak but I wish to make some remarks in the light of the comments that were made by Senator Kernot. Senator Kernot drew our attention to her concern for the taxpayer. Her concern for the taxpayer relates to the fact that the Australian Democrats have a proposal that they put down in this Parliament that taxes be increased by over $7 billion in their alternative Budget. Some concern for the taxpayer! Senator Kernot was worried about the issue of tax deductibility and suggested a lack of concern on our part. I point out to her that the reason that clause was in this Bill was that it was actually the policy of the Australian Democrats. They had a policy that the first $100 of a contribution be tax deductible.
—You wanted it open; you wanted it unlimited.

—Just as a footnote to history, the interesting feature of this is that the Australian Democrats, when we drew this to their attention, did not even know that was their policy. Having had that brought to their attention, they then of course had to proceed with it. That is the history of that clause.

PARA.TAB: Truth in advertising was another matter Senator Kernot raised. I think all of us would strongly endorse the need for advertisements to be accurate and not misleading. I suggest that that applies not only to advertising but also to things like direct mail. Senator Kernot sent off a direct mail letter, if I recall correctly, to a large number of people in the agriculture machinery area in which she misleadingly quoted our policy.

So for her to stand up in this Parliament and lecture everybody else about the need to be truthful in advertising, I suggest, is worthy of comment. There is the old saying, `Physician, heal thyself', or, to paraphrase that, `Politician, heal thyself'. If Senator Kernot wishes to get up and talk about everybody else being truthful, she should make sure that her direct mail letters are entirely accurate. Then she will be slightly more credible on that front.

We still have the great dilemma, despite all the amendments which have been brought before us, that the trade union movement is in receipt of vast amounts of money from this Government and, at the same time, contributes to the Labor Party. Taxpayer funds go out to the trade union movement; the trade union movement contributes extensively to the Labor Party. The total amount of grants by this Labor Government to the trade union movement since Hawke came to office has been $15m and, in the last year, some $12m. It is a very big problem where we have a major interest group so closely allied with one political party in receipt of very substantial grants of taxpayer funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think we need to continue this catfight that Senator Kemp has managed to drag the debate into other than to make one point which needs to be made. We on this side of the Parliament—I think I could say that the Democrats subscribe to this as well—do not take the attitude that anyone who does not support us we will criticise, condemn, rape, pillage or whatever. We accept criticism of our policies and our position. At the same time, we recognise that there are groups in this community who for different purposes need assistance in funding. More often than not they are community based organisations and without government assistance they are not in a position to pursue the voice of their members and the people they represent. We make no bones about the fact that we think it is the role of government to assist those organisations in pursuing the voice of the people they represent.

PARA.TAB: In recent days we have seen, for instance, the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations being condemned and criticised by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ninety five per cent funding by the Labor Party.

—It was tarnished; it was accused of being in the pocket of the Government because it gets funding from the Government. It has always had funding from the government. In fact, its first dose of big funding from the government came under the Fraser Government, although there had been grants before that. It had continued to be supported by conservative governments, governments which at that time were prepared to cop criticism from this organisation. As a government, we have been criticised by this organisation probably as much as we have been thanked by it. Being a former Minister for Consumer Affairs, I was the butt of some of its criticisms. But that did not lead us on this side of the Parliament to stop its funding. Nor should it in any democracy lead to any government stopping the funding of organisations which, firstly, are in need of assistance and which, secondly, are critical to the political process.

PARA.TAB: So whether it is the unions and the functions they perform, consumer organisations, churches, the local bike riders or whatever, we are used to Senator Kemp's side of politics condemning them in a defence of its `Knockback' policy. We will support them in the interests of debate in this community.

A couple of points need to be responded to before we go to the committee stage. The first one is in respect of the candidate information booklet. I do not need to debate this at any great length other than to say that the booklet was proposed as a way of compensating for the absence of political advertising at the time the final Bill went through the Senate. Since the High Court decided to rewrite the rules of the game in this area and since political advertising has now been allowed to continue, the Government felt that there was no need to keep in place a mechanism to compensate for the absence of political advertising. As a consequence of that, we are rescinding that part of the legislation.

Senator Parer raised a question in which I am sure he delighted in raising: the question in respect to the provision that we are proposing which will make it illegal for people to persuade electors to use an optional preferential vote. The question is: are we not penalising people for advocating that people vote formally? I suppose that is what Senator Parer is asking. The response to that is that under the Act as it now stands we have in place what can best be termed a savings clause, which will ensure that those who have made a mistake on their ballot paper do not have their votes discarded because of an unintentional mistake. In those circumstances, we are talking about people who vote 1, 2, and then may vote for three candidates with a number 3 or for two candidates with a number 3 and next one with a number 5. That provision is basically there to ensure that people do not unintentionally vote informally in this circumstance. The legislation also ensures that we do not have an optional preferential system. Unlike some State legislatures, Federal Parliament has decided not to adopt that system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not a bad idea though, is it?

—I am not convinced of it. But whether I am convinced or not is quite academic in this instance because what I am referring to is the legislation, section 270 of the Act, which says that we do not have an optional preferential voting system. What we are doing by our amendment is ensuring that people do not go out and intentionally frustrate the will of this Parliament by advocating an optional preferential system. So, to an extent, what Senator Parer is saying may have some validity; but in the context of the legislation and the theory behind it—legislation which does not accept optional preferential voting—what we are saying by our amendment is that those who were out there campaigning in the 1987 and the 1990 elections to frustrate the will of the Parliament by advocating what is in essence an optional preferential vote, should not be allowed to continue to do that. If there are any other points that need to be raised in respect to this debate, we will have them in the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot, I think you had something to mention in relation to one clause.
—I want to oppose clause 24.
—The question is that clause 24 stand as printed.

—I oppose the repeal of the candidate booklet. I have already cited the reasons for doing so, but I will repeat them. It is not good enough to say that because we have now reverted to full-on political advertising we no longer need basic information. We probably need more than ever basic, propaganda-free, non-glitzy information in each household so that people can simply read who a candidate is, a basic statement of that candidate's policy and a few details about the candidate. People can then make a decision based on that information and ignore or listen to the rest of the propagandist advertising that they will be subjected to for the whole election campaign.

PARA.TAB: This is a basic right, especially if $17m is to be spent on a barrage of advertising, the likes of which we have seen and know will become more and more like the American excesses. Ordinary citizens have to have some defence in the truthfulness of this basic information. I do not agree with Senator Parer that this system could be rorted easily. I do not believe that it would be. I do not believe that the administrative problems were sufficient to say that it was not worth trialing. I would like us to have trialled it and to have asked Australian voters what they thought about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question for the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus). I would very much like to hear from the Minister the reasons that the Government is proposing for the repeal of this provision. I remind the Committee that this provision, which is to provide factual information to voters about candidates, previously had the support of the Government. I would have thought that that process would be more supportive of democracy in this country than relying, as is now the case, upon a splurge of propaganda, particularly by the major parties. I simply want the Minister to explain to the Committee why this provision should be repealed.

—On behalf of the Liberal and National parties, I indicate that we will be supporting this. I spelt out in some detail the reasons for doing so during my speech on the second reading debate. But let me make this comment.
—Warwick, I was asking the Minister.

—I am not responding to Senator Harradine; I am responding to the earlier remarks of Senator Kernot. The Minister will sum up after we have made our comments, so I will leave it to him to make his response. One modern form of campaigning is direct mail campaigns. A concern people have is whether they will be flooded with stacks and stacks of information and, under this provision, to have more added to it at taxpayer expense. We opposed this idea in the first place because we believed that it was an abuse of taxpayers' money.
—You imposed tax deductibility for political donations.

—In her speech on the second reading debate, Senator Kernot mentioned tax deductibility for the membership of political parties or donations up to $100. When I interjected that she and I knew that we did that because we were opposed to public funding, she would not pick up the interjection. That is not honest. I have to respond now to her interjection on that point in order to put the record straight.

PARA.TAB: I repeat that the Liberal-National parties were opposed to this proposal in the first place because we thought that it was a ratbag notion. If my memory is correct, there were about 100-odd amendments to the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. The debate went on for some 20-odd hours. The Government agreed to the Australian Democrat amendments—that was one of them—in an effort to get through the Bill. Senator Kernot and the coalition made the remark at the time that the logistics of this move would be almost impossible for the Electoral Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true.

—Senator Kernot is shaking her head and saying, `Not true'. She knows, as do I, that the Electoral Commission, if asked, will not give a statement. I have also asked this of members of the Electoral Commission. One does not have to listen to what they say; one just has to see the looks on their faces to be given an answer. This is a most ridiculous provision and it opens itself up to attack. It would have been a free kick to people who had no feet on the ground and no support groups. It would have enabled them, at taxpayer expense, to campaign about loony, single issue items that Senator Kernot would know about. I would not say the same about Senator Harradine, who is a different person altogether.
—Thanks a lot. That is really offensive.

—Just because I praise Senator Harradine, the Australian Democrats say that it is offensive. That is marvellous. We will support this, for the reasons given earlier in my speech on the second reading debate. At the time of the debate in December last year, we opposed it for all the good reasons that it is now being withdrawn.

—I want to set the record straight. I cannot let the comments of Senator Parer stand unchallenged. The Opposition wants to have it both ways. It is piously opposed to public funding but will take every cent of it—thank you very much—and not send a single cent back. You say that you are opposed to public funding, but you will take it all anyway; and you have tax deductibility as well.
—While you are at it, Senator Kernot, can you make your comments through the chair?

—Yes, Mr Chairman. I will say it all again, if you like. The Opposition likes to have it both ways. It says very piously that it is opposed to public funding, but it takes every last cent at every election. The point is that it does not decline the offer. So it has public funding and, since we passed the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill in December last year, it also has tax deductibility on the membership of political parties and donations of up to $100. So it really is a bit hypocritical to have it both ways and then to criticise others in the way that it does.

—Senator Kernot knows the reasons behind the arguments. She is trying to pretend otherwise. We are not stupid. If public funding is available, anyone who does not take it is out of his or her brain. It does not mean that, from a policy point of view, we are opposed to it. We pushed for tax deductibility because we believe that donations to political parties should be fair and equitable. Everyone, including Senator Bolkus and Senator Kernot, is aware of this.

PARA.TAB: Our concern was that there was a gross inequity because the major funding of the Australian Labor Party comes from the trade union movement. The ALP gets its money from affiliation fees to the trade union movement, which in turn gets it in the form of tax deductible donations. In addition, all income earned by the trade unions, irrespective of whether they run the casino on the Gold Coast or have properties in the CBDs of Sydney, Melbourne or Adelaide, is tax-free. That means that the ALP gets the benefit of affiliation fees coming from tax-free monies as well as any income that might be earned by the trade unions from tax-free monies. To make tax free the $100, which would enable those individuals to contribute to parties, including the Labor Party, reduces albeit in a minor way the inequity that already exists.

TALK.START.PARA: —After hearing the remarks of Senator Parer, I have decided to speak. For a decade now, it has been a remarkable case of hypocrisy by the Liberal Party to argue on every occasion it gets that it is opposed to public funding. But when an election comes around it is first to go to the Electoral Commission to collect the cheques to pay for the election campaign.

PARA.TAB: If this was the moral issue that the Opposition claims it is—if public funding is so immoral—I would have thought it would have had the guts to announce that it was going to accept the money. But not on your nelly! Now we have the diversion of an attack on the trade union movement and the contributions to the Labor Party.

At one stage it was rumoured that the Liberal Party wanted to amend legislation to make it more difficult for trade unions to make a contribution to the Labor Party, either by affiliation fees or by donations. Under the arbitration Act all registered trade unions have to declare such donations in their annual financial reports. They have been publicly disclosed for decades. But the Liberal Party, which has lived on the donations from the business sector and from public companies, has never sought to vote to force companies to declare in their annual reports the donations that are made to political parties, including itself.

I would find it less hypocritical and a little more substantial for Senator Parer and the Liberal Party to argue their case in attacking the trade union contributions if they were willing to argue that the Companies Act ought to be amended so that it is compulsory to disclose donations to political parties—as trade unions have to—in their annual reports. But not a whisper, not a word.

Senator Parer suggested that there ought to be ballots of trade union members before a union can make a contribution to the Labor Party or affiliate with it. I have never seen anybody in the Liberal Party put up a proposal that there ought to be a ballot of all shareholders in a public company before a donation can be made. Senator Parer knows full well, as does the Liberal Party, that if such a proposal were to be put up, shareholders would overwhelmingly vote it down and they would not get any money.

In all of this endless debate from the Liberal Party, there would be a much more substantial case if it moved amendments to the Companies Act to make it compulsory for directors to disclose donations made in the annual report and to call on all shareholders to vote at the annual meeting as to whether they agree that donations should be made to any political party. Until it does that, it is running an absolutely hypocritical case. It is part of its campaign to smear and attack the trade union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call any more honourable senators, I remind the Committee that the question before the chair is that clause 24 stand as printed. Clause 24 deals with particulars of candidates. It does not have anything to do with donations to political parties. I would ask honourable senators who are going to make a contribution to be relevant to the matter before the Chair.
—I would like to comment very briefly on Senator Schacht's remarks and relate it back.
—You can't.

—I can relate it back very easily. We talked about a booklet being provided at taxpayers' expense. Senator Kernot then raised other issues. The point I made was not a criticism; it was a statement of fact. We are realistic. It is just a matter of being realistic and recognising the fact that the ALP receives its money in the main from the trade union movement because one is the industrial arm of the Party and the other is the political arm of the Party.
—As far as I can see, you are out of order.
—Mr Chairman, I think it is a matter of responding to remarks made by Senator Schacht with regard to what was tax deductible or what was at taxpayers' expense.
—There is nothing about tax deductibility in section 386A.

—I make the point that the brochure, which is now being withdrawn under this section, was being provided at taxpayers' expense. Senator Schacht seemed to show an extraordinary amount of sensitivity because somehow he was ashamed that we were making the remark that there was inequity. I talked about the inequity of tax deductibility as it occurred. All that I was doing, in responding to Senator Kernot, was saying that we were trying to address the inequity that currently exists because of funding of non-Labor political parties. I make that explanation, and I think it should be put on the record.
—It is on the record, but I am not sure whether it is on the record properly.

—I think the only point made in the last half an hour that I need to respond to is Senator Harradine's. The justification for the Government's action is that when we initially embraced this proposal, it was in the context of the ban on radio and TV of political advertising at election time. We felt that it was quite justified in those circumstances to compensate for the `information' that people may not have been getting by embracing this concept of the booklet.

PARA.TAB: We felt that it was a legitimate use of funds and that it could have been done logistically. We took some time to analyse it and work it out, but we could have done it, and it would have cost some $3m all up. As Senator Harradine knows, the High Court intervened a couple of months ago and reinstated the right to broadcast political advertisements at election time. We felt that, in the context of that being restored to the process, our initial justification for the booklet had dissipated. As a consequence, we have taken this step to rescind the provision in the Act that would provide for the booklet.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could read but they could not hear or see.

—I would not draw that sort of bow. That is the justification. I could go into it in depth and we could have an argument about it across the chamber, but the Government felt that the initial justification for the booklet had dissipated with the High Court decision.

PARA.TAB: We have always taken the view on this side—and not just us on this side; I think the view has been taken extensively across the world—that public funding such as this, and public funding in general, is a legitimate action of government for the political process. Particularly at a time when there is greater disclosure legislation, as we have now, and when there is greater pressure on people who donate to stand up in the sunlight when they do so, governments do play a role in ensuring that the political process can be sustained by measures such as public funding.

I will finish on a point in respect of public funding. I am one of those who have long held the view—and it was part of the initial legislation—that the mechanisms in place for public funding are somewhat outdated. We need to move to another mechanism; for instance, a CPI adjustment based on a basket of campaigning methodologies, rather than a CPI as it applies across the community. But what we should have done in the first place was to have linked adjustments in the levels of public funding to a basket of campaign methodologies. Maybe in the not too distant future the Parliament will embrace that concept.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senate and Reps will be the same.

—The initial concept was that we have the same level of funding for Senate and House of Representatives votes. But, as Senator Kernot knows, that was withdrawn in the course of the debate on the Bill in which this booklet found its birth.

—The Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) made a very interesting comment about adjustments in the level of public funding being linked to a basket of methodologies. That interesting question has been considered by the ABS in respect of other areas. For example, there is a great concern amongst retirees that, for a number of reasons, the CPI adjustment is not an adequate arrangement so far as their circumstances are concerned. Mr Chairman, I would be out of order if I went into this matter any further. However, the Minister has raised a very interesting question.

PARA.TAB: I asked the Minister why the Government had reversed its support for a leaflet briefly detailing the policies of a candidate going out to each elector. The reason the Minister has given is the High Court decision in respect of political broadcasting. Political advertising was not prevented by the political broadcasting legislation. In fact, it was provided for in the legislation which was overturned by the High Court. The two major parties were to get a certain amount of equal free time and the remainder was to be divided up between minor parties and Independents.

The High Court threw out that type of political advertising and left open the adoption of other types of political advertising, such as paid political advertising. We will now have paid political advertising. To be quite frank, it is just not logical for the Minister to say that, because of the High Court's decision, the Government is not going to support the distribution of a leaflet.

My concern has been expressed by Senator Kernot. At the next election we will have a return to a presidential-style campaign between Paul Keating and John Hewson. The electorate will be bombarded by highly paid, slick political advertising from both sides, ultimately funded substantially by the taxpayer and much of it not going to the crucial issues which face the electorate in various areas.

Distributing a leaflet outlining policies in respect of various areas of concern has merit in that it would enable electors to sit down, study them and come to a conclusion. Many of them may not study it.

TALK.START.PARA: —How would the Electoral Commission check what was put in by the candidate to it for publication? The Electoral Commission would have to rely on the information coming from the candidate.
—That is correct.
—Which they could not do without checking it out.
—They would need to check it, I suppose. As to the person's bona fides?
—It is all right for you, but there would be some people who would be mischievous and who would put all sorts of things.

—They may do. If they do put all sorts of things in it, I suggest that the electors might take the appropriate steps and not vote for them. I might also say, perhaps as a frivolous aside, that Senator Parer referred to the faces of the Electoral Commission officers. I thought Electoral Commission officers should maintain a poker face on all matters.

PARA.TAB: In my long experience on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, the officers have put in submissions in respect of these questions over the years. I might be wrong—and the Minister can correct me if I am wrong—but I have not heard of a submission that they have made in respect of this matter. The Minister might tell the Committee whether the Electoral Commission has made a substantial submission to the Government in respect of the provision to each elector of a document setting out the policies of a particular candidate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My position, and the Government's, is that we think the justification for the booklet dissipated with the High Court decision and the reintroduction of radio and television political advertisements. Senator Harradine and the Democrats take a view that there is still a need for it. It is a matter of judgment. I do not think that by debating it we will come to a common position.

PARA.TAB: In respect of Senator Harradine's second point as to whether there was a submission, my advice is that there probably was not a substantial one and that we had the Commission address the mechanics of how to do it. Obviously, a lot of problems were raised in that context. There is no recollection of there being a substantial submission. If there were one, I would be very surprised if it was in support of the proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to facilitate this process. I am going to call a division on this clause. I do not know whether it would be preferable to take all the questions on the other clauses first.
—We specifically called on clause 24. I would like to deal with clause 24 now.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the clause be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask a couple of questions of the Minister concerning clause 22 which amends section 274 of the principal Act.
—There are new amendments.
—I am referring to the Bill on page 9, line 29, clause 22 amending section 274. Is that the one we are dealing with?
—It has been amended by clause 22A.
—I do not have a copy of that.
—Senator Schacht, could you please ask your question?
—The clause in the Bill I have before me concerns the direction given to conduct an indicative preference count on the night of the ballot. The Bill I have states in clause 22:

SPEECH.PARA: (2A) Each Assistant Returning Officer must, if the Australian Electoral Officer for the State or Territory that includes the relevant Division so directs in writing, also:
(a)conduct a scrutiny of such preferences (other than first preferences), on such of the ballot-papers, as are required by the direction; and
(b)transmit to the Divisional Returning Officer any information required by the direction; . . .

I ask the Minister, if that is as it still stands—and I have not seen the subsequent document being circulated—does the Australian electoral officer for each State or Territory have discretion to give or not to give a direction to the assistant returning officer in each polling booth about carrying out the indicative count of the preferences?

PARA.TAB: I raise this matter because of the extraordinary circumstances in Kingston during the last election where all the pre-election polls showed the Democrats on about 30 per cent, the Labor Party on about 30 per cent and the Liberal Party on about 30 per cent. It was going to be split very close either way and clearly the result could have gone any way between the three candidates. I rang the Commonwealth Electoral Officer for Australia to ask whether he would give an indication to the returning officers in each polling booth that on the night, at the request of the scrutineers, they should count the two-party preferred vote, so that we would get a much clearer idea of the result from all the booths at the close of counting.

After a 40-minute conversation with the Commonwealth Electoral Officer for Australia, I came to the conclusion that he did not have a clue what I was talking about—this idea of counting preferences to get the two-party preferred vote—because he started quoting all sorts of sections of the Act saying that this could not be done and so on. I pointed out to him that informally it had been going on in polling booths for at least the last 20 or 30 years. I came to the conclusion that either he did not understand the Act or he was thick, or both. In the end, I was told that the Act was very complicated and that my informal request could not be acceded to. I understand that other members of parliament made similar requests for other electorates and they were all turned down. This led to the recommendation coming from the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters with which we are now dealing.

I read in the Bill that, if the Australian electoral officer for each State or Territory decides not to direct, an indicative preference count cannot take place. By putting in an application to the Australian electoral officer for each State or Territory, does that automatically mean that the direction is given? We could still run into the situation where the electoral officer for each State may refuse a request from a member of the public or a political party that the preferences on a two-party preferred basis are not counted by the end of the night in each polling booth. So the intent of what we are all after could still be thwarted by a recalcitrant Commonwealth electoral officer in each State not following the request. I wonder whether the Minister could respond to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht raises questions which are in fact covered by the amendments to the amendments. There is a provision under the fourth amendment of the amendments moved on behalf of the Government which ensures that during a scrutiny:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the scrutineers must be allowed to inspect, in addition to the preference votes being counted in the scrutiny, any other preference vote given for a candidate unless, in the opinion of the Assistant Returning Officer or DRO, as the case may be, this may unreasonably delay the scrutiny.

The words `unreasonably delay' are there to ensure that the delay is not excessive. Where representatives of candidates are there as scrutineers and want to inspect the votes, they will be given the opportunity to do so as long as it does not mean that by giving the extra time to the scrutineers it will take all night long to count the vote.

PARA.TAB: The point that goes directly to Senator Schacht's question is the fifth amendment. One does not need to apply to get this count through. The amendment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: If, in a House of Representatives election, there are more than 2 candidates for a Division, the Australian Electoral Officer for a State or Territory that includes the Division must, in writing, direct the Assistant Returning Officers—
and so on—to:
. . . provide an indication of which candidate is most likely to be elected for the Division.
That amendment will achieve what Senator Schacht is seeking. We will not have to go through the process of either himself or the candidate having to apply for that count to be made on the night.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could ask one further technical question now that I have the further amendments which cover practically all my points of concern, amendment No. 5 states at the end, `will provide an indication of which candidate is most likely to be elected for the Division'. When dealing with situations such as that which occurred at the last election in the electorate of Kingston or in Queensland electorates where the Liberal-National Party and the Labor Party are both getting, say, 30 per cent of the vote each and it is very hard to tell which party will finally emerge as the two-party preferred winning candidate, does this mean that the electoral officer will also count a two-party preferred vote of Labor versus Liberal or Labor versus National Party or National Party versus Liberal Party? Does the amendment cover that possibility? Even though it will take longer to do, will the two-party preferred be counted the right way so that one knows on the night who will ultimately be the two final candidates and not just counted out thinking that it will be Labor versus Liberal when in fact it is a Liberal versus National Party result?

—The reason why I went to both provisions when I initially answered Senator Schacht's question was that, in that context, the capacity and the opportunity for the scrutineers to count and to inspect the second preference votes of other candidates is important. For instance, if we take the seat of Kennedy, where there is a massive number of outlying polling booths, Kennedy would be treated in the same way as other seats. On the night, the Electoral Commissioner, or his delegate, will decide which are the two candidates that he thinks will survive through the count. The returning officers will be asked to transmit the votes for those candidates through to the central tally room for that electorate.

PARA.TAB: If, for instance, during the course of the ballot on that evening they find that they have the Liberal instead of the National candidate as one of the two to whom preferences are to be distributed, then it may be very difficult to get a complete recount on that evening. But, in order to ensure that there is some certainty available at an early time during the count, we have put in place that amendment that I previously mentioned to give scrutineers the opportunity to go through and look at where the preference votes are going so that there can be some degree of certainty by the end of the night as to who might win the seat. The honourable senator does raise a problem which we anticipate we can overcome, but there may be circumstances in which it might be just too difficult.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one amendment but I also have a couple of questions so I would like to ask those first. The first one relates to clause 22A, which deals with precluding an optional preferential vote. It is still possible to get around this, is it not, because this only applies during an election period? It is the same argument as for the advertising. For the rest of the year, somebody could write a book, run courses, do whatever they like. I think that loophole exists.

—For the interests of Senator Harradine and others, the reason why we are adopting this approach is form. We are adopting this approach because it is consistent with other offences in the Act. In respect of other offences, we do limit it in many circumstances to the election period.
—Will there be a reprint of the Electoral Act available before the next election and after this Bill is passed?

—My advice is that it is very much in the hands of the Attorney-General's Department to do so, but I will undertake to write to the Attorney-General and see whether we can give some precedence to it. Given the changes we have had over the last couple of years, I, like Senator Kernot, believe that there should be a reprint available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is very important in the election period to have that at hand.

PARA.TAB: I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.After clause 19, page 9, add the following clause:
"19A. After section 180 of the Principal Act, the following section is inserted:
`180A.(l) Where the relevant authority is satisfied that:
(a) a person who was an employee:

TAB.TAB: (i)resigned in order to become a candidate for election as a member of a House of the Parliament of the Commonwealth or of a State, of the Legislative Assembly for the Australian Capital Territory, of the Legislative Assembly for the Northern Territory or of a prescribed legislative or advisory body for another Territory;
(ii)was a candidate at the election; and
(iii)failed to be elected; and

PARA.TAB: (b)the resignation took effect not earlier than 6 months before the date on which nominations for the election closed;

SPEECH.PARA: the relevant authority must, upon application by the person within 2 months after the declaration of the result of the election, employ the person in the same or a similar capacity with the same rate of pay as that payable to the person immediately before resigning.

PARA.TAB: (2)In this section, "relevant authority" means:
(a)the Australian Public Service;
(b)any other office or body (including the Australian Defence Force) established by or under Commonwealth legislation;
(c)the public service of a State or Territory;
(d)any other office or body established by or under State or Territory legislation; or
(e)any other office or body that is prescribed.'.

The thrust of this amendment is simply to guarantee the reinstatement of public servants who have had to resign in order to contest an election. It goes to the heart of the Cleary case. It goes to the heart of history in Queensland, where, in Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen's days, teachers in particular were unlikely in many instances to get their job back. I understand the Government has some problems with this amendment, but it is important to get on the record the view that this Government should take steps to rectify the situation that Mr Phil Cleary and other candidates who work in the Public Service find themselves faced with every time they contemplate standing for an election. We need the best people standing for election in this country and we do not need discriminatory legislation which means that public servants rule themselves out of candidacy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot is talking very much to a responsive audience. When I first stood for the Senate and got elected in September 1980, I had to resign a position I had before nominating. Unfortunately, in my case, it was not a matter of being elected one day and taking up a position the next. I did not take my place in the Senate until 1 July the next year, so I had some nine months of so where I could not work. So I understand the problems—
—You could have got a job in private enterprise during that period.

—It does raise a question as to whether one should, for instance, work in private enterprise. I felt that it was best for me not to do that given that I had been elected as a Labor candidate and people knew where I had come from and where I had been working. But Senator Crichton-Browne is right; I could have worked there. I could even have taken the dole, but that may have caused all sorts of other problems under the Constitution. So I understand the problems. I do not, however, appreciate the press statement Senator Kernot put out saying that Cleary should not happen again. I do not know what the Democrats have against Phil Cleary that they insist that he should not happen again! Unlike Peter Reith, I do not take the same attitude to Phil Cleary.

PARA.TAB: As to Senator Kernot's amendment, sympathetic though the Government might be to the principle that the Democrats are pursuing, that principle being that public servants should not be unfairly discriminated against in being able to stand for parliament, the Democrats are attempting to introduce provisions that apply in Federal legislation in respect of State and Territory parliaments and candidates for State and Territory elections.

The advice I have is that it would be beyond the Commonwealth's constitutional power to apply through this legislation provisions to govern State legislatures and candidates for State legislatures. Sympathetic as I am to the principle, we have had enough instances of playing Russian roulette with the High Court in respect of electoral legislation in recent days. I suggest that, instead of Senator Kernot pursuing the Democrats' amendment this afternoon in this process, she allow me to have the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) raise this matter for discussion between State and Federal Attorneys with a view to uniformity in approach in respect of all legislatures, State and Territory and, of course, the Commonwealth, which has its in place already. I think the best way to go would be for the States to make amendments to go as far as we have in respect of their parliaments and the election processes of their parliaments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on behalf of the Liberal and National parties that we have sympathy with the intent of the amendment. Senator Bolkus gave an example, and I thought I would give my own. It might be of interest that, prior to coming into this place, I was Deputy Chairman of the Queensland Institute of Technology, which is now the Queensland University of Technology.
—Doesn't anybody work for himself?

—It was a totally honorary position, totally unpaid. The view was expressed to me by Sir William Knox, a well-known expert in his field, that I may come under the ambit of profit under the Crown. So prior to my being appointed by the State of Queensland I resigned from that position. At the time I felt that it was a fairly silly law. However, having said that, I agree with the comments made by Senator Bolkus. If there is some possibility of constitutional problems, his proposal to refer the whole matter to the State and Federal Attorneys-General is perhaps the route we should be taking.

—I agree with the comments that have been made, but the Constitution is quite clear. I myself was in a situation in 1975 when I had to decide whether or not to resign from certain boards. For example, the wages boards at that time had an honorarium, although a very minor one. So I resigned from those. I did not resign from the Library Board because I did not think that was an office of profit under the Crown. The Government of the day looked at various options when I was elected as Secretary of the TTLC 10 years before that.

PARA.TAB: The Secretary of the TTLC was always appointed to a paying board, normally the Hydro Electric Commission. The position of Secretary of the TTLC was a very poorly paid job. But I had had a barney with the Government of the day and it looked around for the only non-paying board to which to appoint me, and that was the Library Board. There was no remuneration involved—although I suppose it was an office of profit under the Crown in that we had a convivial drink after each monthly board meeting! But, there again, that was a problem. A year after I resigned finally some questions were raised in the Parliament about 24 dozen bottles of beer being consumed by the Library Board. I knew that I was the only member of the Library Board who actually drank beer, and I knew that I had not disposed of 24 dozen bottles of beer in a period of 12 months over 12 sittings—only half a dozen or whatever. The whereabouts of those bottles I think remains a mystery. Nevertheless, the point is that I chose not to resign from that board before standing for election because I considered it not an office of profit.

As you, Mr Chairman, will remember, this matter has had a canter around the course of this chamber over many years. I think the case of Jim Webster was in vogue shortly after we came to this chamber. It is a very interesting area, and I think the best way to approach it is to refer the matter to the Attorneys-General so that some further consideration can be given to it in order to come up with a reasonable solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to accept the Minister's offer. I am happy to have the Attorneys-General look at the matter, but I say to the Government: please, do not let it get lost for another decade, and keep all of us in this debate informed on the progress of the Attorney-General's deliberations. I am happy not to push my amendment if I can have that undertaking. I ask the Government: please do something. Do not let us be sitting here next year and the year after and the year after that addressing this issue yet again.

—I undertake definitely to contact the Attorney-General this evening and ask him to pursue the matter with the State Attorneys. That is as much as we can promise at this stage, given the States' involvement.

PARA.TAB: The issue raises problems not only for the Federal Government but also in terms of the States. I expect that there will be some urgency at their level also to redress the situation not only in respect of the office of profit aspect, which goes directly to Phil Cleary's case, but also in respect of prequalification for those seeking citizenship. All the States seem to have different provisions from each other, let alone from the Commonwealth. I will ask the Attorney-General to make sure the matter goes on the agenda for SCAG.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is going to coordinate the responses and possibilities for action afterwards?
—It will be within the province of the Attorneys-General, but I can make my consultant, Mr Richardson, available at all times in respect of the matter.
—Senator Kernot, do you wish to proceed with the amendment?
—No, this is all recorded in Hansard, so we know the intent. I am happy to withdraw the amendment at this stage.

PARA.TAB: Amendment—by leave—withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chair was very restrained in not entering into show and tell, because I have some good stories about the 1970s.

—I had intended to jump to my feet after the Minister's explanation on the scrutiny of votes in House of Representatives elections and the indicative distribution of second and later preferences. I think the very reason the Government has brought in this amendment shows that the Australian Electoral Commissioner was within his rights in not responding to a request made to him by Senator Schacht. He did not have to do what Senator Schacht asked him to do. In fairness to Senator Schacht, he had indicated that that had been done previously and, presumably, voluntarily.

PARA.TAB: I would not like it to be thought by anybody listening to this debate or by anybody in the chamber that the current Australian Electoral Commissioner—who is a person of great integrity, as have been his predecessors—did anything that was contrary to the law. Now if he is so requested, he would be required under the law to undertake that task, if this amendment goes through.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht probably raised the issue because he was concerned about inflexibility. The Electoral Commission may not be the only institution that has been inflexible from time to time. Those who might have been listening to the cricket on the ABC would have been dismayed, if not stunned, to learn that with four balls to go they decided to follow the practice they had adopted all afternoon, and at six minutes past six they switched to news items. Most of Australia would have missed out on whether the last two wickets have been obtained by Australia.

PARA.TAB: There are those aspects of inflexibility in our system from time to time, and Senator Schacht would have been referring to that. Under this provision, we will ensure that people can be as responsive as possible.
Remainder of Bill agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to; report adopted.

Motion (by Senator Tate)—by leave—agreed to:
That the following Government Business orders of the day be taken together for their remaining stages:
No. 5—States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1992
No. 6—Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1992

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (GENERAL PURPOSES) BILL 1992BANKING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 15 October, on motion by Senator Bolkus, and from 4 November, on motion by Senator Collins:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills that we are now debating cognately are the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill and the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill. I will say a little about both of those. The States Grants (General Purposes) Bill is a standard Bill to allow for the payment of $14.1 billion in grants to the States and the Northern Territory for general current and capital purposes. The amounts of the grants were agreed to at the Premiers Conference held on 12 June this year. At that Premiers Conference, global borrowing limits were also agreed to. However, in the light of recent Australian Loan Council developments, particularly in Victoria, one must wonder how strictly they will be followed. That is a matter that we will be looking at very carefully in the Senate Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council, which is in the process of commencing its deliberations.

PARA.TAB: The States Grants (General Purposes) Bill is the major instrument of financial relationships between the Commonwealth, on the one hand, and the States and the Northern Territory, on the other hand. The value of the financial assistance grants is the same in real terms for 1992-93 as it was for 1991-92. There is also a one-off augmentation of $166m for this year only. Identified but untied road grants and capital purposes grants are also maintained in real terms.

This Labor Government's idea of Commonwealth-State relations has been characterised by the quite unrepentant desire of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for a greater centralisation of power in Canberra at the expense of the States and Territories. It should not come as any surprise to the Australian community that that is the case with Prime Minister Keating. Quite consistently throughout his term as Treasurer he constantly attacked the States and made good Commonwealth Government savings at the expense of the States. One of the remarkable features of financial management and fiscal policy during the 1980s was the extent to which the Commonwealth Government allowed its own purpose spending to continue to mushroom year by year whilst, at the same time, squeezing the lemon very dry so far as Commonwealth payments to the States were concerned.

This attack on State government finances led the States to use excess borrowings. During the 1980s it forced them to increase narrowly-based and unproductive taxes, such as payroll tax and stamp duties. That is one of the reasons we have the unemployment problem that we have today. Payroll tax—one of the taxes that a Hewson-coalition government will abolish on coming to office—has increased very savagely over the course of the last decade.

Payroll tax is simply a tax on jobs. It is the last thing that Australia needs at the moment with one million Australians unemployed. Today's national account figures show that growth in the economy is limping along or wallowing.
