We are nowhere near achieving anything but a rate of growth which will see unemployment inexorably increase.

Many years ago the Prime Minister himself said, as the then Treasurer, that the abolition of payroll tax would cause the creation of another 180,000 to 200,000 jobs in Australia. We agree and that is one of the essential reasons why we will be abolishing payroll tax. It is extraordinary to me that the Government has not deemed fit to act in a like manner.

The reform of Commonwealth-State financial relations is long overdue. The former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, made a not insignificant start to a cooperative federalist approach during his latter years as Prime Minister, only to have it torpedoed by Paul Keating's leadership aspirations at about this time last year. Indeed, Mr Keating's speech on Commonwealth-State relations, in which he reiterated his centralist views in this area, was one of the final catalysts that a year or so ago led to the overthrow of Prime Minister Hawke by Mr Keating.

Fightback—the coalition's package of policies and proposals for reforms to rebuild Australia, and to restore growth and job creation in Australia—includes major reforms in the area of Commonwealth-State relations. With greater certainty and flexibility in respect of taxation—the removal, as I said, of the job destroying payroll tax—the States' financial integrity and corresponding accountability will be very much improved. Indeed, we regard the building of a better Commonwealth-State financial relationship as one of the most fundamental reforms to be achieved in the 1990s.

We in the coalition wish to build a better federation. We are totally committed to the Federal Constitution which, of course, is the cornerstone of our Federation. We support the Federal system which distributes powers in such a way as to encourage participation and which acts as a barrier against centralist, remote and authoritarian control.

There is now broad agreement throughout many sections of the Australian community—including the political parties, with the notable exception of the Prime Minister—that Commonwealth-State relations are in urgent need of reform. There is also widespread agreement about the problems that need to be resolved—duplication, lack of responsibility and apparent lack of coordination between different levels of government.

On coming to office, a Hewson-coalition government will negotiate with the States on the basis of giving them a permanent share of income tax. The coalition would be prepared to make room for the States to share directly in income tax revenue. In doing so, the existing rights of the less prosperous States would be fully protected; no State would be disadvantaged; and the relative positions of the States would be preserved.

We regard a greater sharing of revenue raising responsibilities than now exists between the Commonwealth and the States to be a very important reform for the 1990s. It will increase the financial integrity, accountability and responsibility of all levels of government, improve efficiency no end and lead to a higher level and quality of administration at all levels of government. It will also mean getting away from the duplications and overlaps and the resulting inefficiencies that arise from the present situation.

It is worth noting the omission of a special clause in the current States Grants (General Purposes) Bill. In the corresponding Bill which was brought in in 1988—and this States Grants (General Purposes) Bill is an annual Bill to make provision each year for the payments to the States—a clause was inserted by the then Hawke Labor Government which sought to force the Queensland National Party Government of those days not only to conform but also to comply with Loan Council agreed borrowing limits.

This year, in 1992, we have seen the remarkable revelations that the former Victorian Labor Government, the Kirner Government—which so staunchly supported Paul Keating's leadership challenge last year—massively breached its borrowing guideline limits and deliberately hid that fact from the Victorian electorate, from other States and from lenders. That was a cover-up that appears, quite without doubt, to have been aided and abetted by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister.

One could not allow passage of the current Bill without noting the absence of a similar clause to that inserted in the corresponding Bill in 1988. The omission this year of a similar clause in this Bill shows the quite base political partisanship with which the Labor Government has dealt with its Labor mates around the Federation when it comes to this area of Commonwealth-State relations. Furthermore, it shows the lengths to which this Government will go to deceive in the interests of short term electoral gain.

The second Bill that we are debating is the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. This Bill legislates for a number of changes announced in the One Nation statement to liberalise foreign bank entry. The two changes allow more foreign banks to set up—in other words, the current limit will be removed—where those foreign banks meet certain prudential requirements. The Bill also allows for foreign branch banking in Australia. Foreign banks will no longer be required to incorporate in Australia. This provision will apply to wholesale banking only; it will not apply to retail banking. Another amendment contained in the Bill will complement New South Wales legislation to bring the State Bank of New South Wales under the Commonwealth Banking Act and also under the supervision of the Reserve Bank of Australia.

Whilst we are on the Reserve Bank and its supervisory role, I think it is worth mentioning here the role that the Reserve Bank played in the collapse of the State Bank of South Australia. As the Jacobs royal commission has said, the Reserve Bank neglected its supervisory role and, even though it may not have had a formal responsibility to supervise the State Bank of South Australia, it was undertaking informal supervision and should have exercised this responsibility better. The South Australian royal commission has followed the Tricontinental royal commission in my own State of Victoria which also was critical of the Reserve Bank's supervisory role.

Given this history of apparently lax supervision, one must wonder just what is happening in terms of the Reserve Bank and this supervisory role that it is supposed and required to have. As I said, the Reserve Bank was criticised in the report of the royal commission on the State Bank of South Australia. The Commissioner, Mr Jacobs QC, said that the Reserve Bank's policy of remaining aloof from banks' shareholders was `neither logical nor commercially and financially sensible when the shareholder was a State government'. Other things were also said in that royal commission report.

One of the matters that concerns the coalition in respect of this is that neither the Reserve Bank nor the Government has made any reply to the criticisms of the bank contained in that royal commission report. In our view, there should be a full statement from the bank. It should not be from just any old anonymous spokesman from the bank; it should be from either the governor or the board of the bank—but preferably, of course, from the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). That is the source from which a full response to the criticisms should come and it should be made public.

In our view, Treasurer Dawkins should make a full ministerial statement to the Parliament outlining the response of the Reserve Bank to the criticisms of it made by the Jacobs royal commission. The Treasurer ducked the opportunity to do that in the last sitting weeks of the House of Representatives. The House comes back for a couple of days at the end of these Senate sittings on 16 and 17 December and we hope that the Government will make a full response to those criticisms at that time.

The final amendment contained in the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill is to establish a second deputy governor of the Reserve Bank. That position will have responsibility for prudential supervision. We welcome that, but I note in that welcoming that it is very much a matter of closing the gate after the horse has bolted—certainly so far as Victoria and South Australia are concerned. One hopes, though, that it will strengthen the supervisory role of the bank because it is obviously something that does need strengthening.

There are one or two other minor amendments included in the legislation—removing the requirement for the Commonwealth Bank to obtain approval to pay dividends from a shareholder general meeting; changing the basis for dealing with unclaimed moneys; and the revocation of the banking authority of the Australian Resources Development Bank. They are all amendments with which the coalition agrees. We will not be opposing these Bills but, in expressing our support for the Bills, I did want to make those points.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 is a continuation of the internationalisation of the Australian economy and a further deregulation of the financial system. Currently, some foreign banks are allowed to trade in Australia under the Banking Act. The right to trade is governed by a banking authority, which is granted by the Treasurer on the advice of the Reserve Bank. In 1984, 16 foreign banks were invited to apply for authorities under the Banking Act. Fifteen applied and were successful. At the time, the Government said that it would not be issuing any more, and it has not.

PARA.TAB: Then came One Nation. Out of the blue, it seems, it was necessary to recommence the deregulation process. The banks probably could not believe their luck. Whilst Mr Keating was busy establishing what a real Labor man he was, he announced offshore banking changes, which we dealt with last night; amendments to the bad debt provisions in the income tax law to allow debts to be partially written off without forcing the banks to foreclose and bankrupt their clients; the relaxation of the requirements for the entry of more foreign banks into Australia; and the abolition of the requirement that foreign banks operate as separate entities, allowing foreign banks to operate in Australia as a branch. This Bill tonight deals with the two latter matters and a host of other minor banking matters.

The theory behind letting foreign banks compete in Australia is simple: it is said that these institutions will build market share by offering better and cheaper services to businesses and individuals. This will force the existing institutions to provide better and cheaper services, and everybody will be better off. There is a big question mark over whether this theory translates into practice.

Basically, because of continual pressure exerted by former Senator Paul McLean and various community groups and the scandal of the Westpac letters, Mr Keating referred the whole question of banking deregulation and banking in general to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. This Committee was chaired by Mr Stephen Martin, a well-known friend of the then Treasurer.

I really do not think that one could realistically have expected this Committee to do anything other than support the previous track record of the former Treasurer and, in doing so, propose more deregulation and make a few tame recommendations in the area of consumer protection, which would then be shelved or emasculated by the Government. I believe that this is exactly what the Martin Committee did. The Martin banking inquiry concluded that the benefits of deregulation tended to be concentrated in the area of big business. How amazing! It completely ignored the devastating effect of using interest rates instead of credit growth as the only instrument of monetary policy.

The Martin Committee recommended that further foreign banks be allowed into Australia. However, it did not do what the Government wanted. The Committee put a caveat on its support for the further access of foreign banks, which was that an authority could be granted only where reciprocal access was offered by the countries of residence of the foreign banks concerned. That means that Australia should say that we want fair and equal access for our businesses before we allow foreign businesses access to our market. One would have to ask why Australian banks should not be granted reciprocal access rights. The Government rejected that condition. Australia is to simply roll over and give away part of its market. It looks suspiciously like the Government's stance on tariff policy to me.

The Government is trying to show that Australia is an independent and self-reliant country. We do not tug the forelock to anybody any more—that is, we do not do so to anyone apart from the international financial community. It may be that the Labor Party saw what happened when Rex Connor tried to bypass the United States and British financiers. The Labor Party may have determined that the risk was too great, but that seems a bit unlikely to me. However, time will tell. Undoubtedly historians will look back on this period and notice the terrifying correlation between successive acts of financial deregulation and our fast immersion into the quicksand of enormous foreign debt.

The Opposition believes that it correctly identifies some of Australia's problems, but the Prime Minister is dead right when he points out that Fightback would make things worse. He is probably the most effective political communicator in this generation and I think he will be able to hammer home the defects of the Opposition's financial policies. The Opposition has gone too far in embracing financial deregulation and market forces. This legislation in some respects could be seen as a further example of that.

On the further question of foreign banks operating as branches in Australia, the Martin Committee also recommended that this be allowed, but that reciprocity be a condition. Again, the Government has not provided for that. But in its response to the Martin Committee report, the Government refused to even discuss reciprocity and officially responded `Qualified implementation'.

I think some members of the Labor Party would be a bit uncomfortable about the way in which the Government is seen in some ways to kowtow to the financial community without demanding some reasonable consumer offsets. Why not pursue a balance of reforms which also stop regressive bank fees being imposed? Why not ensure that adequate development capital is provided to small business? For example, in the superannuation area, why not ensure that consumers cannot be ripped off by excessive fees and charges?

That kind of approach is an inclusive approach which the Prime Minister referred to. He said something like, `Don't just grovel to the big end of town—recognise that markets do need to be regulated to protect people'. On principle, the Democrats will be voting against those two measures in the Committee stage.

The other matters are not controversial and we will not be opposing them. The States Grants (General Purposes) Bill is also being debated cognately with this Banking Legislation Amendment Bill. This is an annual Bill which appropriates moneys to be given to the States and Territories. This amounts to a bit over $14 billion this financial year. These are colloquially known as `untied' grants—that is, they are unfettered gifts of revenue for whatever purposes the recipients desire.

The need for grants to be paid arises from the division of powers between the Commonwealth and the States. The reality is that no State ever wants to raise taxes to cover its expenditure, and it can only be done by all States jointly. Hence, the Commonwealth has great potential power over the States because it controls how much money they get. If the Commonwealth Parliament really wanted to be bloody-minded, this Bill could be used to achieve a huge number of initiatives at the State level. For example, if it were unconstitutional for the Commonwealth to amend the electoral legislation—as we discussed during the previous debate—to give State public servants reinstatement rights after resigning to contest an election, an amendment to this Bill could make a State change its laws or else be ineligible to receive the grants.

There is a huge power, but I understand why it is not used very often. It is a reserve power of the Commonwealth. One has to concede that it could be used to effect important matters at any time. One recent example is the treatment of Queensland when it refused to agree to the global limits proposed by Canberra. The Democrats will be supporting these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills before us are not controversial in their main thrust, and in a moment I will deal with some of the concerns raised by Senator Kernot. The States Grants (General Purposes) Bill—and this is the third year in a row in which I have dealt with this Bill—never gets a significant amount of attention in this chamber, essentially because it is a fairly routine implementation of publicly known government decisions; it is part of the Budget and within the Bill there are no controversial clauses.

PARA.TAB: However, it is sometimes worth while stopping to remember that this is a Bill under which we are proposing to provide $14 billion to the States and the Northern Territory—about 13 per cent of the estimated Commonwealth Budget outlays in 1992-93. That does not make the Bill controversial, nor does it mean that we have to make long speeches about it, but from time to time it does seem a little surprising that $14 billion flicks through unnoticed while we agonise over matters of trivia and take hours, days and sometimes even weeks to pursue matters of much lesser consequence.

I suppose it is sensible, if we all agree about a proposal, that we should not spend too much time dwelling on it. However, a number of very important decisions are reflected in this legislation. To the extent that there is any controversy within the chamber about the package of Bills we are discussing, it does not relate to the State Grants (General Purpose) Bill but to the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1992.

Let me just recapitulate what this Bill does and deal with the elements about which Senator Kernot raised some concern. First, the Bill liberalises foreign bank entry and permits the issue of banking authorities to foreign owned banks; secondly, it permits foreign banks which are authorised under the Banking Act to operate as wholesale banks in the form of a branch; thirdly, it amends the Banking Act to make it clear that depositors with foreign bank branches are not subject to the depositor protection provisions of the Banking Act; and fourthly, and quite importantly, it amends the Banking Act 1959 to complement New South Wales legislation which will enable the State Bank of New South Wales to apply for a banking authority under the Banking Act. I think that is a positive step in bringing the State Banks which are constitutionally separate from the Reserve Bank's standard proceedings in and under the Banking Act.

Fifthly, the Bill amends the Banking Act to make several minor amendments with respect to unclaimed moneys in bank accounts and to revoke the banking authority of the Australian Resources Development Bank. Sixthly, it streamlines the process of declaring dividends by enabling the board of the Commonwealth Bank to declare dividends without seeking shareholder approval at a general meeting. Finally, the Bill provides for the creation of a second Deputy Governor position in the Reserve Bank. That is also important. Because the whole chamber supports this point it may go unnoticed, but it will assist the Reserve Bank's prudential supervision of the banking system and is consistent with the recommendation of the inquiry into banking by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration—the Martin Committee. The second Deputy Governor will also participate in the management of the Reserve Bank and will be a member of the board.

That brings me logically to the inquiry into banking by the Martin Committee. I thought that Senator Kernot was a bit unfair to the Martin Committee because Steve Martin, in his capacity as Chairman of that Committee, and the subsequent Chairman, Paul Elliott, have both done an enormous amount to demystify banking in this country and to make it easier for people to come to grips with the issues.

Banking and finance is one of those areas that tends to generate conspiracy theories where everybody thinks that somehow or other in the bowels of some banks someone is doing something mystical and creating credit and then suddenly this ogre will emerge to devour the poor innocent citizens. I think we have now put most analysis of that on a more rational basis. What the Martin Committee recognised, what the Government recognises and what the Bill reflects is that we are now in an international financial community. We cannot escape that fact. There is no separate existence for a modern Western economy other than as a participant of the international banking system. So we should get out there and compete effectively.

We talk about possible concern with international banks coming into Australia, but Australian banks are very active participants in the international banking community. In Europe, in Asia, in Africa, in New Zealand, and particularly in the UK, we have various major Australian banks participating very effectively and on a large scale. I do not think we want to try to retreat behind some barriers where we think we might be protected from the international financial community. The transfer of money is instantaneous these days and we all need to be a little more up to date and recognise that those are the terms under which we all operate. Therefore, that is the context in which these amendments are being brought forward. In conclusion, I simply note that there will be some government amendments at the committee stage. I thank senators for their support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: STATES GRANTS (GENERAL PURPOSES) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: BANKING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendments and new clauses. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 11, page 4, lines 25 to 28, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "11. Section 69 of the Principal Act is amended:
(a)by adding at the end of each of paragraphs (4)(a) and (b) `and';
(b)by omitting from paragraph (4)(c) `and';
(c)by omitting paragraph (4)(d);
(d)by omitting from paragraph (9)(b) `as is prescribed' and substituting `as the Treasurer determines'.

SPEECH.PARA: (2)After clause 20, page 7, insert the following new clause in Part 3:

PARA.TAB: "20A. Section 128 of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end of the definition of `protected name' in subsection (6) the following paragraphs:
`(f)Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia;
(g)Commonwealth Savings Bank;
(h)CSB'.".

SPEECH.PARA: (3)Schedule, page 10, the item referring to Chase Manhattan Bank Limited, after "Bank", insert "Australia".
I seek leave to have the brief speech on these amendments incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government wishes to introduce three amendments to the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill. Two of these amendments seek to amend the provisions of the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959 and the Banking Act 1959, while the third corrects an error.

The purpose of the amendment to the Banking Act is to reduce the amount of information which banks must provide in relation to unclaimed moneys. One of the requirements is that the annual statement of all sums of unclaimed moneys of not less than $100 contain information by which accounts may be identified, including the name and address, so far as they are known to the bank, of the deceased person's legal representative. Since banks are responsible for verifying the bona fides of claimants, we only need sufficient information to ascertain whether the moneys in question have been transferred to the Commonwealth. The Government has found from experience that the name and address of the solicitor acting on behalf of the estate of a deceased person is not necessary.

Section 128 of the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959 provides protection to certain trading names of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA), such as Commonwealth Bank of Australia and State Bank of Victoria, for business activities. The amendment adds the names "Commonwealth Savings Bank", "Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia" and "CSB" (the CSB names) to the list of names protected by Section 128 of the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959.

The reasons for making the amendment are set out in the Supplementary Explanatory Memorandum. Briefly, it is to prevent any possibility of persons soliciting investments from unsuspecting members of the public using the considerable goodwill and history attached to the CSB names. It is considered necessary because current protection of the CSB names ceases from 1 July 1993, and because the CBA is unable to obtain the same level of protection as other banks due the presence of the word "Commonwealth" in its name.
The Ministerial Council for Corporations has considered this matter. All State and Territory Attorneys have agreed to the proposal.
Finally, the third amendment corrects the name of one of the banks listed in the schedule of the Bill, from Chase Manhattan Bank Limited to Chase Manhattan Bank Australia Limited.
I commend these amendments to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended agreed to.
States Grants (General Purposes) Bill 1992 reported without amendments; Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bills (on motion by Senator McMullan) read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That standing order 64 be suspended for the remainder of the 1992 sittings to allow new business to be commenced after the question for the adjournment of the Senate is first put each day.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think this needs much debate; the issues for and against are well-known. We have on each recent night moved at some appropriate stage to suspend standing order 64. We have not needed it on each occasion, but we have done it as a contingency and the way the program is progressing, I think we will need to continue to do that on a regular basis. It seems to me that the most intelligent and systematic programming mechanism is to do away with standing order 64 and continue to seek a cooperative approach to the passage of the legislative program. To some extent we have been achieving that—not absolutely, but to some extent. I appreciate and welcome such cooperation as there has been. We have been pretty well around this track a few times.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the motion moved by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan). I sat patiently awaiting the reasons to justify the Government's case for suspending standing order 64, not for tonight but for the balance of the session, and Senator McMullan did not even seek to make out such a case. Basically, he said—I appreciate his giving us some credit for cooperation—that on occasions it might need to be suspended. If it needs to be suspended on occasions, why should it not be addressed on those occasions? I remind the Senate that standing order 64 states:

SPEECH.PARA: No new business shall be commenced after the question for the adjournment of the Senate has been first put on any sitting day.

It is a sensible standing order which acts as a persuasion to the Government to keep its program in order and in some ways reminds us that it is not good practice to introduce new legislation late at night. The result is that if the legislation is to be dealt with in such circumstances, it does not receive the proper scrutiny to which it is entitled. Therefore, the standing order seems to me to be sound in all circumstances.

PARA.TAB: The only question is whether something of an exceptional nature is occurring now that would require, in the interests of proper management, that standing orders be suspended for the balance of the session. There is no such occurrence. There is no doubt that the Government's program this session has been a shambles. The Government has presented to us a ridiculously large volume of legislation at the end of the session. It has therefore imposed unreasonable pressure upon the Senate to do its job in a sound and satisfactory way. But we have criticised the Government for that and that is now a fact of life. It is a regret that it is not able to get a program that gets the legislation before the Senate earlier in the session so that it can be dealt with in an orderly way with the degree of scrutiny that we think is appropriate. Be that as it may, that is irrelevant to what is now being debated.

As I said, Senator McMullan has not made any case for suspending this standing order for the balance of the session. I presume that the Australian Democrats also think that it is unwise and unnecessary and that they also recognise that to set aside a standing order that limits a Minister from introducing new legislation late at night is not sensible practice. But this will again put them to the test. Basically, this session the Australian Democrats have not behaved well in this regard. When they promised not to introduce a guillotine in the Appropriation Bills, they immediately introduced a guillotine which restricted our capacity to scrutinise. It will be interesting to see whether they go along with this concept of the Government that the work of the Senate can properly be done in the wee hours of the night. We know that was their view the other night because they conspired with the Government to see that the Senate sat all night, which was a ridiculous practice and resulted in the Senate not doing its job properly, apart from adding unnecessary stress in what is already a stressful job.

I hope that the Australian Democrats will say to the Government, `You have not made out your case for this suspension. You should come back each day, and if you are not achieving sufficient business and you can make out special circumstances the Senate can address the need for suspending the standing order on the particular day in question'. It will be interesting to hear the Australian Democrats' view on that. Simply because the Government has adopted bad practice does not justify the suspension of this standing order—this sensible protection—for the balance of this session, and that is why the coalition will oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a shared responsibility for the use of time in this chamber. I do not believe it is fair to say to the Government, `It's all your fault that your agenda has not been followed'. Equally, we can say to the Opposition, `You bear some of the responsibility for the time that has been taken in this chamber on various inappropriate procedural and legislative changes and discussions'.

PARA.TAB: It is not simply a matter of one party bearing the blame. We have tried to achieve a cooperative approach. I believe that we have made reasonable progress in the last couple of weeks, without the guillotine, at the end of 220 hours of debate on appropriations and Estimates, compared with 19 hours on legislation. That is not a reasonable balance.

This standing order does not compel us to sit until midnight, it makes it possible for us to do so, if that is necessary. Senator Hill talks about persuasion on the Government to bring its program here on a daily basis. I consider it to be an equal persuasion on the Opposition to be cooperative. Today we saw what I consider to be a hijacking of Question Time. That was not a cooperative response; that was desperation grandstanding, which was totally unnecessary. If it is good enough for the Government to bring its agenda here under some restraint, it is good enough for the Opposition.

In the interests of curtailing filibustering and encouraging collective discipline, I point out that some members of the Opposition today have addressed no comments at all to the provisions of the Bills we have been debating. I think that is an absolute abuse of this chamber. Members of the Opposition should not talk to us about cooperating or having lots of time. We should all be asking: are we being fair in the way we are using the time allocated to us in this chamber? We are not being fair.

I believe that the request to suspend this standing order is a reasonable one. It aids cooperation. I repeat: it does not compel us to sit here until midnight. It makes it possible for us to do so should that be necessary. If members of the Opposition want to complain, all we have to see is the evidence—no filibustering, and some sort of collective discipline so that the time available is used fairly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I am a little confused. I think Senator Kernot mentioned that this proposition will not compel us to sit until midnight. I thought the proposition was to suspend standing order 64, which provides that no new business shall be introduced after 10.30.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—That is correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not too sure what Senator Kernot meant when she said that this proposition will not compel us to sit until midnight.
—I see. This is not necessary tonight, is it?
—You are correct; it is not.

—I believe that we will debate the environmental legislation shortly and that will be put before 10.30. Whether or not the adjournment is negatived at 10.30 is another question. We are talking about the suspension of a standing order. Negativing the adjournment is a different question, although I am opposed to it. But that is a motion that is before the Chair pursuant to Standing Orders. If that is negatived, that is not a suspension of Standing Orders; that is a decision of the Senate in respect of a motion put to it under Standing Orders.

PARA.TAB: This procedure is a suspension of Standing Orders. As Senator Hill said, there have to be exceptional circumstances to suspend Standing Orders. I believe that Standing Orders ought to be maintained unless a case is made out for exceptional circumstances. With respect, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) has made out no such case to the chamber this evening.

The Parliamentary Secretary has not indicated why this standing order needs to be suspended for the rest of this sitting. As he has admitted, it does not need to be suspended tonight. It will not need to be suspended tomorrow night because we are drawing stumps at probably around 8.30 p.m. We do not know whether it needs to be suspended on Thursday night.

Frankly, I am opposed to this sort of cavalier attitude towards Standing Orders. Standing Orders are in place for a particular reason. They are in place for the good order of government and the proper functioning of this chamber. They are also in place to preserve the rights and responsibilities of each individual member of this chamber. Frankly, as an individual member of this chamber, I believe that unless we are given some warning beforehand and the reason why Standing Orders should be suspended, we will not know what might come on after 10.30 p.m.

Finally, I am opposed to the suspension of Standing Orders for another reason. This proposition is probably designed for the last two sitting days—that is to say, 17 and 18 December when the House of Representatives resumes. The House of Representatives will then consider legislation dealt with by this chamber last week, this week and next week, and will send messages up to us after 10.30 p.m. Instead of doing the right thing and considering the Bills in an orderly fashion, as they are passed by us—(Extension of time granted) I thank the Committee—I will take 30 seconds to complete my speech. The Government guillotined 71 Bills through the House of Representatives. That chamber should be debating the Bills which the Government forced through. The House of Representatives should be sitting in an orderly fashion and examining legislation. We will be required to fix up the mistakes in legislation which the Government has guillotined through the other chamber.
Question put:
That standing order 64 be suspended.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION BILL 1992ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Endangered Species Protection Bill and the Endangered Species (Consequential Amendments) Bill present the coalition with several problems. While we in the coalition are totally in favour of the protection of endangered species, quite frankly, the coalition is absolutely appalled at the way in which this matter has been handled. We are also appalled at the fact that the Australian Democrats provided us with a whole range of significant amendments this afternoon, of which we have not had the opportunity of taking a reasoned view; and I do not know whether the Government has had the opportunity of even understanding the range of them.

PARA.TAB: In dealing with major legislation such as this Bill, it is ludicrous that we should conduct ourselves in this way. It was bad enough that the House of Representatives was required to debate the matter just eight days after the Bill was first published. The main Bill has 175 clauses spread over 72 pages with four schedules, which make up a further attachment of 30 pages. It is quite complicated and important legislation. As it affects the environment, very important conservation issues are involved. It is of major and direct interest to a wide range of industries because obviously it affects the use of land, the way in which various developments might be carried out and the way whole industries are conducted—particularly, for example, the forest industry.

This is a matter of fundamental importance for the country, regardless of which point of view one has, and there are many interested parties in relation to this legislation. In my view, it was totally improper for the House of Representatives to have rushed in this Bill and for it to have done so under a guillotine that allowed only one hour for debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —And there are 81 Democrat amendments.

—In addition, as Senator Tambling says, there are 81 Democrat amendments which we also have to try to cope with here and now. I say to the Government that it seems to me ridiculous that we are proceeding with this legislation at this time and with 81 Democrat amendments. I think it only reasonable for me to ask the Government what its intentions are in relation to these 81 Democrat amendments and whether it intends to proceed to the committee stage tonight, because the present situation is simply absurd.

PARA.TAB: I do not usually hand out threats in this place, but I say to the Minister that we have not had the opportunity to digest the significance of the 81 amendments, and if they are put tonight there will be 81 divisions. It is just intolerable to put up with this kind of legislation at haste. I hope that we do not come to that situation, but I believe it only fair to tell the Government that we do not think it possible to undertake this kind of rushing stuff through when it is so significant without having the appropriate capacity to understand the significance of the amendments and establish our attitude to them.

It is bad enough that this legislation went through the House of Representatives with only one hour for debate. That is just incredible. But that is the way this Government is running this country and that is the contempt that it shows to this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much notice has it had of these?
—We got notice of these Democrat amendments this afternoon at 3 or 4 o'clock.
—How much notice did the Government have?

—I do not know what sort of notice the Government had, but maybe it will tell us. They are the sorts of technical problems that we have in dealing with the legislation. Basically, we have an even more substantive reason for being appalled at the way the Government has gone about this legislation. The Minister in charge of the Bill, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly), has completely bypassed the very expensive and very extensive ecologically sustainable development process in bringing this Bill forward at this time. We all know that a large number of people have engaged in the ESD process at very considerable expense to business and unions and at very considerable taxpayer expense, because the conservation groups, naturally, were unable to fund their side of the equation.

PARA.TAB: People have sat around tables looking at things in depth and come up with balanced recommendations. But what happened? Out of left field, so to speak, this Minister produced an initial draft of a Bill a few weeks ago which had nothing to do with the ESD process. This draft Bill was not a matter of consultation; it was produced at a time when the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council, ANZECC, had already appointed a task force to look at the problems of the protection of endangered species. That task force was still drawing up a draft national strategy within which the governments that are party to that Council were to draw their respective pieces of legislation, when this legislation was rushed through the House of Representatives in one hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —So much for consultation.
—So much for consultation with interested parties.
—How much consultation did the Democrats have?

—Yes, I wonder how much the Democrats were consulted—or are they of a mind to hammer through their 81 amendments in just the way the Government hammered through its improper legislation in the other House? We heard today an impassioned plea from the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Coulter) when he said that the Senate was being robbed of Question Time when in fact six minutes of Question Time were being removed by an urgency motion. I wonder now whether this newfound enthusiasm for the democratic process from a party that has in the past supported the guillotine will be shown in its attitude to its 81 amendments. As I said when the Leader of the Australian Democrats was out of the chamber, unless we get the opportunity thoroughly to examine these 81 amendments, there will be 81 divisions tonight.

PARA.TAB: What we have here is a mosaic of legislation which would be effective in protecting endangered species. That is, we were to have a mosaic of legislation which would be effective in protecting endangered species. That mosaic was to be drawn up, according to a nationally agreed plan, after full consultation with the States. That should not have been a long, drawn-out process. That task force was to report in March with its final recommendations. It should have been possible in the first half of next year to have legislation before this chamber and complementary legislation through the State parliaments dealing with this issue in a sensible way. But what did we get?

The present Minister for the Environment acted totally politically again, presumably under instructions from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), whose every act in this lead-up to the election is a political one. She went right around the side of this issue and absolutely broke agreements with the States and ignored the commitments that she had made to the other Ministers to wait for the report of this task force on endangered species. She came up with legislation which even her own ministerial colleagues found totally unacceptable.

There was supposed consultation with the States on the draft Bill, but the draft was sent out to the States so that they got it about a day before the proposed consultation. When this consultation with the States was held, three States could not be present, simply because they had not had sufficient notice. Yet the Minister said that people had been consulted. The conservation groups and industry representatives were allegedly consulted on the same notice. To call that a process of satisfactory consultation is a denial of the normal meaning of the phrase.

As my colleague Mr Carlton said in the House of Representatives, it is really a totally unacceptable way of bringing these matters before the Parliament. He added that, fortunately, other Ministers in the Government listened to some of the advice that was coming in from a broader range of people than apparently the Minister for the Environment was prepared to listen to, and substantial changes were made to the legislation.

From what we have seen of it so far, we are in favour of the general thrust of the legislation. Let there be no mistake about this—and I want to stress it—the coalition is very concerned that there should be satisfactory legislation around the whole of Australia to protect endangered species. There can be no doubt about it.

I must admit that I am not looking forward to hearing—but no doubt I will—the usual misrepresentation about these matters that comes from the Government, and I expect from the Australian Democrats, when they say that the coalition is in some way not interested or concerned about these matters. We are concerned about these matters but we are also concerned that the legislation should be the result of due process and proper consultation; that it should be conducted within the framework of ESD and the ministerial council; that it should be in accordance with the intergovernmental agreement on the environment; and that it should be the right legislation to do the job properly.

The intergovernmental agreement has been breached by the Federal Minister in this case because the State Ministers did not have a satisfactory opportunity to give their views under the agreement. The Minister has said that she did not breach the intergovernmental agreement, but that statement is just as nonsensical as the level of consultation that took place.

As to the reactions of various people to this legislation so far, many people have not been able to give a coherent response even yet—and that is a fortnight or so after it was rushed through the House of Representatives. We have tried to have some kind of coherent response to it, and I will be moving some amendments to the Bill which hope to make it a little more rational. There is clearly a whole series of problems.
Once again, it is up to us in the Senate, with 74 pieces of legislation in front of us, to try to examine this legislation and give it proper democratic consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —And all the Democrat amendments; there are 81 of them.

—As Senator Brownhill properly interjects, there are all those Democrat amendments. I note that in the House of Representatives Mr Carlton said that our support for the legislation at that stage was conditional upon the various submissions to be made to the Opposition from conservation groups, unions, industry and anybody who has an interest in the matter. They have been sought, and it is as a result of some of those that I intend to move some amendments in the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: I suppose there is clear merit in referring this matter to a committee. To an extent, we want to see what all these Democrat amendments really mean. I am very heavily inclined to the view that that would be a proper course of action in view of the method that has been adopted by the Democrats in hitting us with this enormous volume of material.

Industry, the unions and the conservation groups have put a lot of work, time and resources into the ESD process at great expense. For all that work to be just bypassed, strikes me as an extraordinary way to run this country, but in view of the way that the Government seems to be running the economy, I am not surprised that it certainly cannot run its conservation policy very well.

The intergovernmental agreement on the environment itself is a breach of the undertakings by the Labor Government to the conservation movement, as the conservation movement did not want intergovernmental agreements with the States. The conservation movement wanted overriding Commonwealth legislation in most cases, which the Labor Party promised before the last election but did not and could not deliver. We cannot ignore the States which have entered into discussions with ANZECC and also entered into intergovernmental agreements, and they are upset that the agreement has been bypassed.

So just about everybody has been offended by this Minister. She can do it without really trying, but in this case it looks as though she has tried pretty hard. Many of us are thankful for the efforts of the Minister's colleagues in amending the Bill. If the present Bill were similar to its first draft, I certainly would not be making the supportive remarks that I am today.

I do not want any further misrepresentation by the Government of our intentions on conservation issues. I am able to offer the coalition's support simply because of the intervention of some sensible Ministers on the Government's side. I am not one of those people who say that everything the Government, Ministers or even Parliamentary Secretaries do is necessarily wrong. Sometimes it is misguided, but it is not necessarily wrong. We are concerned that we should have a proper consideration of these amendments.

The Bill provides lists of endangered species. We would want to look at the definition of an endangered species. We need technical advice to see whether the definitions that are offered are acceptable to us. The list provided for in the Bill includes endangered, vulnerable and presumed extinct native species, along with lists of endangered ecological communities and key threatening processes. It sets up advisory committees. An endangered species advisory committee is to be established to advise the Minister of his or her obligations under the Act, as is an endangered species scientific subcommittee to advise the Minister on the lists that are referred to in the Bill.

There are proposals for recovery and threat abatement plans not only on the part of the Commonwealth itself; there are also cooperative plans with the States. We are pleased to see that the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service is a responsible person named in the Act as the director in charge of this piece of legislation. We certainly have confidence that the ANPWS would act sensibly in these matters.

A very important area of the legislation is that of the placing of conservation orders, of which there are three kinds: interim, permanent or impact assessment. We note that the previously unfettered right of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories to take various decisions unaided by colleagues has been watered down. We say amen to all that. Obviously that was by the intervention of other Ministers, who recognised the risks of leaving her with that kind of power. There are restrictions on what the Minister can do in putting an interim conservation order on a particular activity in order to protect a species that might be threatened, pending suitable investigation. That seems quite sensible.

Then there are permanent conservation orders which can be made on Commonwealth lands and waters by the environment Minister on the same grounds as the interim conservation orders. Although the Minister says in her second reading speech that these will be made only with the approval of Cabinet, as will extensions of interim conservation orders, the legislation does not prescribe this. We have only the support of the second reading speech for requirement for the Minister to consult with the Cabinet and get Cabinet agreement on a permanent conservation order.

That is not as strong a basis as we would like. It is a much weaker form of restraint on the Minister. It relies on the Acts Interpretation Act and a court presumably looking at the second reading speech and giving that a certain weight. It certainly does not have the same weight as a section of the Act which would require the Minister to take a matter to Cabinet and go through the Executive Council. That is one of the matters we will be raising later on.

The other problem is that the Bill relies very much on the key concept of ecologically sustainable development. That is not described in the Bill itself; it is to be dealt with by regulation. The procedure of allowing this key concept to be dealt with by regulation contravenes the convention that important questions of policy and principle be dealt with in an Act and not in regulations under it. That is one of the matters of major concern to me.

My time is running out. I simply state that the coalition is a supporter of the protection of endangered species, but surely there are better ways of doing so than the Government has shown in its presentation of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator Baume mentioned the ecologically sustainable development process at several points in his speech because, quite clearly, fundamental to ecologically sustainable development is the idea of inter-generational equity: the idea that future generations will have available to them no less access to the variety of species that we have today than we have today.

PARA.TAB: Fundamental to that is the idea of the protection of all those species which are extant in this country and all the biodiversity which is extant in this country so that it will be available to future generations. Senator Baume is absolutely correct to underscore ecologically sustainable development.

The Senate is debating what should have been one of the most significant examples of environmental legislation in Australia's history. Instead, the Endangered Species Protection Bill 1992 and the related Endangered Species Protection (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1992 represent a very restricted and ineffectual approach to one of the greatest environmental problems facing Australia today—the loss of biodiversity.

The title of the Endangered Species Protection Bill belies the fact that the vast majority of endangered species in Australia will not be protected by this Bill. Australia's endangered and vulnerable species will continue to be threatened by the indiscriminate and irresponsible development and by a government unwilling to take the necessary action to conserve Australia's threatened wildlife.

This Bill is long overdue. It was promised by the Labor Party as long as seven years ago. At each Federal election the ALP has promised to introduce legislation to protect endangered species. At the last election the Labor Party made a number of promises on the environment as a result of a questionary which was sent around by the major conservation groups.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's called `being sucked in'.

—I agree with the Opposition. That captured Green preferences and thereby secured the ALP victories at the polls. One of those promises was to use increased powers to protect native flora and fauna from extinction. That specifically means using the corporations power; that is what the Government referred to quite clearly when it mentioned increased powers. This Bill fails to live up to that promise.

PARA.TAB: The use of the corporations power, which is what is meant by `increased powers', was not even seriously considered in the preparation of this Bill. The Bill itself applies only to Commonwealth land and waters and Commonwealth agencies. Commonwealth land represents a mere 0.2 per cent of this vast continent of ours. It is ludicrous to establish a framework for species conservation within Commonwealth jurisdiction only. It makes no ecological sense. Therefore, the arbitrary nature of this Bill makes it fundamentally flawed.

In relation to the corporations power, I cannot help noting in passing that, while both the Government and the Opposition have specifically said that they would use the corporations power to enter the area of industrial relations, both have steadfastly refused to protect endangered species using precisely that same head of power.

Even though this Bill has been described by conservation groups as the barest minimum, certain business and industry groups have been vociferous, if not stridently implacable, in their opposition to it. These groups have deliberately stirred up fears in the business community about the impact of the Bill. They have asserted that the legislation might threaten Australia's economic development by delaying major development, adding to development costs and harming investor confidence.

They have turned a blind eye to the fact that our current pattern of economic development threatens the very ecological fabric on which our economy depends. At this point I draw the attention of the Senate to a news release which has been sent to all senators today by the World Wide Fund for Nature with the support of the other major conservation groups. In that press release, Mr Kennedy of WWF draws attention to the fact that in the five-year period 1987 to 1991, the US endangered species Act prompted 73,560 applications seeking advice regarding proposals which potentially threatened a listed species. Of these, only 18—or 0.0002 per cent—were stopped from going ahead.

The real fact of the matter is that these industry groups are ideologically opposed to legislation to protect endangered species. They would prefer that the Bill was deferred indefinitely or dumped altogether. They have not stated this position publicly. It would be most unwise and unpopular of them to do so, but they have declared repeatedly that the legislation gives too much precedence to the protection of endangered species and not enough to social and economic concerns. They have claimed that the legislation lacks balance and cuts across the ecologically sustainable development process. As I said in my introductory remarks, lying right at the base of that process is the protection of biodiversity and, therefore, the attention which must be given to intergenerational equity.

The shadow Minister for the environment, Mr Jim Carlton, has joined in this chorus by claiming in his speech during the second reading debate that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly, has completely bypassed the ESD process in bringing this Bill forward at this time. This is a blatant and wilful misrepresentation of the truth. The fact is that the conservation of biodiversity is, as I have stated before, a basic principle of ESD. Without the full protection of endangered and vulnerable species, ESD cannot be achieved. Strong, effective and enforceable endangered species legislation is a fundamental component of ESD.

It appears that some Cabinet Ministers share Mr Carlton's views on this matter, and I guess they are the particular Ministers to whom Senator Baume was referring a moment ago. In response to the extraordinary claims made by business and industry groups, the Keating Cabinet genuflected to industry and allowed these groups to set the agenda on species protection in Australia.

The Government's attitude throughout the period in which the legislation was being debated in Cabinet was one of appeasement and accommodation of industry's interests. Industry claimed that the legislation was being rushed through without sufficient consultation. There is an element of truth in that, because, as I have indicated, the Government has promised this legislation for a long, long time. Now, jammed up against an imminent election, it saw the desirability of pushing this legislation through now so that it would be on the statute books before the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —What consultation have you had on your amendments?

—Very little. Every time the Government responded by consulting further with industry, the legislation was watered down. In its final form, the legislation reflects the fact that the Keating Government lacks tenacity and integrity on environmental issues. The sad irony of the situation is that the Government had before it, in the form of my private member's Bill, the Threatened Species Bill 1992, an example of a strong, practical and effective model of species protection.
—How much of that is in these amendments?

—Quite a bit, Senator Tambling. We will be attempting to move this Bill as far as we can in that direction. My Bill did precisely what the Government promised it would do back in 1990 but has failed to do in this legislation. The Threatened Species Bill 1992, which went through a very lengthy process of consultation with both conservation and industry groups, was designed to put in place a network of management plans across the entire continent, not just in those Territories which come directly under Federal government control. Such a scheme would provide a systematic approach to both species protection and industry development.

PARA.TAB: It would mean that where developers want to engage in an activity that would have an impact on threatened species, the developers would know beforehand—and this is a very important point—that they could use area A, that they could not use area B or that they could use area C but only under certain conditions that are incorporated in the management plan for that particular area. Such a scheme would lay the foundation for the achievement of ESD. It would mean that economic development could occur within a framework of species conservation and ecosystem protection—a framework that has been laid down before the developer comes forward with his proposals.

What we have in the Government's Bill is a system that is guaranteed to arouse community conflict over proposed developments. Without State cooperation, species recovery plans and threat abatement plans cannot be established on 99.8 per cent of the continent. In addition, conservation orders to restrain actions by commercial operators that further threaten a species or ecological community with extinction cannot be imposed on 99.8 per cent of the continent. This is not the legislation the ALP promised to deliver before the last election. It is also not the legislation that most people in Australia want from the Federal Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Being sucked in again!

—The ANOP survey conducted last year on public attitudes to the environment reported that 68 per cent of Australians—Senator Panizza should note this—believed that the Federal Government should set uniform standards for the protection of plants and animals. This is a clear message from the people of Australia. They want development that can create jobs, but not at the expense of biodiversity or of Australia's unique flora and fauna.

PARA.TAB: Another of the environmental promises the ALP made before the last election was that the Government would give a major increase in funding for a comprehensive biological survey of Australia to be completed by the year 2000. Again, the ALP has failed to deliver. As my colleague Senator Bell said during the debate on the Threatened Species Bill 1992, grants to the Australian biological resources survey increased from a low of $1.1m in 1990 to only $1.5m in 1992. It has been estimated that at this rate of funding the survey would not be completed until the year 3000—not the year 2000 but the year 3000—by which time, at the present rate of extinction, most species would have been lost from this continent.

I note that Mrs Kelly announced on 15 October that grants to the biological survey are to be increased to $2.3m in 1993. Whilst this is to be welcomed, the amount still falls far short of what is needed to complete the survey by the year 2000. Only when we know the full range of species of flora and fauna in this continent can we be sure that we can conserve them and that we know enough about their interrelationships to look after them.

The timing of this Bill in the Senate is particularly cynical. It was guillotined through the House of Representatives, as Senator Baume said, and brought forward on the Senate legislative program by 10 days. It is quite obvious that the Bill was brought forward to ensure that its passage was secured prior to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announcing his environment statement in mid-December. It is also obvious that the Government wanted the legislation passed this year in case the Prime Minister chose not to reconvene Parliament next year. Clearly, the Australian Democrats support swift action to protect endangered species. However, the Government's belated action was not caused by concern over conservation but over electoral fallout and bad PR if this legislation is not in place before the Prime Minister's environment statement or before the next Federal election.

Turning to examine the Bill more closely: as it stands, the Australian Democrats very reluctantly support this Bill. Although we believe that it has many serious flaws, we will not be voting against it. However, we will be moving a very large number of amendments during the committee stage which, if accepted, will bring the Bill very substantially towards my Threatened Species Bill 1992, which we debated several weeks ago.

The Bill establishes a nationally agreed list of endangered and vulnerable species. It provides for the establishment of a national list of endangered ecological communities but does not include any such communities on the schedule. It fails to provide for a national list of vulnerable ecological communities. It establishes a list of key threatening processes, but fails to include the most significant process of all; namely, the continued clearance of native vegetation. While the destruction of habitat remains unchecked by this Bill, more species will become threatened and others will be driven closer to extinction. The Bill establishes mechanisms for the preparation and implementation of species recovery plans and threat abatement plans and provides for conservation orders to be imposed on activities that threaten species with extinction.

This last point had industry groups in a state of sustained agitation. It was the subject of heated debate in Cabinet. The first draft of the Bill contained a simple and effective procedure for the making of conservation orders. That process was then severely watered down over successive drafts by pressure from industry Ministers in Cabinet. The final result is a convoluted mix of conservation orders that allows too great a consideration of economic and social concerns and too much decision making power in the hands of industry-oriented Ministers.

The first draft of the Bill provided for limited third party rights to seek injunctions against Commonwealth agencies and for protection against payment of damages. In the Bill before us, the third party may seek an injunction only against the Minister or the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service. In the event that the injunction is overturned by a court, third parties now have no protection against payment of damages. This effectively means that third party rights have been gutted in the Bill.

The Bill fails to guarantee public nomination for endangered or vulnerable species in ecological communities. It fails to address the issue of commercial developments outside Commonwealth areas that require Commonwealth decisions for their approval or operation. It fails to provide any parliamentary accountability for the overriding of the obligations in the Bill in the national interest. These are only some of the omissions and flaws in the Bill which the Democrats will seek to address during the committee stage.

It is an indictment upon the Government's environmental credentials that this Bill was supported by the coalition in the House of Representatives. The Government prefers to believe that it is poles apart from the coalition on the environment. The truth is that the Government and the coalition consistently vote together on environmental matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are going to support it.
—Let us see how many of our amendments to improve this legislation Opposition senators support.
—We haven't had a chance to look at them.

—Have a look at them. Opposition senators have them in front of them. Even the coalition has admitted this policy kinship in endorsing the intergovernmental agreement on the environment, rather than, as I stressed earlier, the use of the corporations power, which would allow the Commonwealth comprehensively and nationally to protect threatened species. The Government must be severely embarrassed by this rather humiliating turn of events.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I refer to a recent statement by many of the world's most prominent scientists, including a majority of the science Nobel laureates, about the accelerating damage threatening humanity's global life support systems. The statement reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A great change in our stewardship of the earth and the life on it, is required, if the vast human misery is to be avoided and our global home on this planet is not to be irretrievably mutilated.
Of the 198 living Nobel laureate scientists, 99 put their signatures to that statement. Opposition and Government senators in this chamber will mock that statement at their peril.

PARA.TAB: This statement calls for a new ethic in caring for ourselves and the earth and asks for help from governments and business and industry leaders, amongst others. One of the greatest threats to humanity and the earth is a loss of biodiversity; the interrelatedness of species of plants and animals. We as a biological species ultimately depend on that interrelatedness for our survival and for our civilisation.

In the last 200 years, European development of this fragile and ancient continent of Australia has wreaked a terrible toll on the environment. We have achieved the worst record of any country in the world in terms of mammal extinction. This Bill should have been an opportunity to reverse this trend and to enhance species and ecosystem survival through the establishment of national, effective and systematic controls over resource development. It should have had a prospective component which would have laid down management plans, which would have allowed people to know exactly where they were going when they came forward with development proposals.

Instead, this Bill will do little to redress the tragedy of species extinction and habitat loss. It is with considerable reluctance that the Democrats will support this Bill. We hope that the Government and the coalition support the amendments which will be put during the committee stage and which will substantially redress the inadequacies in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, the penny has finally dropped. It has taken the Democrats some two and a half years to wake up to what happened at the last Federal election. The Democrats are fairly nice people personally, but they are just a bit slow. It took them two and a half years to work out what we told them before the last Federal election, but they would not take any notice of us then. We told them that they should not give their preferences to the Australian Labor Party. We told them that the ALP was, to put it politely, pulling the wool over their eyes. We told them that the ALP had no interest in conservation except the political interest, the few votes that it could get.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan and Senator Richardson sit very smugly on the other side of the House and I congratulate them. One has to give credit where credit is due. The Government went out and wheedled the second preferences from the conservationists with the support of this lot—the left, left-wing of the Labor Party. That is how Labor won the last election.

We could have told the Democrats—in fact, we did tell them—that our policies on the environment were pure, sensible and concerned. Granted that those policies did not go all the way that the radical environmentalists wanted us to go, but they did look at the environment and conservation issues very sensibly. We put forward an honest policy on those issues.

Senator Coulter might not have liked everything we said, but at least we were honest. He fell for the trap last time, and it was through his influence and the second preferences from his Party that Labor won. I know that he says he issued double-sided cards, but he supported the Labor Party. He gave tacit support to it and that is how it got in. I say to Senator Coulter that the chickens have come home to roost.
Senator Coulter interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The conservationists now understand that he was fooled that time and that is why they, as well as everyone else in Australia, are leaving the Democrats in droves. That is why the new Green parties—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Senator Coulter, as I understood the remark you made, it was in fact acknowledged by Senator Macdonald in which case it will have to be withdrawn, if I heard you correctly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not think it was acknowledged.
—The remark was made. I think it would be a lot easier if it was withdrawn.
—I will withdraw the remark, but while I am on my feet, I will seek to make a personal explanation. That is, that the Democrats have never allocated preferences and did not give—
—Order! Senator Coulter, you cannot make a personal explanation when you are withdrawing a remark. The remark is withdrawn.

—Thank you Madam Acting Deputy President, I appreciate your protecting me from whatever scurrilous remark it was; I did not hear it. It really does not worry me. I do not worry about most of the things the Democrats say to me.
—Pretty irrelevant.

—They are pretty irrelevant. Madam Acting Deputy President, I understand that you have a duty to uphold the decorum of this chamber and I appreciate your conducting your duty in the way that you did. The Democrats are quite nice people, but a bit slow on the uptake. That is why the new Green parties have formed. That is why the intense conservationists have no further faith in the Democrats; they have formed their own parties. The result of this Federal election will be quite interesting because of that.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity to say to the Green parties that they should not fall into the trap that Senator Coulter and his group fell into. Do not trust the ALP with the environment. During the course of the day we have proved that the ALP cannot be trusted with money or jobs, and I say to those parties, `You cannot trust them with the environment either'. The sooner the Greens, and what is left of the Democrats, understand that, the better off we will be. The Green parties will not get everything they ask for from the coalition, but at least they will get a consistent, honest policy that is concerned about the environment and about conservation.

I am proud to be a member of a party that has the conservation and environmental record that the Liberal Party has. Over the years we have demonstrated our genuine concern for the environment which allows the development that this country so badly needs, but which also allows for a genuine concern to protect the environment and to conserve what best needs to be conserved in Australia.

We in the Liberal and National parties believe that Australia can and should conserve endangered species and we believe that we should have development as well. We, and all Australians, want our environment, but we want an economy as well. In dealing with conservation matters and the environment, we need to ensure that we conserve things but that we do it in a sensible way.

In leading this debate for the Liberal and National parties, Senator Baume mentioned that we will not be opposing the Bill. We would have liked some more detail and debate in the other place so that we can ensure that the provisions of this Bill are adequate. Having Mrs Kelly in charge of this Bill does not leave one with much confidence. In the time that Mrs Kelly has been in the portfolio, she has achieved a reputation for some unusual decisions—if can I say that in parliamentary language. She has certainly performed her duties in such a way as not to leave much confidence in her administration of the portfolio. It is not a matter of only people such as myself saying these things, but even some of the more sensible and rational Ministers in the current Government were concerned as to what she might do with this Bill. Indeed, they went to great pains with a lot of debate and a lot of argument, according to the press, to overturn many of the provisions that she originally had included in the Bill. Many of the original provisions, if press reports are to be believed, gave her the sole and unfettered power to make decisions. It would be horrific if anything like that were ever implemented.

Nevertheless, although we support the general thrust of the legislation, and we will not be opposing it—subject to some amendments which we will be moving—we do have some concerns. We are concerned that the consultation that took place seems to be very limited. In fact, it appears that the recent inter-governmental agreement on the environment—which was announced with such flair and which local governments, State governments and the Federal Government all signed—has in its first test probably been ignored. I may not be correct in saying that, but because of my particular interest in local government, I would ask Senator McMullan to indicate to me what negotiations and consultations there have been with local governments about this legislation whose provisions will have an intense impact upon local authorities around Australia. I fear that there was very little consultation, and that is a matter of real concern in a Bill as important as this.
I note that we are to be subjected to 81 amendments from the Democrats—

TALK.START.PARA: —We have only just seen them.

—Yes, we have only just set eyes on them. That really shows how sensible the Democrats are about these things. If they want these things introduced—if they are not just playing politics; if they have a serious desire to do something about amending the Bill to make it more proper and sensible—one would have thought they would have consulted with us long before this and made us aware of these amendments rather than throwing them on us at the last minute.

PARA.TAB: Having received advice on the implications of this Bill, we are concerned about a couple of matters. First, the procedure of allowing the key concept of ecologically sustainable development to be dealt with by a regulation contravenes the principle that important questions of policy and principle should be dealt with in the Act and not in regulations. One can understand why that is a policy and principle. If it is dealt with in legislation, it is debated, it is looked at closely by parliamentarians, it can be referred to groups interested in the matter to comment upon and it can be debated fully in this chamber.
