If it is done by regulation, it has to be caught going through and procedures have to be implemented to set aside that regulation if someone is vigilant enough to see them and if the Senate is then able to deal with those things. It is certainly being dealt with the wrong way. It should have been done in the normal way—that is, included in the legislation.

Secondly, we are concerned that while the second reading speech states that permanent conservation orders will be made only with the approval of Cabinet, the only advice mentioned in the Bill is that provided by the director of ANPWS and the advisory committee. The same applies to the extension of an interim conservation order beyond 28 days. Those things are of concern to us as well.

I do not have a great deal to add to what Senator Baume has said. I know that Senator Panizza and Senator Ferguson have very worth while contributions to make that will make our position clearer. I simply want to say before concluding that if the Government's handling of this legislation—and no doubt the bodies to be set up pursuant to it—is anything like the Wet Tropics Management agency we have real cause for concern.

I quote an article written by Greg Roberts which appeared in the Age of 23 November. He indicated that the Wet Tropics Management agency had spent more than $1m on consultancies but at the same time had failed to release some $30,000 to save a fish that was on the brink of extinction. That shows what that agency is like. It shows what this Government's interests in those sorts of things is all about. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Some Government scientists believe that much of the consultancy money—
details of which we elucidated from the Estimates committee—
has been squandered.

PARA.TAB: The curator of fishes at the Queensland Museum, Mr Rolly Mackay, said it was disturbing that funds had not been released for such an endangered and unique species as the Lake Eacham rainbow fish.
The fish had been found only in Lake Eacham, on the Atherton Tableland—

SPEECH.PARA: a very beautiful lake, one of the two lakes on the tablelands, the other being Lake Barrine—
but is now extinct except for some kept in captivity. The funds were to be spent on examining ways of releasing them back into the lake.

But those funds were not available. They were held back by the Wet Tropics Management Authority. While the fish missed out, last year the agency spent more than $1m on consultancies ranging from a community attitude survey—would you believe—to landscape and scenic qualities.

PARA.TAB: The mismanagement of that agency continues. In Estimates I was able to obtain details of a fairly enormous advertising campaign which was being run by that agency in North Queensland. I do not think it was run anywhere else; in fact, the answers in Estimates found that it was not. It was being run, interestingly, in the Cairns, Atherton Tablelands and Townsville region. It just so happens that these three seats are held by Labor at present and are considered to be very marginal. All sensible commentators expect they will change hands at the next election. They are held respectively by Mr Gayler, who is not standing again—he left the area after tipping a big bucket on the ALP, and rightly so—Mr Hulls, who holds the seat of Kennedy, which is based on the Atherton Tablelands and out to the west; and Mr Lindsay, who holds the seat of Herbert, based on Townsville. These three seats are in real danger.

We had a massive advertising campaign, particularly on the radio, telling everyone how great this agency was and what great works this agency—a Commonwealth government agency—was doing in this area for the environment. They were the sorts of ads that gave us a warm feeling. If we did not know better, we would feel a lot of goodwill to whoever implemented that. But it is all fraud, like everything the ALP does in conservation and environment matters.

We are debating the Endangered Species Protection Bill. We have an endangered species which is just about extinct. It could be saved, but what do the agencies that the ALP set up do? They do not spend $30,000 to save that endangered species; they go out and spent $1m or so on consultancies. These consultants from the south probably had not seen a wet tropic rainforest before they arrived on their expensive consultancies. All the people who live in that area—people on the Atherton Tablelands, people in Cairns and people in the rainforest areas who have a practical knowledge of that through living with the rainforest all of their lives—were not consulted. If they had been, they certainly would not have charged $1m. That is the sort of interest that the ALP Government has in those sorts of things. It is good for getting a few votes, but if one is really concerned about the environment and endangered species, one should not come to this Government for anything sensible.
It is my privilege to move a second reading amendment which, if it has not already been distributed, will be distributed shortly. I move:
At the end of the motion, add:

SPEECH.PARA: ", but the Senate expresses its grave concern that, in presenting the legislation, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has by-passed the Ecologically Sustainable Development process and ignored the Inter-Governmental Agreement on the Environment".

That second reading amendment certainly deserves the support of this chamber. I urge the Senate to support the amendment which expresses grave concern for the way in which this Government has dealt with the legislation and ignored the agreements on the environment made with other levels of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation, as I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Macdonald a moment ago.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of his remarks, Senator Macdonald said that the Democrats and, by implication, I, in times of election, gave preferences to the Labor Party. That is absolutely untrue; the Democrats always issue double-sided how-to-vote cards and leave the selection of their second preferences to the voter, as they should be left. It is absolutely untrue that I or the Democrats gave second preferences to the Labor Party at the 1990 election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have grave reservations about this legislation, and they are not based on any particular issue of principle, because we on this side of the chamber support the principles that underlie the legislation. My reservations about this legislation are quite simply in relation to the manner in which it would seek to implement those principles. The concern of those of us on this side of the chamber—National Party senators and Liberal Party senators together—is that there should be an adequate provision in legislation to provide for the future welfare and well-being of Australians. The legislation with which we are presented is riddled with holes. It is legislation that is arguably excessive in its reach; and legislation which, if amended in the terms proposed by the Australian Democrats this evening—and I will get onto those proposed amendments later—would be unacceptably arbitrary and unacceptably restrictive on the development of this nation.

PARA.TAB: As has already been said tonight by my friend Senator Baume, we in the coalition will be supporting the passage of this legislation. But we will be putting amendments that we believe are of paramount importance if this legislation is to be acceptable to the Australian community and if it is to make adequate provision for future development of our economy. It must be made very clear that in this country we cannot live with an increasing population and a declining gross national product. In fact, if we are to increase the prosperity available to each and every Australian, it is absolutely critical that our economic growth must at least match our population growth, otherwise we will find more and more people sharing a dwindling portion of our nation's cake.

As has been said previously, the Democrats have now circulated in the chamber some 81 amendments to the Endangered Species Protection Bill, which I suppose they would have us believe we are fit to deal with tonight, at a quarter to 10. Some of those amendments are wholly unacceptable to any thinking Australian. Some of those amendments—for example, section 111C, which they propose to insert into the legislation—quite simply send shivers up and down my spine. For the benefit of honourable senators who have not come to the sixty-second amendment proposed by the Democrats, let me say that it seeks to make provision for the Commonwealth, if it is not satisfied that a State or Territory has made sufficient progress—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is like looking for Tasmanian tigers.

—I acknowledge the interjection from my friend Senator Calvert. If the Commonwealth is not satisfied that a State or Territory has made sufficient progress in developing appropriate legislation, this provision would give the Commonwealth the power to legislate so as to override the legislation of the States. And these people call themselves Democrats.
—And we are in the Senate.

—And we are in the Senate. Section 111C(b) proposed by the Democrats does not provide for the Commonwealth to override the legislation of the States only if it is not satisfied; the proposed paragraph allows the Commonwealth to override the legislation of the States by way of regulation.
—A dreadful proposition. The antithesis of democracy.

—As Senator Baume says, it is a dreadful proposition. It is the antithesis of the democratic process, which we in this Senate are supposed to support. We are asked tonight to support No. 62 of 81 proposed amendments. One must have grave constitutional doubts about the validity of that and other amendments that are proposed by the Democrats tonight. A quick perusal of section 51 of the Constitution does not give me any reasonable grounds to believe that the proposed amendment is constitutionally valid. But it might be useful for political purposes.

PARA.TAB: I believe that many of these amendments are politically inspired, and I do not normally say this. I have been handed a copy of a letter circulated by Greenpeace Australia Ltd—that well-known multinational corporation. The third paragraph of the letter, which is addressed to honourable senators, refers to the amendments Senator Coulter has circulated in the Parliament tonight. The paragraph reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: We understand that Senator Coulter will be presenting amendments to the Bill. We have been shown drafts of these amendments and believe that they should be supported. We strongly urge that you give these amendments serious consideration and approach this legislation with an open mind.
We would love to approach this legislation with an open mind—if we had had the benefit of seeing these amendments on 27 November or before, as Greenpeace Australia did.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some pigs are more equal than others.

—Some pigs are more equal than others. Senator Coulter has snubbed the Senate; he has shown a contempt of the Senate; and he has shown a contempt of the people whom he will ask tonight to support his amendments. How is it that Tricia Caswell, the Executive Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation; Lynette Thorstensen, the Chief Executive of Greenpeace Australia; Karenne Jurd, the Director of the Wilderness Society; and John Sherlock, the Executive Director of the World Wide Fund for Nature, should be shown these amendments before Parliament sees them? They expect us to deal with 81 amendments in the course of the evening. We have grave reservations about the manner in which this legislation is being dealt with.

PARA.TAB: We on this side of the chamber in the National and Liberal parties will be proposing amendments to this Bill in the committee stage. Those amendments, which Senator Baume proposes to move, are very important. They will seek to give legislative effect—real, effective power and backing—to the promises the House of Representatives received at the second reading stage, promises that are not contained in the legislation. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) in her second reading speech said to the House of Representatives that permanent conservation orders would not be put in place without the consent of Cabinet. But a perusal of the legislation reveals the contrary. There is no requirement for Cabinet to agree, nor is there a requirement in the legislation for the relevant Ministers to be consulted.

As a consequence of this, the coalition will be moving in the committee stage amendments that would require the Minister, on renewing an interim conservation order, to have the approval of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, that is, the Minister administering the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act, the Minister administering the Export Control Act and the Minister administering the Fisheries Administration Act. If these amendments we propose are not accepted and are not included in the Bill when it passes the third reading stage, we will have enormous scope for arbitrary power in the hands of the Minister, which may totally disregard and override the sound economic development of this country. This legislation has been subject to much discussion—admittedly hearsay discussion, because we were not provided with the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe Greenpeace was.

—Maybe Greenpeace was, Senator Ferguson. The principles of this Bill have been subject to much discussion. One of the key issues related to Marandoo and the pebble mound mouse. As one commentator said, if the Marandoo project, on which I am sure Senator Panizza will speak further this evening—he nods sagely—were to have been vetoed on the basis of the existence of the pebble mound mouse—
—I ask you to withdraw that comment now, Senator Coulter.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! Senator O'Chee, I understand that you are not taking a point of order. A conversation between you and Senator Coulter is of no relevance to me. If you have a point of order, you might direct it to me. If not, would you continue with your speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I find it grossly offensive that any honourable senator could refer to any other honourable senator in this place as a `Nazi moron'. I suggest that Senator Coulter be asked to withdraw.
—From my understanding of contemporary language, I believe that the Senate would find that offensive. If that is what you said, Senator Coulter, I ask you to withdraw it.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I did not say that. I said that he was an oxymoron. If Senator O'Chee does not know what the meaning of the word `oxymoron' is, I suggest he looks it up in a dictionary.
—Order! If Senator Coulter did not say that which has been attributed to him by Senator O'Chee, there is no point of order.

—I do know what an oxymoron is—it is an intelligent Democrat. If the pebble mound mouse were allowed effectively to veto the Marandoo iron ore project, it would have been valued at something in the vicinity of $36 billion—$36 billion for a mouse! That is why we, on this side of the chamber, will seek to move amendments at the committee stage. We do not believe that the arbitrary power proposed in this Bill—which we have been promised will not occur but, legislatively, is provided for—can be accepted. The amendments which we will seek to move will take away that arbitrary power and ensure that there is a cooperative framework in which this nation can be developed. That is what we require.

PARA.TAB: If we look around and see the grave economic circumstances in which this nation finds itself—economic circumstances which show that today our balance of payments deficit continues to grow; which show that today our net foreign debt stands at $162.8 billion—clearly an intelligent and reasonable framework must exist. The framework should not be based on arbitrary power for Ministers, nor should it be based on arbitrary power for a few desperate people who sit in the chamber. That would be wholly unacceptable. It would be wholly unacceptable for them to impose extremist views on the rest of the Australian population. That is why I think it will be necessary at the committee stage to have a cold, hard look at many of the amendments which will be proposed by the Democrats.

This side of the chamber can give no guarantee that, even if we do support this Bill at the second reading stage, we will necessarily support it at the third reading stage if the Government chooses to go down a path proposed by those who sit to my left. The Government must understand that support for this Bill at the second reading stage cannot be guaranteed at the third reading stage if the Government chooses to accept these wholly unreasonable amendments.

I also have some reservations in relation to this Bill in so far as it will impact on the timber industry. For example, it is entirely possible that plantation hardwood timber could be subject, at the time at which it is harvested, to the provisions of this Bill and, therefore, the harvesting of that timber will not be allowed to proceed. I hope—and I am sure Senator Tate, who is a reasonable man, would hope—that that would not occur. Certainly there is nothing in the Bill to prevent that from taking place. Nothing in the Bill gives guarantees to people who are involved in the extractive industries. It does not guarantee them the opportunity to extract mature hardwood timber resources which they have planted.

My concern is that this legislation may be used by extremist environmental people as an opportunity to further destroy the resource industries of this nation. In the past we have seen the consequences of the extreme environmentalists seizing powers—`extended powers', to quote the words of some honourable senators in this chamber—to achieve their ends. Let it stand on the record that those extended powers have not resulted in a better protection for the environment; in fact, quite the contrary.

The manner in which the timber industry has been treated in this country has not improved worldwide environmental standards. In fact, it has hastened the demise of tropical rainforests in Malaysia and South America. We, in this country, had a long term view as to the consistent use of those resources. But when we ceased to harvest tropical hardwood timbers on a sustainable basis, countries such as Malaysia and Brazil went ahead and clear felled. Not only does this nation import $1,800m of timber and timber products a year—much of it from Malaysia or Latin America where the environmental safeguards which we had even before the takeover of much of our timber industry were in place—and further erode our balance of payments, but also we achieve absolutely nothing in terms of furthering the worldwide preservation of the environment.

The danger must always be that the extreme environmentalists in this country will look after a little bit of the backyard and turn a blind eye to what happens across the road. That is something which I do not believe we can morally condone; that is something which I do not believe we can economically condone; and that is something which, for the future benefit of Australians, I do not believe we can condone in any way. Therefore, we will support this Bill at the second reading stage. But we will have a very close look at the proposed amendments. There can be no guarantee that the Bill will receive the support of the National and Liberal parties at the third reading stage if these extremist amendments are allowed to succeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was amazed this evening to hear the usual line that Senator Coulter of the Australian Democrats runs on environmental issues. He told us that the Government is wrong. I think this is the first time this year I have heard him say that the Government is wrong on anything. He says that the Liberal Party is wrong; he says that the National Party is wrong; he says that everybody is wrong except himself. He reminds me of mummy's little boy who is the only boy marching in step.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps one could ask why I am speaking on the Endangered Species Protection Bill 1992. I am speaking because of the dangers which I believe it poses to mining and rural development of Australia. Solicitors in this place would know that general contracts always have a catch-all clause. Towards the end of contracts there is always a general clause which catches everything just in case everything else fails to right a wrong. I am afraid that this is the case with the legislation that is now before us.

I said the same thing when the Democrats introduced an endangered species Bill, a threatened species Bill, or whatever they called it. I believe that the environment and species in Australia have been reasonably well looked after without the need for legislation. I believe that this legislation will make no difference whatsoever. As you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, farmers are environmentalists at heart. They have to be because if we do not look after the land, in time it will not look after us. That is the basis on which I approach it.

Two points stand out about this legislation as far as I am concerned. Of course, this is a coalition concern and fear. First, the coalition is in favour of protecting endangered species, even though I personally think this is unnecessary. Secondly, the coalition is appalled by the way in which this matter has been handled. Either earlier this year or late last year the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) sought to make herself the centre of power in the development of resource projects. She was not worried too much about environmental issues but she wanted to be the sole power in respect of whether resource development in Australia got going. She wanted to give herself the power of veto.

Further to that, before this legislation was drawn up the Government or, in this case, probably the Minister, by agreement, was supposed to consult with all the States in Australia in order to bring in legislation that was not centred in Canberra—because the fountain of all knowledge does not necessarily lie in Canberra—so that it would take account of the concerns and ideas of the whole of Australia. It has already been pointed out this evening that the Minister broke all of the agreements that were made.

When the first draft of this Bill saw the light of day, even the Minister's own colleagues did not support it. That is why it was delayed, and especially because it included the veto power. Other Ministers were worried—and rightly so—that their portfolios would be threatened by that power of veto. Fortunately, we have Ministers who have a broader view of things than some of the very narrow-minded ones centred here in this supposed seat of power. To that extent, the coalition supports the thrust of this Bill.

Conservationists were promised the world in the run-up to the 1990 election. I do not need to go over that; it has already been pointed out this evening. The Government promised them everything and the Democrats delivered their preferences, even though they claim that they did not. The Green movement acted on what they were promised. They were sucked in in 1990—hook, line and sinker. Senator Macdonald pointed out that the penny has now dropped. It has taken them nearly three years to wake up to the fact that they were taken in; that they have not received any of this sort of legislation and the Government did not deliver on some of the promises it made during that whole time.

Now that an election is looming, the Government has to do something for the Democrats and the Green lobby group to try to get those votes again, because it was only with those very few votes that the Hawke Government—not the unelected Prime Minister we have now—got over the line. So now we are here debating this legislation in the dying months of the Keating Government. Obviously the Greens and the Democrats want something in return for their support.

The Bill provides lists of endangered species. I would like to know the real definition of endangered species. I am not going to accept the definition given by the Government, nor am I going to accept any definition given by the Democrats. I would not accept anything from the Democrats, especially a definition of this sort of thing. The Bill provides lists of endangered species, vulnerable species, presumed extinct native species, and key threatening processes.

As I said, this Bill is very important to the mining and rural industries. My concern is the placing of conservation orders at the whim of a Minister, with the Green lobby groups and the Democrats edging the Minister on. Three kinds of conservation orders can be made under this Bill: an interim order, a permanent order or an impact assessment order.

Even though, on reading the Bill, an interim order seems innocuous, it can be used, and such measures have been used, to hold up very important resource developments in Australia—developments that can get this country out of the mire that it is in as a result of the actions of this Government over the last 10 years. Forget about a permanent conservation order; even an interim order will cause delay while calls are made for one report after another. The impact assessment also can hold things up for a mighty long time. Impact assessments are a boon for these Green lobby groups that act as consultants. It is a way for the Government to put much needed funds into their organisation and the Democrat organisation. If one asks enough questions at Estimates hearings for the Budget, one will find that out.

The all embracing power of the Minister has gone from this Bill, and rightly so. There are restrictions on what the Minister can do in regard to such an investigation. We need that; otherwise we will have the abuses of power that we have seen in all parts of Australia. The abuse of power probably started off in the famous Coronation Hill case. Then we saw it occur in other places.

In my State of Western Australia, a $350m project at Marandoo was held up for at least two years by irrational demands for report after report. Everything was used—Aboriginal heritage and sacred sites. This is what the catch-all clause does. When it looked as though that project would get off the ground, the pebble mound mouse appeared. We were told that Marandoo was its natural habitat and the only place in Australia that it was found. I heard that excuse for not going ahead with an extension to the freeways near Perth approximately 25 years ago. That excuse is used for whatever whim—whatever is necessary.

Then there is the case of Yakabindie. Senator Chamarette can laugh as much as she likes; she had better laugh now as she will not be here much longer. The project at Yakabindie was worth at least $200m. It was held up for two years. It now virtually has the go-ahead—after the thirteenth report. The biggest objector to that project was a white Aboriginal who was born in Queensland. He was supposed to be living in the area, but he lives in a two-storey mansion in Leonora in Western Australia.

The $200m project at Mount Todd in the Northern Territory was held up by the whims of radical groups. I believe the hold-up there was due to the goulden finch. Various other projects have been held up. Shark Bay in Western Australia was involved with the pastoral industry. That is where this endangered species process started by throwing out the family that had been on the station probably for the last 100 years. Senator Richardson, the Minister for the environment at the time, helped that to take place. I could give dozens of examples where this sort of thing has happened in Western Australia. The very few projects I have mentioned tonight total at least $1 billion in forgone resource development in Australia. What would that have done for the economy of Australia in the last two years? The figure of $1 billion represents only the lost development; there is also the lost production which would have flowed from that. It would have done a lot for the economy, especially considering the balance of payments figures that came out today.

These sorts of measures were aided and abetted by the now disgraced Western Australian Minister for the environment, Bob Pearce, who was removed from office—well, he removed himself from office but the Royal Commission in Western Australia really did that for him. He fell prey to the environmental groups to keep him and his Government in power, and almost $1 billion worth of resource development was lost in Western Australia.

As I have said, this sort of legislation is the catch-all clause. It will be used and abused by the Democrats and their greenie support groups and the result will be the holding up of resources. Senator Tate looks at me, but we know that the State of Tasmania was the first State in Australia to suffer from the holding up of resource development. It started with the Franklin River dam in, I think, 1983 and spread to the rest of Australia, and Senator Tate knows the results in Tasmania.

As I said when I started speaking in this debate, I am very worried about the endangered species in Australia, but I am also very worried about another endangered species in Australia; that is, the farmers and miners—the 5 per cent of Australia which supplies at least 65 per cent and beyond of Australia's export income which keeps Australia afloat even in these hard times. I will leave it at that and I certainly will be supporting the amendments moved by my colleagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Endangered Species Protection Bill 1992 because, like all senators in this chamber—not just the Democrats who seem to think they have some divine right to represent conservation interests in Australia—I am concerned about the conservation and preservation of all that is unique about Australia for my children and for future generations.

PARA.TAB: The question is whether this Bill provides us with the best method of doing that. By far the most important concern I have—and one that I have not heard raised yet—is whether this legislation will actually save one endangered species from extinction. What measures does this Bill contain which will actively save endangered species? It provides for lists of endangered, vulnerable and presumed extinct species; advisory committees to advise the Minister on obligations under the Act and the lists; recovery and threat abatement plans; conservation orders; and the imposition of obligations to protect species.

But what do these measures really mean? I would suggest that they basically mean locking up areas of Australia, an idea which would at first appear to have some merit. I say appear to have merit because I am afraid that it is quite illusory. The whole world has lost 60 species of mammals in the last 500 years; Australia, a single country, has lost 20 species of mammals in the last 200 years—and I have heard it said that we are the endangered species vandals of the world.

So what have we been doing about it? What we have been doing is locking up areas of Australia, which only means putting an invisible line around an area on a map. It does absolutely nothing positive or concrete to actively save those endangered species. Despite the best of intentions, it has not slowed the rate of extinction of our endangered species, especially on the eastern seaboard. The policy of locking up areas of Australia has obviously failed. In fact, it might be the quickest way to get rid of endangered species.

This is not an opinion I have arrived at without some consultation. One person I have consulted and whose opinion I respect because of his role in actually increasing the numbers of some of our species, against the tide, is Dr John Walmsley of the Warrawong Sanctuary in South Australia, whom I am sure Senator Coulter would have had some dealings with. He has used private funds to create his sanctuary which now provides a haven for animals like the yellow footed rock wallaby, the numbat and the brush tailed bettong.

Not only does the Warrawong Sanctuary not get any direct assistance from the Federal Government—which says it is so concerned about our endangered species—but it does not get any indirect assistance either. If Dr Walmsley were running sheep on his property he would not even pay land tax, and he could buy some goods sales tax free, including the vehicle he would use to go around his property to check on the animals in the same way that a farmer might check on his sheep.

Does the Government not want to encourage people to create sanctuaries for our endangered species? Quite frankly, I think the answer is no. Dr Walmsley is quite happy to give examples of cases where the South Australian Government has locked up areas for the purpose of saving the yellow footed rock wallaby, and those wallabies have now completely disappeared. Why? Because these areas are not managed. Management means doing exactly what Dr Walmsley has done—fencing in an area, no matter how large that area might be, and then eradicating major threats to endangered species within that fenced area, such as feral cats and foxes, to name but a couple. This is how Dr Walmsley has increased the numbers of yellow footed rock wallabies and other endangered species, while outside the fenced-in area the number of species across Australia continues to decline.

We can save our wildlife and that is what the Warrawong Sanctuary and the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management are doing. They are the only two groups in Australia that are actively managing their land, and they should be commended for it. These two areas are the only places in Australia where endangered species numbers are not decreasing. So where are their funds from any Federal government? Where is the legislation that follows their good example and implements their ideas?

The bottom line is that there is no point in locking up areas of Australia if there is no attempt to eradicate the real problem. In order to illustrate this problem, I would like to make a brief reference to the creation of the wilderness areas by the Victorian Government. The aim is to preserve different environments from the highlands to the plains of the Mallee for future generations. A total of only 4 per cent of Victorian land is now protected, yet even this could be wasted.

What is the point of creating wilderness areas if the land is not managed? What if brambles and other examples of wild vegetation are allowed to overtake and ruin the forest in the Victorian highlands? What if wild brumbies and other feral animals are allowed to graze and trample rare plants unchecked? What if grass growing out of control allows bushfires to spread far further and far quicker than if there had been some control of the undergrowth? What if cats and foxes and other feral animals continue to have access to this area, killing endangered animal species at will?

I am not just raising these points in passing. They are concerns that have been raised by Dr Tim Flannery of the Australian Museum in Sydney and by one of Australia's most eminent natural historians, Charles McCubbin. Mr McCubbin is particularly interested in the fate of the potoroo in far East Gippsland in Victoria. He is a committed environmentalist and conservationist, but he is also a realist. He knows that locking up areas of land is not necessarily the answer.

Indeed, as my colleague the honourable member for Corangamite, Mr McArthur, pointed out in a speech in the House of Representatives, a recent study by the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources found, in support of what I have just stated, that the major threats for our wildlife and plants are fire, and introduced species such as foxes and cats. Contrary to popular belief, the International Union found that most extinctions of species were not due to the clearing of farmland, disease or over-hunting. Yet we continue to focus on these issues as well as mining and development as the causes of extinctions. Our endangered species desperately need help, and yet all we do is avoid the real causes and the real problems.

Why? What is the problem with fencing off areas, eliminating feral animals from these areas, providing enough staff to actively monitor these areas and providing tax incentives for these sanctuaries to exist? I am not sure that I know the answer to this, but I do know that at a recent council meeting of the Australian Conservation Foundation it was decided not to get involved in the feral cat debate because it would potentially lose too many cat-loving members. What an outrageous decision. Is the Australian Conservation Foundation in support of our endangered species or not? I know that in South Australia there are 22 million hectares of national parks, yet fewer people are employed to look after this large area than are employed to take care of the Adelaide City Council gardens. I think this is a deplorable state of affairs.

We have a lot to learn, and one source we can learn from is our primary producers and rural communities. They might not have come up with all the answers, but they certainly know what many of the problems are. Our farmers and our rural communities have been leading the way in protecting our environment because they live not in high rise apartments or suburbia but on the land. They see the result of our past bad practices and they, more than anyone else, see that the way forward is to pursue farming and development in harmony with the environment and our plants and animals. Primary producers had to cope first with deforestation and its devastating results, and now they are replanting substantial areas of Australian farming land to combat soil erosion. They had to cope first with the rising water table and the disastrous effect of salt on crops in the local environment, and now they are working actively to combat salinity.

Farmers had to cope with the devastating effects of the introduction of animals and pests such as the fox, the cane toad, the rabbit, the wild goat, the wild pig and the donkey. Yes, I am aware that primary producers have contributed to these environmental problems and the extinction of many endangered species. But the point is that while the people in the cities have only recently been jumping up and down about the environment and our wildlife our rural communities have quietly gone about doing something about it. There are hundreds of land care groups all over Australia. The people who belong to these groups really care about the environment, and I am sure that they care about our endangered native wildlife and plants—and so do people involved in Australian industry. Yet during the debate on the Democrats' Threatened Species Bill on 15 October Senator Bell said:

SPEECH.PARA: Industry groups have shown very clearly that they do not want endangered species legislation.

I do not accept this. What makes Senator Bell think that people involved in industry, people with jobs, care less about the future of the planet than anyone else? I do not subscribe to the view that one has to be a Democrat, a university student or unemployed to care about our native wildlife and plants. People who work in and own Australia's industries come from all walks of life. By far the majority of these people, regardless of which way they vote, care about our endangered species and our environment. I certainly do not accept that people involved in the mining sector and primary industries do not care about endangered species.

PARA.TAB: The question that we must address when we look at this legislation on endangered species is one of balance. How can we care about endangered species and still care about our economy, our jobs, and our industry? What we need now is a balanced approach, one that puts more emphasis on earning income from our unique wildlife and environment, one that encourages ecologically sustainable development and one that allows the future growth and prosperity of industry without harming our environment.

The coalition supports this Bill, but with some reservations. We must learn to be innovative in our approach to protecting the environment; we must recognise that development and industry are here to stay and come up with ways of ensuring that they do not further harm our planet; and, most of all, we should learn from the quiet achievers of the Australian environment movement, our primary producers, who have learned that confrontation might get media headlines but only distracts from the job that must be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be supporting the amendments that are to be proposed by the Australian Democrats during the debate—
—When were you shown them?

—I have them here. I was very interested in them, and very keen to see that some homework was being done. I will be supporting the amendments to be proposed by the Australian Democrats during the debate on this vital piece of legislation, the Endangered Species Protection Bill. I pay tribute to the Australian Democrats, and particularly Senator Coulter, for introducing his Threatened Species Bill, which would have gone far further that the present legislation in protecting endangered species in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Government and the Opposition stand condemned for not supporting the Democrats' legislation and forcing the Senate to try to rebuild the essential elements of that legislation into the Government's compromised and ineffectual Bill. That is why we need all the amendments. I have a philosophical commitment to the protection of biodiversity. Thankfully, this commitment is shared by many others worldwide and is beginning to be reflected in international conventions and agreements. The most recent and most publicised convention in this regard is the Biodiversity Convention which was signed at the Earth Summit in Rio in June of this year.

Animals and plants should have a right equal to that of humans to an existence on this planet. There is an analogy to the common law duty that we all have to other human beings. This duty should be extended to include all animals and plants. Some industry groups, together with some members of the Government and Opposition, feel, however, that this commitment to protect biodiversity is at odds with the need to ensure continued economic growth.
Mr John Prescott, the head of BHP, for example, said in a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that endangered species legislation:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . would cut right across the Government's support for balanced development and would harm the national interest.
This represents an extremely short-sighted and narrow view of what is in the long term interests not simply of the nation but of the planet. Mr Prescott went on to say:
It would place an over-riding value on conservation values at the expense of other interests in the community.

Which community was he referring to? It was the human community at the expense of the natural world. These sorts of comments reflect a philosophy which sees humans as separate from and dominant over nature. Dr David Attenborough, however, sees us in a proper context. I quote him:

The main value of ecosystems, of course is that we all live in them. The jargon use of the word ecosystem tempts you to think that it's what goes on in a national park or somewhere round the corner. We live in networks of relationships with animals and plants, big and small, of which we are a central part. But we can't live without plants, because without plants we can't feed, and the whole system is so interlocked that if you start messing about with one part, you inevitably affect other parts of it, and, in fact, you affect yourself and the rest of the human beings.

The industry and Government perspective is therefore narrow, short-sighted and anthropocentric. If we are to work towards a truly sustainable future—not, may I point out, the distorted industry view of ESD—we must view biodiversity protection as paramount in government policy decisions. We must ensure that future generations are able to live on a planet that is rich in diversity and with a multitude of healthy life supporting ecosystems. There is an overwhelming need to protect not just individual species but the ecosystems and habitats that sustain them. It is a sad indictment of this Bill that this principle is not enshrined in it.

PARA.TAB: The world's economy is underpinned by the maintenance of four biological systems—forests, fisheries, grasslands and crop lands. For humans, these systems provide us with food as well as a large percentage of our building and clothing materials. Species conservation is an integral part of maintaining these ecosystems.

It is also worth noting at this point that the introduction of this Bill is substantially behind the schedule initially proposed by the Government. Senator Coulter mentioned earlier that it was seven years ago that the Labor Party first promised this legislation. I understand that the Government was promising that it would be introduced by the end of last year at the conservation groups peak council meeting with Minister Kelly in September 1991. The Government was obviously too busy trying to push through a Forest Conservation and Development Bill, which would have had dire consequences for the ecosystems of Australia's remaining forest if it was passed. It is deeply disappointing that Cabinet has agreed to try to implement this legislation yet again.
In my home State of Western Australia, the Conservation Council has pointed to the poor record of species extinction in that State in its policy on endangered species. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Now more than 800 species of plants are endangered and 80 species of animals are rare or endangered. WA has by far the worst extinction of all States.

In its proposals for endangered species legislation, the Conservation Council of Western Australia has pointed to the need for an ecological approach to decision making. One of its recommendations states:

Adopt an ecological view of the environment which recognises, in particular, the relationship between species and habitats and the importance of maintaining natural ecological and evolutionary processes.

Whilst this approach was reflected in the Democrats' legislation, unfortunately the Endangered Species Protection Bill 1992 does not contain many of the recommendations made by the Conservation Council of WA or any of the other major conservation groups.

PARA.TAB: The conservation movement's commitment to effective threatened species legislation is evidenced in a letter sent to all honourable senators from the Australian Conservation Foundation, Greenpeace Australia, the Wilderness Society and the Worldwide Fund for Nature. In part, the letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: We feel that the Australian Parliament as a whole should be seen to be supporting the protection of our unique wildlife.

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional orders I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION BILL 1992ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the many concessions that the Government has made to industry, some would argue that the Bill is now so weak that it is not worth passing in its present form. The letter from the four peak conservation groups states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a sad fact that in the last 200 years Australians have witnessed the extinction of more native mammals than any other country in the world. We believe that the current Bill as it is currently presented will do little to redress this tragedy.
It goes on to say:
If we are to show the rest of the world that we are serious about saving our unique wildlife we urge you to put aside your party leanings and give these amendments —
meaning the Democrats' amendments—
your full and considered support.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have only just been given them. We haven't had a chance to read them. They were given to you, but not to us.

—Anybody with an interest in this legislation would be deeply interested in what the Democrats might have to say, since they have already submitted to this Senate very adequate legislation to cover the concerns. It is heartening to see that the coalition intends to support this Bill. I sincerely appreciate that it is willing to do that. However, I will not be able to support the amendments that it is proposing.

PARA.TAB: In passing, I refer to Senator Panizza's comments on Marandoo. There is no need to refer to the pebble mound mouse as the reason for Marandoo not being an appropriate developmental site. There is no justification for the devastating effect of what will happen to Marandoo; neither was there a need to go there. There are hundreds of tonnes of iron ore in the lease of the late Lang Hancock further to the north of Marandoo. However, this represents the deliberate exploitative policy of the mining industry to search first for the precious and fragile areas, where it will have difficulty making claims and where it is more likely to have legitimate opposition, and then to seek out the easier pickings.

It is a tragedy for Western Australia that the mining of Marandoo may go ahead. Enormous amounts of water and the hydrology of the area will be endangered by the draining of the water table. It was interesting to hear the defence of these industries by Senator Panizza. One wonders whether he would be prepared to declare whether he had any financial interests in them.
I must add that industry complaints that this legislation will harm employment are unjustified. I will quote from a Worldwide Fund For Nature press release. Mr Kennedy, of that association, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Industry continues to perpetuate the myth of job loss and industry disinvestment as a perceived result of the Commonwealth endangered species legislation, while ignoring the reality of the United States experience. . . . Facts show that during a five year period (1987-1991) the US Endangered Species Act prompted 73,560 applications seeking advice regarding proposals which potentially threatened a listed species. Of all these, only 18 (.0002%) were stopped from going ahead.
Strong Commonwealth legislation will not affect employment levels in Australia, nor contribute to nervous financial markets . . .

The Opposition's amendments recount the fact that it believes this legislation bypassed the ecologically sustainable development process and ignored the intergovernmental agreement on the environment. In the first place, the need for this legislation is integral to the ESD process. It is a presupposition of it and in no way conflicts with it.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, in terms of the intergovernmental agreement, we need Federal powers and corporation powers. We do not need to wait for States' agreement. We need proper Commonwealth legislation. Regrettably, this legislation does not provide that; it only covers Commonwealth land.

This Government Bill is extremely limited in its coverage. As mentioned by Senator Coulter, it covers 0.2 per cent of Australia instead of extending its area quite legitimately across the Commonwealth. I will now quote from a Four Corners program involving Michael Kennedy in a discussion regarding Minister Kelly's powers:

SPEECH.PARA: We know full well that within the Constitution there are a range of powers that can be used by the Federal Government to step in to save species in a State that doesn't take action.
He refers then to the Franklin dam, an issue where the Government had the will to intervene and, in doing so, was successful. He goes on:

I think our advice is that there are enough powers within that Constitution to cover most of the State, and the parts that were left that we couldn't cover are insignificant. So yes, you can use Commonwealth powers.
I will now cite the support we have had from community groups for the Democrat amendments and for this legislation, even though it is in such a weakened form. Greenpeace stated:
This watered-down piece of legislation represents a pathetic greenwashing exercise. . . . Without these amendments—
that is, the Democrat amendments—
the legislation lacks any real mechanism to protect the habitats of our endangered wildlife.

The Democrats' amendments would have eliminated the complicated processes associated with three forms of Interim Conservation Orders. They would have defined more precisely the concept of killing or injuring an endangered species so that it gave protection to the habitat of species as well.
Greenpeace continued:

The brawl between Mrs Kelly and her proextinction Cabinet colleagues has left the legislation in tatters. . . . The watered-down legislation is a clear indication that the anti-environment henchmen in Keating's Cabinet have won the day.

At the end of this process, the Prime Minister has shown that he lacks the leadership to drive the government towards an ecologically sustainable future. Species will continue to become extinct, forests will continue to be clearfelled and our waterways will continue to be contaminated.
If this is any indication of the Prime Minister's commitment to the environment, his so-called Environment Statement to be delivered later this month will be an absolute joke.
The Worldwide Fund For Nature believes that the Commonwealth's endangered species legislation is weak in several important respects, but nonetheless supports its passage through Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The conservation and long term survival of many threatened species will come to depend upon its more progressive provisions. The Worldwide Fund is particularly concerned about the following matters. These are:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The legislation does not contain overriding Commonwealth powers; (2) There is no public, species/communities/threatening processes, nomination process; (3) The interim conservation order provisions are far too weak; (4) Third party rights are also far too weak; and (5) There is no provision to control the activities of Australian nationals overseas; (6) There is no immediate listing of critical habitats; (7) The legislation contains irrelevant and obstructionist references to economic and social considerations and the ESD.

So we can see that there is support for this Bill. Any legislation which hopes to fully protect species should include the full protection of habitats of endangered species, including the listing of vulnerable ecological communities; the ability for members of the public to nominate species for listing; and placing the protection of an endangered species above all monetary interests or the so-called national interest.

PARA.TAB: I have seriously considered the suggestion that I not support this Bill on the basis that it is too weak to provide any real level of protection for any species. Ultimately, however, I feel that it is better to have some form of protection than none. However, I trust that both the Government and Opposition members of this place will seriously consider all the amendments that are proposed by Senator Coulter and the Democrats.

If the Government especially is to honour its commitment to ecologically sustainable development, it must enact an endangered species Bill that truly provides protection to the ecosystems which provide the life support systems that we and future generations will continue to rely on for our very existence. We cannot continue to be dictated to by the economic rationalists who argue that profit should come before protection of the environment. A healthy ecosystem is an absolute necessity for our survival, not a luxury.
Appropriately, today, whilst walking in the corridor outside the Senate chamber, I saw a young woman in a black T-shirt with a message on the back of it which read, `Extinction is forever'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented and seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette said that I was a defender of a particular company at Marandoo, Hamersley Iron owned by CRA. I was merely defending the right of that mine to mine its own leases at Marandoo on an abandoned cattle station. Mr Hancock's leases belong to his company, are separate from those leases and nothing to do with Marandoo.

PARA.TAB: I also declare that I have no financial interest in that particular mining company. I speak for all mining companies on Bills like this, and Senator Chamarette ought to withdraw the implication she made about my reasons for speaking in the way I did.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is any need for me to go through and explain what these Bills are all about. As a Tasmanian, I say be wary, because this Bill and these amendments once again extend power to the Commonwealth and give it jurisdiction on either land or sea. As a Tasmanian, I am very well aware that, by using foreign investment, export licensing controls or foreign treaties controls, at the end of the day the Commonwealth can have the final say.

PARA.TAB: Notwithstanding that, it is important to remember that these Bills themselves arise from promises made by this Labor Government to the radical Green element in the 1990 election campaign. This was referred to by Senator Coulter, and it is a pity that he has left the chamber because I was going to say a couple of nice things about him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter is over there.

—Yes, that is correct. Senators would remember that in the frantic lead-up to the election, and in an effort to save its own hide, the Government became involved in a massive trade-off to the Green movement back in 1990. We do not need reminding that the Green movement is now very angry because the promises that the Government made have not been kept, like a lot of other promises it made before the last election. In other words, in 1992 we are back to 1990 revisited.

PARA.TAB: It is quite significant that we are looking to the Prime Minister making a major statement on the environment in the next week or two, and a lot of promises will be made once again. The Democrats must feel a bit peeved about this legislation, because it was the Democrats who first promoted this endangered species legislation around Australia. In fact, I was the only Federal politician who attended their launch in Hobart when Senator Coulter launched the Democrats' endangered species legislation campaign. It was quite well attended although it was a pretty cold night. All in all, the Democrats have tried to highlight something they are very concerned about. People on both sides of the chamber are very concerned about this matter.

On this occasion the Democrats have been gazumped. For political purposes, the Government grabbed the Democrats legislation—just as it did in 1990—and came up with this compromise. Now it is trying to push it through. We are supporting it, as are the Democrats, but the legislation is watered down.

It is important to remember the amount of money that this Government has put into placating the Greens over the years; the amount of taxpayers' money that this Government is handing out every year to keep the Green movement quiet. For example, from 1990 to 1992 the Australian Conservation Foundation received $341,000 of taxpayers' funds. The World Wide Fund for Nature received another $56,000 of taxpayers' funds and the Wilderness Society received a similar amount. It can be seen that the Government is prepared to pay whatever is necessary to keep the Green groups on side and in the next few weeks there will be another effort from the Prime Minister.

It is also very important to take the opportunity to reaffirm and reiterate in this debate the coalition's commitment to the environment. The coalition is often misrepresented by both the Government and the Democrats who seem to believe that they have a mortgage on caring for the environment. As a member of the animal welfare Committee, I, together with my colleague Senator Brownhill, Senator Bell from the Democrats and Senator Cooney—it was before Senator Sherry's time—looked at the effect that large feral animals were having on endangered species in central and northern Australia. We were just as caring, and still are, as any environmentalist in Australia.

For instance, we were shocked to see the effect that wild horses were having on native flora and fauna in Australia. In fact, wild horses, camels, donkeys and foxes have been responsible for removing some 50 species of flora and fauna from our landscape. It is all very well to criticise the farmers, developers and mining industries for the effect they have had, but by far the biggest effect on flora and fauna in this country has come from introduced animals.

I can understand the feelings of the average man in the street when he sees horses being shot, donkeys being killed and rabbits being poisoned. All the do-gooders say, `You are not allowed to do this. You are not allowed to shoot horses and poison rabbits'. In fact, my Whip's predecessor, Senator Kilgariff, had one of the largest infestations of rabbits just south of Alice Springs and it totally devastated his property. There was no other way to get rid of them than to gas or poison them. If that had not happened, the area would have become a wasteland.

As I said, the Democrats and the Government do not have a mortgage on caring for the environment. My colleagues on this side of the chamber, and from the other, have seen the devastating effect that large feral animals have had on some of our wonderful native species. In fact, I had the pleasure of tabling a native bilby at a committee hearing.

TALK.START.PARA: —A what?

—I actually tabled it. It came out of a hessian bag, not a paper bag. There is a photo of it in one of the promotional documents for the Senate. It is devastating to see the effect that feral animals have had on the bilby population in Australia, just to pick out one species.

PARA.TAB: Once again I repeat, the coalition has a very sound record in relation to protecting the environment. One has only to remember the decisions made on Fraser Island, for instance, the fact that we were the first to promote the anti-minerals regime in the Antarctic, and the support we gave to retaining the huskies in Antarctica just this week.

It is important to remember that the manner in which the Government and the Minister for the environment, Ros Kelly, handled this Bill was a disgrace. There is no doubt that the Bill will have far-reaching effects for the future of this country. It was debated for about one hour in the House of Representatives. Apart from that, most key groups associated with the environment in either a government or voluntary capacity received only a week to consider the Bill. I believe that that was because the Minister was defeated by her colleagues in the Cabinet, who realised that the draft Bill she had placed before the Cabinet was totally unacceptable. I do not believe that that is the way legislation should be passed through the House or debated in this chamber.

Tonight, without any notice or consultation, we have this huge wad of Democrat amendments, some 81 of them. They might be well thought out amendments, but what hope do we have as an Opposition of considering any of them before they are put tonight? It is totally unfair. It seems that Senator Chamarette has had a fair time to look at them, but my colleagues, and especially Senator Baume—who is in charge of this matter on our behalf and who is, like myself, totally committed to the environment—have had no opportunity to see these 81 amendments. As I said earlier, the Democrats were the first to promote this endangered species legislation around the country, and they did a reasonable job of it. It is pretty typical of the Democrats; they seem to think we are their enemies. We debate issues as they come up, and we are just as entitled as anybody else to know what is going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not as entitled as Greenpeace. They gave them to Greenpeace last night.

—They gave them to Greenpeace as well. I would have thought that if they wanted to get some support from the Opposition, they would have at least done us the courtesy of letting us have some time to consider these amendments. It seems that the Democrats have snubbed the Opposition, just as the Minister has snubbed the expensive ecologically sustainable development process that has been in place for some time. As my colleague Senator Baume said earlier, the ESD process, which has received widespread support from State governments, business and unions, was totally ignored by the Minister.
—She has snubbed them too.

—That is right; Senator Ferguson mentioned it too. The Minister has also seen fit to ignore the ministerial council of the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council, which is looking at the problems of the protection of endangered species. In fact, that group is still in the process of drawing up a draft national strategy, which included consultation with the States and other relevant parties. It looks as though that is also going to be overridden.

PARA.TAB: I reiterate that the coalition does want this legislation to pass and we are prepared to support its passage through the chamber. A couple of amendments will be moved by my colleagues Senator Baume and Senator Macdonald. I am terribly disappointed that, having supported the Democrats when they launched their campaign on the endangered species legislation, for which I am prepared to give them credit, I find that they are obviously not prepared to give the Opposition any credit for caring about endangered species. They could not even be bothered to show us the amendments they intend to move. I think that is most disappointing.

The other matter that concerns me is the fact that this legislation refers to Commonwealth waters. I understand that, to date, there has been little or no consultation with the fishing industry. It is likely that over the ensuing years there will be increased environmental pressure upon those who fish for a living in Australia's waters. Whilst I agree that we need to protect our species—as a Tasmanian, I have seen the scallop industry raped, and I believe that eventually the orange roughie resource will be in some danger—I do not think there has been enough investigation of the effects of this Bill on the fishing industry. I trust that, if this Bill is passed, we will not see the Green movement and the Government use it to prevent rational development. It is repeatedly brought home to me that some sections of the community do not want to see development occur at any cost. I believe that that is a totally unsustainable view, given the economic crisis we are experiencing at present.

The final point I wish to make is that I believe it is necessary to consider the effect of the permanent conservation orders that can be made on Commonwealth lands and waters by the environment Minister. The Minister in her second reading speech in the other place indicated that such orders would be made only with the approval of Cabinet. However, this is not prescribed in the legislation. That is totally unsatisfactory because, inevitably, that situation will be put to the test. I would not like to see a determination being based upon a court's interpretation of the Minister's second reading speech. As I said, we are supporting this legislation, but I reiterate my concerns about these Democrat amendments and their lack of consultation with our shadow Minister who is handling this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Endangered Species Protection Bill and the Endangered Species Protection (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1992, even at this late hour, in order to record my support for the protection of endangered species. None of my colleagues from this side who have spoken denies that support. My colleagues have brought home very clearly just where we stand with this legislation. Senator O'Chee in his contribution tonight made some very sound points about the timber deficit we have and the pressures that are put on other forests around the world if we lock up country in Australia. That is something we have always got to look at. At present we are importing a lot more timber than we are exporting, and that is also causing us economic problems. Senator O'Chee also made the point about States rights that, if the Minister requires it, under parts of this Act they could be completely overridden.

PARA.TAB: As I said, we support endangered species legislation. When one looks at the protracted history of this legislation, the Government has tried yet again to be all things to all people but it is now failing to satisfy anyone. It is not satisfying the Democrat people from the Green movement. We do not believe that this legislation is anywhere near ideal either. It has got problems for both sides of the debate. As I said, the Government has tried to be all things to all people and it really has not achieved much at all.

The various conservation groups have pushed for their amendments. They are not happy, but they will support the Democrats' amendments. I do not know whether those amendments are being moved by Greenpeace or by the Democrats. Obviously, they all know a lot more about them than we do because we received them only a little while ago. This shows that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) is rather out of her depth on environmental subjects.

The purpose of the Bill is to provide for the protection of species of flora and fauna that are endangered or vulnerable or come within Commonwealth jurisdiction on land or sea. Of significance is the fact that it can affect any activity for which Commonwealth approval is necessary. I immediately think back to the long-footed potoroo, supposedly found in the south-east forests of New South Wales. As I understand it, the long-footed potoroo has not been sighted yet. Tragically, it held up development in that area. All that was found of that animal was a hair in the dung of a fox.

That dramatically held up the development of that area. I ask honourable senators whether they have seen the long-footed potoroo. If they have, they should let somebody know, because people have actually been down in the forest looking for it for years. As I understand it, no evidence has been found except for that bit of hair in the fox dung. Taking that further than the forestry debate on endangered species, if one sees what is considered to be an endangered species, farming may be stopped. If there had been an endangered species on the site of Parliament House, maybe Parliament House would not have been built. I wonder whether that has been cleared up well enough in the legislation as it stands.

If one looks at the debate in the other place, this legislation was, as is usual for the Government, guillotined through the chamber; everyone has made that point very clearly here tonight. For most of the one hour allowed for the debate, the Minister did not even have the courtesy to attend the chamber in the other place. That is as much interest as she had in that debate. I wonder whether she really did not know much about it to start with and she was not prepared to even learn a bit, even though it would have been a quick learning curve in that one hour.

At that stage, it was hoped that the Senate would give the Bill proper consideration and contemplation, but here again it has been jammed through with little opportunity to critically examine the Bill with all of its ramifications. As I said, that is typical of the approach of the Government. To ask legislators—whether they be legislators trying to do the right thing or legislators trying to ram things through without any decent scrutiny, as the Keating-Labor Government is trying to do at the moment—to consider 70-odd Bills in the last three weeks of Parliament is a disgrace.
We are told that this Bill was canvassed extensively and I suppose it has been. We are told by the Minister in her second reading speech that:

SPEECH.PARA: Extensive consultation with all relevant interest groups including industry, conservation organisations and the States and Territories followed during the development of the Bill. The legislation was adjusted to take into account the legitimate concerns of industry and conservation groups, while still maintaining its integrity.

I do not think the legislation now has as much integrity as it could have had because it has tried to be, as I said in the first instance, all things to all people. That is a sad thing because, as I said earlier, we on this side of the chamber believe in protecting endangered species and in protecting the environment, but we definitely do not believe in bad legislation. In the long term, I do not think that this legislation will do all the things that the legislators want it to do.

PARA.TAB: When we think about it, the poor old timber industry now has about seven different areas to go through before it can actually start to produce timber, resulting in exports for Australia or in a roof over our heads. The industry has to go through EISs, World Heritage, National Estate, woodchip legislation, the FIRB—which looks at any of the things that the industry wants to do—the Commonwealth export powers and other areas before it can actually start to mill any timber.

If we go too far in restricting people in this country we will find industries being lost. We will also have an even worse economy than that which the Keating Labor Government has given this country. We are told that there was consultation with the States. As I understand it, that consultation did not happen. But even though it has not happened the Government has not been deterred from pushing ahead. The Government has obviously read the various media commentators who say that the Labor Party needs to once again stitch up the conservation vote. If it wants to have a hope of winning the next election, it has to try to get another special group on side. It does not have Senator Richardson to do it this time, but maybe he is doing it behind the scenes.

I am concerned that what constitutes an endangered species has not been thoroughly or satisfactorily defined. I earlier mentioned the long-footed potoroo. What else is going to be found—and not going be found, if you like—while this legislation is being looked at? Work that one out, if you can. The long-footed potoroo was never found. People kept looking for it, but all that was found was that long bit of hair in that bit of fox dung.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whereabouts was that?

—That was down in the south eastern forests of New South Wales. That restricted and held up much of the timber industry for a long time. I am concerned about the placing of conservation orders. Fortunately, someone has seen the wisdom of not giving Minister Kelly absolute veto and authority in the issuing of such orders. In her second reading speech, she said that permanent orders must receive Cabinet approval. However, I believe that is another grey area in the legislation; it is not actually specified in the Bill itself. The other area of great concern is the Democrats.
—They are an endangered species.

—The endangered Democrats. The Democrats very kindly showed their 81 amendments to the Government and to Greenpeace—or, as I said, are they Greenpeace's amendments that the Democrats are fronting in this place? I think that any party that does a disservice to this chamber by not showing the amendments to all members of this chamber stands condemned. Senator Chamarette was shown the amendments. I wonder who else was. I suppose everyone else around the place who was tied up with that side of the debate had a look at them. What deals have been done with the Government on those 81 amendments? Here we are at 10 minutes past 11 on Tuesday night, when we all should be getting a bit of sleep so we can come back and debate things properly tomorrow and the next day, trying to debate in the dark 81 amendments that have just been put in front of us.

PARA.TAB: Time and again we have told the Labor Party that we are not opposed to the concept of this legislation to protect endangered species; neither perhaps would the various State governments, had they actually seen the legislation and been given appropriate and reasonable time to consider it. This legislation is another example of why the Labor Party does not deserve the responsibility of government. It cannot get the economy right. We have seen that in the last couple of days. This country is in absolute neglect economically and it will be put further into neglect unless the Government is voted out and we are given a go on the treasury bench.

As I have said, the Government cannot get this legislation right and it cannot manage its parliamentary and legislative timetable either. I think that Senator McMullan would have done a better job by allowing this debate to proceed in a way which would have enabled everyone to have had a closer look at all the amendments that have been put before us. We could have had a good look at all the problems associated with the legislation, and in the end we could have come up with something that was decent to protect the endangered animals in this country.

If the Endangered Species Protection Bill had been debated properly, we could have really gone on with it. Basically, there will be some real problems with some parts of the Bill—such as with the permanent conservation orders, as mentioned by Senator Calvert a while ago—unless we get it right. If we do not get it right, we will all regret it. We are legislators who are meant to put good legislation through this chamber. By it being guillotined, the legislation will not be as it should be.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Endangered Species Protection Bill 1992. This legislation is the manifestation of an election commitment made in the heat of the last Federal election campaign at a time when the Labor Party was making its last desperate lunge to get the preferences of the Green vote because its own vote was in the range of 36 to 37 per cent.
—We got there.

—Senator Sherry makes the point that the Government got there. It did not get there because it was people's first or second choice; it got there because people seeking to cast a vote of protest against the Government foolishly followed the Green how to vote card and ended up at the bottom of the ticket casting a vote for the Labor Party because its name happened to be but one above that of the Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: It was in that context that this legislation was manifest. It was first prepared exclusively in the divine office of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly, who has spent the whole time she has been in that portfolio seeking to inherit the mantle that was passed on to her by Senator Graham Richardson—that is, to ingratiate herself with the more extreme and radical elements of the conservation movement.
