Her problem has been that, as distinct from the obvious signs of the period of Senator Richardson being the Minister for the Environment, the economy has for the duration of the last three years continued to spiral downwards and plunge us into the depths of abject recession. Cabinet has been understanding enough to recognise that there is not a great deal of sympathy to be had in the community for those who are driving a harsh radical environment policy to the detriment of the economy. So the support for the environment and the environmental movement has, to some degree, been diminished.

Even this dopey Cabinet has woken up to the fact that unless we have a strong, virile economy we simply cannot have conservation. Even the most unenlightened minds have only to cast their eyes upon the environmental considerations in the Third World countries to see the degradation that takes place there simply because they do not have the foundation of a substantial economy to allow them to consider such matters as the environment and quality of life.

One of the other problems for Mrs Kelly, which is well known, is that she is so politically dopey. I well remember her being interviewed on the radio one morning observing that she was doing her bit for the environment because she was now driving a smaller motor car. Not only did she not know what brand of motor car she was driving, but also when she was asked a very benign question by the interviewer, who was trying to help her along, about the size of motor car she had, its engine size and what the reduction in fuel consumption was, she did not have the slightest idea. It was an example of her typical tokenism towards being concerned about the environment and portraying herself as having some affinity with the more radical movement.

I was interested to observe that in exactly the same week as Mrs Kelly chose to climb out of a six-cylinder and into a four-cylinder motor car she got into a VIP Falcon jet and flew up to Sydney to make a fool of herself on the Steve Vizard show. The reason that she was in that jet at a cost of $10,000 an hour, which was spewing out gas into the environment, was that earlier in the evening she had been at the Lodge celebrating the Canberra Raiders' victory. We all know that she is their mascot and she could not afford to not be there on that occasion. That shows us the concern that Mrs Kelly has for the environment. She will drive around Canberra symbolically in a small motor car but get in a jet aircraft and fly up to Sydney to plonk her bottom on a chair next to Steve Vizard to make a fool of herself in the name of whatever causes she purports to represent.

This legislation is somewhat of a compromise by the Labor Cabinet. It has watered down some of the more extreme provisions, not the least being the intrinsic concentration of power which was originally in the hands of the Minister. It has been a compromise. The more pragmatic minds in Cabinet understand the absurdity of her original notion, but she can serve up this trash and this tripe legislation and when she gets rolled she can go back to the Green movement and say, `Don't blame me, I'm on your side' and in that way seek to continue to ingratiate herself for the cause of the next election.

There are a number of features of this legislation which I find obnoxious, but time prevents me from canvassing them all. To start with, the Minister gave a commitment to the Ministerial Council that the Bill would be drawn up in consultation with the States and following the report of the task force on endangered species protection. The Minister has effectively disregarded the intergovernmental agreement on the environment. The industry has expressed its disappointment that the Minister has bypassed the ecologically sustainable process which has involved considerable resources from industry. It has really made a mockery of that total process.

The definitions and the grounds upon which the Minister's decisions are made are not specific, which means that economic development will be left to the whims and discretion of the Minister responsible for the Act. No doubt, as in the past, her decisions will be driven by political expediency, not responsible and mature economic considerations.

The Business Council of Australia very wisely observes that it is disappointed that the Bill does not adequately cater for economic considerations. Again, this Government shows it has no balance. It does not see a consideration and contemplation of the competing and conflicting considerations which go into making sensible and rational decisions at the end of the day.

The National Farmers Federation has observed that the major deficiency in the legislation as far as it is concerned is that the process does not require economic and social impact considerations prior to listing a species with only conservation issues being considered at that stage, which is very much the point being made by the Business Council of Australia.

The schedules in this Bill contain a list of 327 animal and plant species considered as endangered; a list of 725 species considered to be vulnerable; and a list of 113 species presumed extinct. This is a list of over 1,000 existing species, overwhelmingly of plants. Animals represent 73 of the 300 endangered species and 66 of the 725 vulnerable species. Overwhelmingly, we are obsessed with preserving plants.

It is interesting to observe by way of comparison, to place the proposed legislation in some sort of context, that the USA has a list of 728 endangered or threatened species with a further 4,000 to be considered. It is odd that the USA, 20 years after implementing the endangered species Act, has a list which is smaller than our starting point. The US Department of the Interior has estimated that it will take between 38 and 49 years just to list the species likely to warrant listing from the 4,000 under consideration.

As with this legislation in Australia, presumably the ultimate aim of species legislation in the USA is to recover and de-list animals and plants which are in danger of extinction. In the two decades that the United States has had legislation, it has not achieved the de-listing of any species in a meaningful way. Only four de-listings have taken place. I think one of those was due to the discovery of previous errors. Three recoveries involved birds limited to a particular island where the discovery of additional birds led to their de-listing. The fourth recovery involved a plant, also due to initial data error, which meant that the plant should not have been listed in the first place.

I conclude by saying that this legislation is the epitome of political expediency, driven by the imperative of being rammed and jammed through this chamber prior to the next Federal election so that the Prime Minister can proffer it as the fulfilment of a commitment made at the last election, in the desperate hope that he can again recapture the Green vote. I observe that we have something like 82 amendments—a matter that has been raised by a number of other speakers. I do not know whether it is a conspiracy to keep the Opposition plunged into some form of political darkness or whether it is just, as Senator Robert Ray would say, a typical Democrat stuff-up that we were not advised earlier on.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you have to choose between a stuff-up and a conspiracy, go for the stuff-up.

—I can speak only for my political party. Without exception, that is exactly what happens. If it looks like a conspiracy, we can be certain it is a stuff-up. If it looks like a stuff-up, it usually is a stuff-up.
—I am told you have run a few conspiracies in your day.

—I will ignore those unkind and cutting remarks from the Minister. The truth of the matter is that we are a chamber of second deliberation, a chamber of second consideration, and a chamber that contemplates with some serious diligence amendments as they come before it. In respect of legislation of such a vital nature, I would have thought it would have been in the interests of all of us to have had these amendments before us. It is only because God has given us the time of 11.25 that we are not dealing with these amendments tonight. If it had been at an earlier time of the day, we would have been confronted with these amendments.

PARA.TAB: If the Democrats expect their amendments to be taken seriously, as they always are by wise-thinking people, they should provide them to us in plenty of time. As somebody else observed, the amendments were given to those people who, presumably, they imagined were going to support them. The coalition, subject to some reservations, is supporting this legislation. That was not a unanimous view; however, it is a consensus view. Having said that, I conclude by saying that I regret that there is not more balance to the extent that the economic considerations are not weighed as carefully as are the conservation considerations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the Endangered Species Protection Bill should very obviously occupy the major consideration of all senators. This is most important legislation. It is going to have effects not only on industry but also on the entire Australian community.
—It might be the end of the world itself.
—I am not going into those sorts of prophecies. It is also important to consider the amendment the Opposition has put forward, and I reiterate it:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:

", but the Senate expresses its grave concern that, in presenting the legislation, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has by-passed the Ecologically Sustainable Development process and ignored the Inter-Governmental Agreement on the Environment".

The intergovernmental agreement on the environment purports to govern relations between the various tiers of government on environmental matters. What we are seeing in the progress of this legislation through the Parliament at this time is nothing short of a steamrolling of the process of the intergovernmental agreement on the environment. We all know that the agreement is a very vital and important one between the Commonwealth and the States and the Territories. The aims of the agreement are essentially to seek a cooperative approach to the environment by defining the roles of the various tiers of government and reducing the potential for disputation. What has happened to the intergovernmental agreement on the environment? It has been torn up; it has been shredded. It obviously has not been observed, and the Commonwealth has walked away from the obligations it would normally have had.

PARA.TAB: It is important that we recognise that Commonwealth and State financial relations are littered with examples of States complaining about the Federal Government cajoling through conditional financial assistance. We are now seeing a similar set of events happening here. The Labor Government's commitment to cooperation with the States and the Territories is just shallow rhetoric. What else has been brought out by the process of this legislation? As several of my colleagues have mentioned, it is important that the Democrats have consulted through their network, very obviously, in recent days, weeks or months or whatever it has been, through the network of Greenpeace, the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Wilderness Society. As I heard Senator Coulter interject, there were some draft guidelines or outlines of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Draft outlines.

—Were those outlines presented to him as a fait accompli from those particular organisations or some representative group or were they presented by the Democrats for discussion to a constituency? They did not have the courage to share them with anyone else. Who else saw those guidelines? Did the States or the Territories? Was industry consulted to see whether there was any common ground at all in any of the issues? No. What happened is that the Democrats wheeled in here today 81 amendments, in the hope of doing some sort of backroom deal with the Government to put them through. The Democrats' treatment on this particular issue is well known. I had representations about this legislation back in September from the Northern Territory Fishing Industry Council. I quote from the representation that was made to me:

SPEECH.PARA: We wish to bring to your attention the fact that the Commonwealth Endangered Species Protection Bill will create significant problems for all land and marine based industries in Australia, including agriculture, forestry, mining, oil and fishing.
Further, it said:

We believe that this legislation will hinder Australia's economy and may not be the best way to protect endangered species. We therefore urge you to stop the current initiative of the Minister for the Environment to allow for more consultation and debate to determine the best means of protecting our endangered species without risking economic growth.

It is a very important representation. I am sure that many honourable senators would be aware of the concerns of the mining industry. I am certainly aware of various comments made by the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines and Petroleum and the advice and involvement it has sought in working through this legislation to ensure that there is a proper way of developing it. I am aware that Mr John Prescott, the chief of BHP, wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in September to say that giving a single Minister such powers would be against the national interest.

PARA.TAB: It is also very important, in looking at the mining considerations, to know what projects may be threatened at this time. Again, if I use the Northern Territory example, the Government has been, to its credit, fast-tracking the development proposals for the McArthur River developments of Mount Isa Mines near Borroloola. Similarly, I am aware that Mr Brereton and other Ministers, in conjunction with Ministers from the Northern Territory Government, have been seeking to get the Mount Todd gold mine under way early next year. I will bet the Democrats have not consulted with Mount Isa Mines or with Zapopan to find out whether there is any implication for those major projects, which are worth hundreds of millions of dollars and hundreds of jobs.

A week or so ago—I think it was on 20 November—I met with the Executive Officer of the Northern Territory Environment Council, Mr Jamie Pittock. We discussed a number of important environment issues, including this legislation. The concern of Mr Pittock certainly did not align in a number of areas with the other concerns that I had had from other constituents. But Mr Pittock alerted me to the fact that this legislation was flawed and needed further discussion.

Whilst I am sure that some of the issues the Democrats may have put forward in amendments might go some way towards meeting some of the Environment Council's concerns, as a constituent representative I would like the time and the opportunity to consult and find out where they are and whether the Democrat amendments are nothing more than something that has been conspired in some back room against national interests.

I mentioned earlier that I was very angry because of the steamrolling effect against the inter-government agreement on the environment. This negotiating process has now been totally thwarted. Let me just track through some very important dates. In March 1990 the then Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, announced the intention of the Federal Government to pass legislation to protect endangered species during the lifetime of the current Parliament. A year later, in April 1991 the Endangered Species Advisory Council provided Mrs Kelly with an options paper on endangered species legislation.

In early 1992, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories released a paper entitled Commonwealth Endangered Species Legislation—The Proposal. I am aware that the Northern Territory Government was involved with this legislative process from about that particular point. Certainly, in July 1992 at the third Australia-New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council meeting, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories gave an assurance that any draft legislation would be provided to agencies of that Council for their consideration.

On 20 August 1992, Mrs Kelly issued a press statement on the release of the revised ESAC document entitled A National Approach to Endangered Species. Mention was made at ANZECC to develop and report within one year on a national approach for the protection of vulnerable and endangered species. But no mention was made of any draft legislation. Let me remind honourable senators of that date—20 August 1992.

On 11 September 1992 the Northern Territory Conservation Commission contacted the secretary of ANZECC, advising him of the omission from the draft summary record of ANZECC of Mrs Kelly's commitment to consult with the States and Territories with regard to the proposed legislation.

The next date on which the Northern Territory Government, through its Conservation Commission, became involved was on 18 September 1992 when, through the agency of the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines—an independent, industry-based organisation—it was contacted and asked whether it knew anything about the endangered species legislation to be tabled in the Federal Parliament. No ANZECC agencies had received the promised draft legislation at that date. I think, quite rightly, at that point the Northern Territory Government assumed that what the Chamber of Mines was talking about was not a government Bill but perhaps Senator Coulter's other threatened species legislation that had also been mooted.

On 21 September 1992, the Northern Territory Conservation Minister received an unofficial copy of version 1 of the Bill from the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines, and was advised that the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy had also received an unofficial copy through AMIC. They were advised that the copies were very definitely unofficial, in draft, marked `in confidence' and that they had not, of course, been released by DASET.

The next day, on 22 September 1992, the Northern Territory Minister, Mr Reed, received a letter dated 18 September from Mrs Kelly's office advising that there would be a confidential briefing on the draft Commonwealth Bill on endangered species at Parliament House, Canberra, on Monday, 28 September. At that stage the Northern Territory Government had not received an official copy of the Bill, and nor had any other ANZECC agency. The matter was also being taken up about this time in the national press, emphasising the concerns of industries and that copies of the Bill had been leaked—it would be very interesting to know by whom.
The next day, on 23 September 1992, the Conservation Commission in the Northern Territory received a fax from Queensland quoting part of the draft record of the 13 August ESAC meeting, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommended against the release of the draft bill for public review if this was to prevent its passage in the current session. However if the bill was distributed for outside scrutiny, the Committee recommended that ESAC be included in this process.

Following this, Mr Reed, sent a letter to Mrs Kelly advising that Professor David Wigston would represent the Northern Territory at the briefing, listing a number of questions and concerns over the draft but certainly indicating that much more time was needed for consideration.

PARA.TAB: On 25 September, the Minister's office received by courier mail from DASET a copy of the draft Bill—version 1 turns up. Mr Reed took the initiative to arrange for as many State and Territory representatives as possible to attend the confidential meeting at Parliament House—coincidently, I am pleased to say that they used my rooms on the morning of 28 September.

On 28 September, three State and Territory representatives met at Parliament House, including the Northern Territory—coordinated, of course, by Professor David Wigston; New South Wales, which had also received its copy of the draft on 25 September; and Tasmania, which had not received a copy of the Bill from DASET but was in possession of an unofficial copy. At the briefing, two other representatives were also present: one from Queensland, who had not received the official copy but had his unofficial copy, and one from the ACT, who had received his official copy that morning—28 September.

On 1 October, having received a detailed report on the briefing session, Mr Reed telephoned Mrs Kelly and expressed his concerns over both the content of the draft Bill and the clandestine process for consideration. On 2 October 1992, at Mrs Kelly's request, Mr Reed wrote a detailed letter of concern over the contents and the process. This letter was copied to all of the State and Territory Ministers and a telephone conference was suggested.

On 13 October, Mr Reed's office received a letter from DASET advising that the Bill was being redrafted and inviting the Minister or representatives to attend another briefing at Parliament House on the evening of 15 October. On 15 October, Mr Reed met with Mrs Kelly and received her assurance that the draft Bill—now, of course, version 3—would be presented to ANZECC agencies for discussion on 6 November. There were more briefings. The agencies were assured that they would receive their final version 3 copy of the Bill for consideration and that it would be discussed on 6 November.

On 28 October a conversation took place to find out whether a copy of version 3 was yet officially available and DASET promised to reply. On 4 November, Professor Wigston from the Conservation Commission received a telephone call from DASET advising that version 3 was not yet available but would forward a copy when it was. Coincidently, that was the same day Minister Kelly made her second reading speech and presented the Bill in the House of Representatives.

On 6 November, Mrs Kelly tabled version 3 at the fourth meeting of ANZECC. Some of the agencies had received their copy the day before and others at that particular meeting. Of course, many of the mining industry representatives had obtained unofficial copies and others through various other agencies. Then, included with the unofficial copies is Mrs Kelly's second reading speech, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Extensive consultations with all relevant interest groups including industry, conservation organisations and the States and Territories followed during the development of the Bill.

What a farce. That was the process. As you are aware, Mr President, our shadow Minister, Mr Carlton, made his response in the House of Representatives on 12 November. Here we are today, under the threat of the guillotine, and the Democrats walk in here with 81 secret amendments to throw on the table at the last minute and conspire to get them passed. The process by which this Bill was to be considered tonight—

TALK.START.PARA: —What guillotine? It has not succeeded in cutting your throat.

—It is a pity sometimes that we cannot reciprocate. A number of issues flow from this. As I have mentioned, there are a lot of conflicts and conclusions in this Bill that have not been properly studied. We are not aware of the implications of the proposed 81 fundamental amendments of the Australian Democrats. Of course, there is no logical reason for the haste of either the Government, which has backtracked on its process, or the Democrats, who have to keep face with some funny groups that they have put together. I am aware that the Northern Territory Chief Minister wrote to the Prime Minister on 19 October. I am sure he would have reflected the views of all States and Territories when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Further to my letter of 8 October 1992, I write again in relation to your Government's proposed Endangered Species Legislation. I understand Federal Cabinet will consider redrafted legislation on 20 October 1992.

While the Northern Territory Minister for Conservation and Government officials received certain assurances in relation to this redrafted legislation at separate briefings in Canberra on 15 October 1992, it nevertheless remains a serious concern to me the undue haste with which the Commonwealth is proceeding with this legislation.

With the report of the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council (ANZECC) on a draft National Endangered Species Strategy nearing completion, a national strategy due to be finalised by March of next year, and serious reservations by industry about this redrafted legislation, I urge you to defer action until the national consultative process is finalised under the orderly processes set down in our Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment.
Yours sincerely,
MARSHALL PERRON.
I am sure Mr Perron speaks for all States and Territories in making that statement. I hope the Senate will consider their views.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, in view of the hour and in anticipation of what will probably be a prolonged committee stage for the Endangered Species Protection Bill 1992 and the Endangered Species Protection (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1992, I will be brief. I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate and indicate that the Government will not be supporting the second reading amendment moved by Senator Macdonald—which I know will come as a dreadful shock to him.

PARA.TAB: The amendment has the effect of accusing the Government of bypassing the ecologically sustainable development process and ignoring the intergovernmental agreement on the environment. The amendment is wrong on both counts. The maintenance of biological diversity is one of the basic tenets of ecologically sustainable development. The maintenance of species diversity is an essential component of biological diversity; that is, protecting endangered species is basic to the ecologically sustainable development process. This Bill is not inconsistent with the intergovernmental agreement on the environment which does not require jurisdictions to clear legislation with one another.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Macdonald's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
That consideration of the Bills in Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.
Motion (by Senator Collins) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the Senate too long, but I cannot allow an article in the most recent issue of Sydney's Sunday Telegraph to go unanswered. The article, an apparently regular feature on family law, is written by one Peter Dowding, partner with Briggs Dowding, who bill themselves as family law specialists.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators may recall that Peter Dowding had a somewhat unsuccessful career as a one-time Western Australia State Premier. He has now returned to a more profitable field, it appears. Given, he says, that his practice is one that specialises in family law—a very lucrative practice—one could also suggest that therefore he would have a vested interest in ensuring the status quo. I take somewhat with a grain of salt his article headed `A long wait for very little', which purports to comment on the family law report which was tabled last week. He claims that the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act suffers from the `Canberra syndrome'—that we have called for more complex regulations and more Acts of parliament that will lead to a massive escalation in the cost of litigation.

I can only suggest that perhaps Mr Dowding is trying to pre-empt a case for increasing his own fees or that he has not read the report very carefully. At length in the report in my own comments and in submissions, members of the Committee have dealt strongly with the at times outrageous costs of family law litigation. Perhaps in my remarks last week I did not make myself quite clear enough when I said that the legal profession needed to take a long hard look at its fee structure. Perhaps I should also have been a little more direct, and I will be more direct now.

There are solicitors specialising in family law who have made a very lucrative business out of lengthy and expensive litigation, invariably not in the clients' best interest. It is time that the whole system was simplified, cleaned up and the cost and pain minimised—and that is precisely and concisely what the report suggests should happen. I am not for one moment suggesting that Mr Dowding is a solicitor such as I have just described. Far be it from me to suggest that I know more about family law than he. After all, it is now his professional career. He has also had considerable experience in the court, which is something that I have not had.

I am suggesting that obviously Mr Dowding has not read past the first page of the report. Indeed, we have a total of 120 recommendations, but Mr Dowding has ignored all but one—and, strangely, that is the very first. Admittedly, it is a purely administrative recommendation but, nevertheless, quite important and quite undeserving of the cynical criticism levelled by Mr Dowding.

I am quite appalled at the lack of depth of treatment Mr Dowding has given the report and I can only assume—indeed, I can only hope that he is so busy in his family law practice that he did not have sufficient time and concentration to write an article worthy of better comment. I would hate to think he would take any client of his into court as ill-prepared and ill-informed about their case as he appears to be in commenting on this parliamentary report.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you were a part of that report. The Committee had before it 1,031 submissions; we had 112 witnesses half of whom were private individuals. The 120 recommendations were made by an all party Committee comprising members from both Houses of this Parliament. Its report was unanimous, except for two or three small items by Senator Spindler.

I do agree with Mr Dowding when he says in his article that the Child Support Agency is an organisation that in his view cries out for an early inquiry. Basically, that is what we have said in our report. But even on that issue he did not really give us as big a compliment as he could have. I believe that people who write articles in papers, especially if they are in a business and writing on behalf of that business, should look to the facts, look a little bit behind the report, look into it a lot more deeply and look at some of the submissions we received. I believe that Senator McKiernan led the Committee in such a way that we gave a good balanced report. I believe that Mr Peter Dowding, ex-Premier, stands condemned for his article in the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to keep the Senate long tonight in speaking on the article in the Sunday Telegraph of 29 November which has just been addressed by Senator Brownhill. I was very disappointed this morning to read the article in question. I have not made a point of following Mr Dowding's articles on this particular topic which have been occurring for quite a period of time; I gave it up pretty early in the piece. I think Peter Dowding has a reputation for not paying attention to detail, and certainly in this article he has not done so again.

PARA.TAB: I do not have a problem at all with people criticising the report that was brought down in this place last Tuesday. As a matter of fact, we welcome criticism because the report is out there for people to scrutinise. But before people enter into print with criticisms, surely they should at least read what they have in front of them. It is quite obvious and quite apparent that Mr Dowding did not read the report before he put pen to paper to write this article.

As I have said, I do not have a problem with criticism of our report. But the Sunday Telegraph is a widely circulated newspaper and people will read Mr Dowding's article because they are interested in the topic of family law. I believe that Peter Dowding, in putting forward an article like this, has done a disservice to himself and to his legal practice, and also to the newspaper's readers. People will get distorted ideas of what is contained in our report.

I believe this is a report that will stand on its own. I will not seek to defend it here. It will be defended by others in other places in time. If even some of the recommendations that we put forward are implemented by a government at some time in the future, I think our committee work over a period of 20 months will have been worthwhile and fruitful. I regret that Peter, an ex-Premier of Western Australia, an ex-Labor Party parliamentarian, has stooped to these depths. I do not know the reason, but it is unfortunate that sometimes upon retirement from parliament politicians go the way that they do.

I want to mention another individual who has done the Committee somewhat of a disservice as well. On 10 October last year in an adjournment speech I mentioned an article that appeared in the Canberra Times on 7 October by one Mr Ian Monk. The article was headed, `Whitewash feared from family law inquiry'. Mr Monk made those comments

SPEECH.PARA: over 13 months ago. He has done exactly the same thing again. He reached his conclusions in October last year. That was little better than Mr Dowding. Mr Dowding waited until the report came out. But Mr Monk reached his conclusions 13 months ago, before the Committee had embarked upon its public inquiry, and on Tuesday of last week, the day after the report was presented to the Parliament, issued a press statement which read:
Please be advised of the anticipated release in Federal Parliament of the report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Family Law Act.

Mr Ian Monk of Sydney, whose reform campaign was instrumental in the establishment of this far reaching and potentially controversial inquiry, will be available for comment following the report's tabling.
He can be contacted on Monday 23 November and Tuesday 24 November. . .

at a hotel here in Canberra. Some gullible members of the media have taken up Mr Monk's suggestion, and one television station put him to air. He too had not read the report. I think I speak on behalf of all members of the Committee, a joint, all-party representative committee, in saying that we would all welcome criticism, but at least let it be informed criticism. People should read the thing. It is 450 pages long and it is available at government bookshops. People should read it, and then if they do not agree with it inform somebody. But they should at least do us the justice of informing themselves rather than making mugs of themselves as Mr Dowding and Mr Monk have done in recent days.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
